Hoy día gracias a su gran empreño y decisión ya tiene su propia micro empresa, “taller de motos y venta de repuestos para motos”, la misma esta ubicada en su propia casa. El negocio que maneja cada vez tiene más clientela y mayor volumen de inventarios, lo que demuestra la exitosa gestión de este emprendedor

El crédito lo utilizara para compra de repuestos para motocicletas.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for motorcycles

loans.name: Kuña Guapa De Yaguaron Group

texts.es:
In the city of Yagyarón, 15 km from the office in Paraguarí, a group of women got together with the desire to undertake activities which would allow them to increase their income. The contacted us to find out more about the program and accepted the terms due to the many benefits it offers to them.

The group is called Kuña Guapa and they are now in their second cycle with an excellent record and 15 active members.

These women perform different activities including the sale of staple goods, fruits, vegetables, fast food, beverages, handicrafts and items for the home.

The loan they are requesting will be used to buy more merchandise so they can continue to progress and increase their income.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

En la ciudad de Yaguarón distante a 15 Km. De la Oficina de Paraguarí, se reunieron unas señoras con ganas de emprender actividades con el fin de aumentar sus ingresos, de ahí que se pusieron en contacto con nosotros para interiorizarse sobre el programa, quienes aceptaron por los múltiples beneficios que presenta.

El comité lleva por nombre Kuña Guapa, quienes actualmente se encuentran en el segundo ciclo, con calificación excelente, integrada por 15 activas mujeres.

Estas mujeres se dedican a diferentes actividades como despensa, venta de frutas y verduras, venta de comidas rápidas, venta de bebidas, artesanías y artículos para el hogar.

El crédito que solicitan desean invertirlo en la compra de mercaderías, de este modo seguir progresando y aumentando sus ingresos.

loans.use: Purchase fabric, thread, meat, beverages, milk, cooking oil, pasta, rice, flour, mens furnishings, linen goods and various fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Moises

texts.es:
Moisés is 49 years old and his wife, Luisa, is 45. They are the parents of two school aged children.

Moisés started out as a builder working for five years in the hydroelectric plant in Itaipú. Later he worked for three more years in the country’s other hydroelectric plant called Yacyreta.

After that he returned to his hometown to establish his life there and to work. He invested some of his savings to open a butcher shop where he worked for three years but then had to close it due to health reasons.

Moisés later purchased a van that he now uses to transport schoolchildren. His wife, a retired teacher, stays home to take care of their children. Even though he got sick, his entrepreneurial spirit has helped him maintain a lucrative, independent job.

This loan will be used to repair his van that he needs for work in order to provide for his family.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

El señor Moisés tiene 49 años de edad, y su esposa la señora Luisa 45y son padres de dos hijos que aún están en edad escolar. Moisés se inició como constructor, trabajando en la Hidroeléctrica de Itaipú durante 5 años, luego trabajo en la otra Hidroeléctrica del país llamada Yacyreta en donde trabajo otros tres años más. Luego de ello, volvió a su ciudad natal para establecerse y trabajar. Primeramente invirtió unos ahorros y abrió una carnicería en la que trabajo durante tres años, la cual tuvo que cerrar por motivos de salud. Actualmente su esposa es docente jubilada y por ahora se queda en la casa a cuidar de sus hijos, mientras que su marido compró un vehículo que lo utiliza de trasporte escolar, a pesar de haberse enfermado, su espíritu emprendedor no se apago por lo que mantiene un trabajo independiente y lucrativo.

El préstamo lo utilizará para reparar su vehículo que es su medio de trabajo y el que constituye el ingreso de la familia.

loans.use: Repair a van used for work.

loans.name: Priscila

texts.es:
Priscila is 55 years old and is a widow with three grown children, two boys and a girl, who are now independent. Her entire forty-year career has been spent building her own business. She learned from her parents when she was very young and, with the dream of getting a good job, moved to her country’s capital to find work and to study. However, she soon faced the sad reality that it wasn’t so easy and that there was a lot of competition and no shortage of employers waiting to take advantage of her. It was then that she decided to start her own business in market number four there in the capital and rented a stand where she could sell staple goods.

Later she married and returned to her hometown where she continued in the same business with much success. Today she has a general store where she sells staple goods and items for the home and her prosperous business continues to grow.

This loan will be used to buy sugar, pasta, baked goods, herbs, rice, fruits, vegetables, canned goods and items for the home.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Priscila tiene 55 años de edad, es viuda con tres hijos, dos varones y una mujer; todos ya mayores e independientes. Ella se dedica al comercio hace más de cuarenta años, toda una vida dedicada a esta actividad.

Este oficio lo aprendió de sus padres desde muy joven, y con el sueño de obtener un buen empleo se mudó a la capital, para poder trabajar y estudiar, sin embargo se encontró con la triste realidad de que no era fácil ya que había mucha competencia y no faltaban empleadores que querían aprovecharse de ella. Fue así que decidió emprender su propio negocio en el mercado cuatro de la capital, alquilando un puesto en donde vendía mercaderías de primera necesidad.

Luego se casó y regresó a su ciudad, en donde prosiguió en el mismo ramo con mucho éxito, hoy día tiene un prospero negocio que crece cada vez más, el mismo es un almacén en donde vende productos de primera necesidad para el hogar.

El préstamo lo utilizará para compra de azúcar, fideo, panificados, yerba ,arroz, frutas, verduras, productos enlatados, artículos para el hogar, etc.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise to sell including herbs, rice, fruits, vegetables, canned goods and items for the home.

loans.name: Rogelio

texts.es:
Rogelio is 50 years old and his wife, Estela, is 48. They are the parents of four children, three boys and a girl, all of whom are students. Rogelio works selling typical handicrafts and his wife has been making quilts for more than 25 years.

Since he was very young, Rogelio has had a lot of success in sales that continues to this day. He also buys and sells cattle with the help of his parents who are in that business. Thanks to an entrepreneurial spirit, Rogelio and his wife have made progress and been able to support a family, build a home and have two vehicles – a motorcycle and pick-up truck – that are also used for work. Their home has many comforts which shows us that with hard work, it’s possible to get ahead while working independently.

The loan that Rogelio is requesting will be used to buy products to sell including towels, bed sheets and blankets and also to buy various colors of cotton thread that his wife can use to make her quilts.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

El señor Rogelio tiene 50 años de edad y su esposa la señora Estela 48, ellos son padres de cuatro hijos, tres varones y una mujer, todos estudiantes. Él se dedica a la venta ambulante de artículos típicos, y su esposa a la fabricación de colchas de hilo hace ya más de veinticinco años.

Desde muy joven, se inicio en esta actividad con la cual continua con mucho éxito hasta la actualidad, además de ello también se dedica a la compra y venta de ganado con la ayuda de sus padres que se dedican a los mismo. Gracias a su espíritu emprendedor, llegaron a progresar, pudiendo sostener una familia, construir una casa y contar con dos vehículos una moto y una camioneta que son también sus herramientas de trabajo. Su casa cuenta con buenas comodidades y nos demuestran que con una buena gestión se puede salir adelante en forma independiente.

El préstamo que solicita desea invertirlo en la compra de mercaderías varias para la venta como toallas, sabanas, frazadas además de comprar hilos de algodón de distintos colores para que su esposa pueda seguir elaborando sus cubrecamas.

loans.use: Purchase towels, bed sheets, blankets and various colors of cotton thread.

loans.name: Comité Paraíso Group

texts.es:
This group is made up of 15 enterprising women who perform different types of activities in order to generate a better income for their families. All of them, besides being dedicated mothers and spouses, perform diverse activities such as, for example, selling fruit, vegetables and other staple foods, managing kiosks, selling clothes and cakes and working as seamstresses.

  The women are currently in the third cycle of the program and assure us that it has been very helpful to them since they have learned to save money and work as a team. They are a very reliable group when it comes to payments and attending their weekly meetings.

This group of women, who call themselves “Paradise,” is requesting a loan in order to purchase additional merchandise to sell.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

Este grupo de mujeres emprendedoras esta conformado por 15 señoras que realizan distintos tipos de actividades para generar mayores ingresos a sus familias. Todas, además de ser madres y esposas dedicadas, realizan diversos tipos de actividades como por ejemplo venta de frutas, verduras, despensas, kioscos, venta de ropas, venta de tortas, costureras, etc.

Se encuentran en el tercer ciclo del programa y aseguran que el mismo les ha sido de gran ayuda, ya que aprendieron a ahorrar y trabajar en equipo. Son un grupo muy cumplidor en sus pagos y en las reuniones que se realizan cada semana.

El comité lleva por nombre El Paraíso, y solicitan un crédito para invertirlo en la compra de mercaderías para su venta.

loans.use: Purchase fabric, yarn, meat, beverages, milk, cooking oil, pasta, rice, flour, mens furnishings and linens

loans.name: Myrian's Group

texts.es:
On Conavi Boulevard in the city of Carapeguá, Paraguay, 1 km from the Carapeguá office, several women of limited resources found out about an Enterprising Women’s Committee program developed by the Paraguayan Foundation and decided to get together in order to receive more information about the program.

These women, eager to progress in their businesses to be able to help their spouses and to offer a better future to their families, formed a workgroup in order to ask for credit and receive the benefits of the program. The group has demonstrated great progress and all of the women have some money saved thanks to good organization and hard work. Their main activity is the sale of crafts; others are weavers or retailers (selling a variety of products) and one of them offers in-home manicures and pedicures.

The women are very responsible with their meetings and payments and for that reason qualify today for additional credit. The money will be used to purchase merchandise to sell.  

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

En la ciudad de Carapeguá en el Bo.Conavi distante a 1 km de Oficina de Carapeguá ,unas señoras de escasos recursos tuvieron conocimiento del programa de comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras que desarrolla la Fundación Paraguaya y decidieron reunirse para recibir una información sobre el mencionado programa.

Estas mujeres, deseosas de progresar en sus negocios para así poder ayudar a sus esposos y brindar un mejor porvenir a sus familias, formaron su grupo de trabajo para solicitar sus créditos y recibir los beneficios del programa.

Estas mujeres han demostrado un gran progreso y todas ya tienen un buen dinero ahorrado gracias a su buena organización y trabajo. La principal actividad des estas mujeres es la venta de artesanías, otras son tejedoras, comerciantes (ventas varias) y una de ellas se dedica a la manicura y pedicura a domicilio.

Son muy responsables en sus reuniones y sus pagos, es por ello que hoy pueden tener acceso a un nuevo crédito para poder invertirlos en la compra de mercaderías para sus ventas.

loans.use: Purchase cotton yarn, handicrafts, fruit, vegetables, hand lotion, nailfiles and hair products.

loans.name: Virgen Del Carmen Group

texts.es:
In the city of Quiindy, a city that is about 20 km distant from Carapeguá, there is found one of the regional Offices of Paraguayan Foundation. Some ladies of scarce resources were informed of the Enterprising Women committee program and they decided to meet to receive information on the program.

Seeking a little more support to increase their family incomes through credit and to improve their quality of life, they decided to form the group called “Virgen del Carmen”. This group is composed of15 enterprising women that carry out activities such as the sale of eggs and milk, vegetables, balls, typical foods like chipa, as well as farming and running newsstands, etc.

With the loan, they hope to buy leather and thread for making balls, as well as vegetables, merchandise for the store such as carbonated water, meats, fruits, vegetables, products for the home, as well as cheeses and cornmeal for making chipas (a bread made from corn and cheese).

This group has grown, thanks to this program, and at present they are completing their fifth loan, having already participated in the program for 20 months. They need this loan to invest in their respective micro-businesses and to achieve a sustainable growth that will allow them to grow as successful micro-businesswomen.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

En la ciudad de Quiindy, ciudad que dista de Carapeguá unos 20 km. en donde se encuentra una de las Oficinas regionales de Fundación Paraguaya unas señoras de escasos recursos se enteraron del programa de comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras y decidieron reunirse para recibir una información sobre el programa.

Buscando un poco más de apoyo para fomentar a través del crédito sus ingresos familiares y mejorar su calidad de vida, decidieron formara su grupo denominado Virgen del Carmen, la misma esta compuesta por 15 mujeres emprendedoras que realizan actividades como venta de huevos y leche, venta de verduras, granja, venta de pelotas, ventas de comidas típicas como chipa, kioscos, etc.

Desean comprar con el crédito: cuero y  de hilo para la costura de pelotas, así como también para la compra verduras, mercaderías para el almacén como gaseosas, carnes, frutas, verduras, productos para el hogar, además para la compra de  quesos, harina de maíz para la elaboración de chipas.

Estas personas crecieron gracias a este programa y actualmente se encuentran dentro del quinto ciclo teniendo ya 20 meses dentro del programa. Necesitan esta operación crediticia para invertir en sus respectivas microempresas y lograr un crecimiento sostenible que les haga crecer como micro empresarias exitosas.

loans.use: to buy leather and thread for making balls, vegetables, carbonated water, meats, fruits, and products for the home, as well as cheeses and cornmeal for making chipas.

loans.name: "kullaquitas" Group

texts.es:
In the city of El Alto, in the Rio Seco zone is found the Pro-Mujer "pan-american" center. Inside this center we find the "kullakitas" association, comprised of 15 associates that form an united, organized and happy group.

Almost all of them are married with an average of 4 children each, generally young. The majority of their children are under the age of 15. They tell us that it is difficult for them to support their large families with the current situation in the country, since basic supplies have risen in price substantially and the few resources that they can obtain do not give them enough to live on.

Most of them are dedicated chiefly to crafts, being carpenters. They produce furniture with old designs in carved wood. Also they weave sweaters with Alpaca wool and aguayos (blanket woven with native designs), products that they offer to tourist stores in the city of La Paz. The "Kullaquitas" association needs to increase its capital for the purchase of materials. In this way they hope to increase their production and acquire their own stores to sell their products directly. In this way their profits will also increase with the sole objective of giving their small children a tranquil and stable life.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

En la ciudad de El Alto, en la zona de rio seco se encuentra en centro focal “Panamericana” de Pro-Mujer, dentro este centro encontramos a la asociación “kullakitas”, integradas por 15 socias que forman un grupo unido, organizado y alegre.

Casi todas estan casadas con un promedio de 4 hijos, por lo general pequeños la mayoria menores a los 15 años, ellas nos cuentan que les resulta dificil mantener estas numerosas familias por la actual situacion del pais ya que los productos de primera necesidad subieron de precio cuantiosamente y los pocos recursos que ellas consiguen no les abastece para subsistir.

La mayor parte de ellas se dedica principalmente a la artesania, siendo asi el oficio de la carpinteria, donde producen muebles con diseños antiguos en madera tallada, tambien realizan el tejido de chompas en lana de Alpaca, y tejido de aguayos ( manta tejida con diseños autoctonos), productos que los ofrecen a tiendas turisticas de la ciudad de La Paz. La asociacion "Kullaquitas" necesita incrementar su capital para la compra de materia prima, de esta forma incrementara su produccion y alquilarian tiendas propias para vender sus productos de manera directa, de esta forma sus ganancias tambien aumentarian con el unico objetivo de brindar a sus pequeños hijos una vida estable y tranquila.

loans.use: To purchase materials (wood and wool) and to acquire their own stores to sell their crafts.

loans.name: La Amistad Group

texts.es:
THE ASSOCIATION CALLED "THE FRIENDSHIP" HAS BELONGED TO THE FAMILY OF PRO-MUJER FOR MANY YEARS COMPLETING ALREADY 19 LOANS. THE GROUP IS LOCATED IN THE ZONE OF ALTA LIMA, CITY OF EL ALTO. CURENTLY THE GROUP HAS 15 ASSOCIATES AND IT HAS PROVEN TO BE A GROUP ORGANIZED TO MANAGE THEIR LOANS.

AMONG THOSE IN THE GROUP THE MAJORITY ARE MARRIED WITH CHILDREN, ALMOST ALL OF SCHOOL AGE, EXCEPT THAT, IN SOME CASES, THEY LACK THE RESOURCES AND, PITIFULLY, THEIR CHILDREN COULD NOT ENTER SCHOOL. IN THESE CASES, THE CHILDREN OFTEN HELP THEIR PARENTS IN THEIR SMALL BUSINESS AND TAKE CARE OF THEIR SMALLER BROTHERS AND SISTERS.

THEY HAVE DIFFERENT BUSINESSES SUCH AS; THE SALE OF CHICKEN MEAT, MILK, AND UNDERWEAR BUT THE MAIN ACTIVITY IS THE SEWING OF SPORTS CLOTHING THAT, ONCE PRODUCED. THEY SELL IN THE OPEN AIR MARKETS OF THE CITY OF LA PAZ. THEY SAY THAT THEY NEED MORE CAPITAL FOR THE PURCHASE OF BETTER QUALITY FABRICS. IN THIS MANNER THEIR PRODUCTS ALSO WILL BE BETTER QUALITY AND THEY WILL HAVE MORE CLIENTS. BY INCREASING THEIR PROFITS WITH THE ULTIMATE OBJECTIVE OF IMPROVING THEIR ECONOMIC SITUATION THEY HOPE TO OFFER THEIR CHILDREN A BETTER FORM OF LIFE CHIEFLY IN THEIR EDUCATION.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

LA ASOCIACION DENOMINADA “LA AMISTAD” PERTENECE A LA FAMILIA DE PRO-MUJER HACE YA VARIOS AÑOS CUMPLIENDO CON 19 CICLOS DE CREDITO, ESTA SE ENCUENTRA EN LA ZONA DE ALTO LIMA, DE LA CIUDAD DE EL ALTO, A LA FECHA CUENTA CON 15 SOCIAS Y HA DEMOSTRADO SER UN GRUPO ORGANIZADO EN CUANTO A SUS CUOTAS DE CREDITO.

DENTRO EL GRUPO LA MAYORIA SON CASADAS Y CON HIJOS, CASI TODOS EN EDAD ESCOLAR, EXISTIENDO ALGUNOS CASOS QUE POR FALTA DE RECURSOS LASTIMOSAMENTE SUS HIJOS NO PUDIERON INGRESAR A LA ESCUELA. YA QUE ESTOS DEBEN AYUDAR A SUS PADRS EN SUS PEQUEÑOS NEGOCIOS Y CUIDAR DE SUS HERMANOS MENORES.

EXISTEN DIFERENTES NEGOCIOS DENTRO LA ASOCIACION COMO SER; LA VENTA DE CARNE DE POLLO, DE LACTEOS, ROPA INTIMA PERO LA ACTIVIDAD PRINCIPAL ES LA COSTURA DE PRENDAS DEPORTIVAS QUE UNA VEZ PRODUCIDAS LAS VENDEN EN LAS FERIAS DE LA CIUDAD DE LA PAZ ELLAS AFIRMAN QUE NECESITAN MAYOR CAPITAL PARA LA COMPRA DE TELAS DE MEJOR CALIDAD DE ESTA MANERA SUS PRIDUCTOS TAMBIEN TENDRIAN MEJOR CALIDAD Y ASI OBTENDRIAN MAYORES CLIENTES Y POR COINSIGUIENTE MAYORES GANANCIAS CON EL UNICO OBJETIVO DE MEJORAR SU SITUACION ECONOMICA DE ESTA MANERA OFRECER A SUS HIJOS UNA MEJOR FORMA DE VIDA PRINCIPALMENTE EN SU EDUCACION.

loans.use: To purchase better quality fabrics for making sports clothing.

loans.name: Aguilas Group

texts.es:
THE COMMUNITY CENTER “ALTO LIMA” IS LOCATED IN THE BALLIVIAN ZONE OF THE CITY OF EL ALTO. THE “AGUILAS” ASSOCIATION, COMPRISED OF 18 ASSOCIATES, MEETS THERE. THEY ARE A VERY AGREEABLE GROUP THAT,WITH THEIR LOAN ADVISOR, RICHARD SUXO, HAS WORKED WITH PRO-MUJER TO COMPLETE TWO LOANS. THE MAJORITY OF THEM HAVE SMALL CHILDREN THAT REQUIRE BASIC MEDICAL ATTENTION. THAT IS TO SAY THEY HAVE NOT HAD VACCINATIONS OR MEDICAL CHECKUPS FOR LACK OF ECONOMIC RESOURCES.

THE ACTIVITIES THAT THE "AGUILAS" ASSOCIATION MEMBERS PERFORM ARE OF ALL TYPES. FOR EXAMPLE, ONE OF THEM IS DEDICATED TO CARPENTRY. ANOTHER BAKES BREAD AND BISCUITS FOR SALE TO THE NEIGHBORHOOD STORES. BUT THE MAJORITY ARE DEDICATED TO THE MANUFACTURE OF CLOTHES SUCH AS: JACKETS, BAGS, SPORTS CLOTHES AND ALSO WHAT THEY CALL THE DRESSMAKING OF CASUAL CLOTHES; THAT IS TO SAY BLOUSES, SKIRTS AND T-SHIRTS.

THEY STATE THAT THEY NEED MORE CAPITAL FOR THE PURCHASE OF MACHINES FOR THE BAKERY AND CLOTHING BUSINESS, SO THEY CAN INCREASE THEIR PRODUCTION AND QUALITY. IN THIS WAY THEY HOPE TO BE ABLE TO GENERATE GREATER RESOURCES, ALL THIS FOR THE GOOD OF THEIR FAMILIES, SINCE INCREASING THEIR INCOMES WILL ALLOW THEM TO ASSURE THE HEALTH AND WELFARE OF THEIR CHILDREN.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

EN LA ZONA BALLIVIAN DE LA CIUDAD DE EL ALTO SE ENCUENTRA HUBICADO EL CENTRO FOCAL ALTO LIMA, A ESTE PERTENECE LA ASOCIACION “AGUILAS” INTEGRADO POR 18 SOCIAS. UN GRUPO MUY SINPATICO QUE JUNTO A SU ASESOR DE CREDITOS RICHARD SUXO, TRABAJAN CON PRO-MUJER HACE DOS CICLOS. LA MAYORIA DE ELLAS TIENEN NIÑOS PEQUEÑOS, QUE REQUIEREN ATENCIONES MEDICAS BASICAS, VALE DECIR QUE NO CUENTAN CON VACUNAS Y VALORACIONES INDISPENSABLES, POR FALTA DE RECURSOS ECONÓMICOS.

LAS ACTIVIDADES QUE REALIZA LA ASOCIACIÓN “AGUILAS” SON DE TODO TIPO, POR EJEMPLO UNA DE ELLAS SE DEDICA A LA CARPINTERIA, OTRAS PRODUCEN PAN Y BISCOCHOS PARA LUEGO OFRECERLOS A LAS TIENDAS DEL BARRIO, PERO LA MAYORIA SE DEDICA A LA CONFECCION DE ROPA COMOS SER: CHAMARRAS, SACOS, ROPA DEPORTIVA Y TAMBIEN COMO ELLAS DENOMINAN LA COSTURA DE ROPA LIVIANA, ES DECIR BLUSAS, FALDAS Y POLERAS,

AFIRMAN QUE NECESITAN MAYOR CAPITAL PARA LA COMPRA DE MAQUINAS DE CONFECCION, ASI AUMENTARIA SU PRODUCCIÓN Y CALIDAD, DE ESTA FORMA PODER GENERAR MAYORES RECURSOS, TODO ESTO PARA EL BIEN DE SUS FAMILIAS YA QUE AUMENTANDO SUS INGRESOS PODRIAN ASEGURAR LA SALUD Y BIENESTAR DE SUS HIJOS.

loans.use: To buy machines for the bakery and clothing businesses.

loans.name: Milena

texts.en:
Milena R. D. R. owns a beautiful restaurant in the city of Pucallpa, in the Ucayali region of Peru. She started the business three years ago and now has many loyal customers, who come to enjoy lunch, drink a beer, or eat dinner. They enjoy the warm and contemporary environment.

Milena is a 49-year-old widow with two children. She decided to open the restaurant because she loves to cook food and proviD. a service she can be proud of. She is creative and smart. She used the Internet to find a good design for her bar, and she came up with the theme for the decor herself. She works hard so she can send her youngest son to college, and she has no one else to rely on.

A member of the community bank Las Abejitas, Milena is requesting a loan of $475 to repay over four months. She will use the loan to buy rice, beer, oil, sugar, and condiments for her restaurant.

loans.use: To buy rice, beer, oil, sugar, and condiments for her restaurant

loans.name: Irma

texts.en:
Irma M. S. owns land where she plants various crops near the city of Pucallpa, in the Ucayali region of Peru. On this land she plans to plant cilantro, peppers, corn, and sugarcane. Irma has a lifetime of experience farming and harvesting in the Peruvian Amazon Basin.

Irma is 66 years old, has four children, and is happily married. She loves working and helping her family. In the future she plans on investing in the business and increasing production. The family currently uses only a small percentage of their land.

A member of the community bank Las Abejitas, Irma is requesting a loan of $550 to repay over four months. She will use the loan to buy seeds to plant her future crops.

loans.use: To buy seeds to plant her future crops

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a variety of different items

loans.name: Mujeres Perseverantes Group

texts.es:
In the city of el Alto, in the zone Ballivian is found the Pro-Mujer center called "Alto Lima". Inside this center we find the "Persistent Women" association. Under this name, 16 associates form a very united and organized group. Only nine of them have completed their studies. The remainder sadly have only learned to read and to write in a very basic way. It is a great dream to be able to go to the adult school to complete their studies, that for the time being and for lack of resources they cannot do.

The majority of them dedicate themselves chiefly to the sale of clothes, design of hats, and making of henhouses and blankets, products that they offer in the main open air markets of the City of el Alto. Besides needing greater resources for the purchase of special machinery, they require capital for the purchase of materials, with the objective of enlarging their production and thus obtaining greater profits. With this they hope to be able to complete their studies and to support their families in a better way of life.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

En la ciudad de El Alto, en la zona Ballivian se encuentra en centro focal “Alto Lima” dentro este centro encontramos a la asociación “Mujeres Perseverantes”, bajo esta denominación 16 socias forman un grupo muy unido y organizado. Solo nueve de ellas tiene estudios culminados el resto lamentablemente aprendió a leer y escribir da manera muy básica, siendo un gran sueño él poder entrar a la escuela de adultos para culminar sus estudios que de momento por falta de recursos no pueden realizarlo.

La mayoría de ellas dedican principalmente a la venta de ropa, diseño de sombreros, confección de polleras y mantas, productos que los exponen en las principales ferias de la Ciudad del Alto. Además de necesitar mayores recursos para la compra de maquinaria especial requieren capital para la compra de materia prima, con el objetivo de aumentar su producción así obtener mayores ganancias y con esto poder culminar sus estudios y apoyar a que sus familias tenga una mejor forma de vida

loans.use: To purchase special machinery and more materials for the making of clothes, hats, henhouses and blankets

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase different supplies

loans.name: Sinat

texts.en: Mrs. Sinat M. is a 42-year-old woman living in the Vihea Villlage of Kandal Province. She is a grocer who sells her goods in the village. As for her family life, she is a single mother with two children, one of whom is enrolled in school while the other is working and generates approximately $1.25 of income per day. Additionally, she has cultivatable land, but she does not have money to buy rice seeds to grow on the field. In order to address this dilemma, she is seeking a loan to buy rice seeds.

loans.use: To purchase rice seeds to plant on her cultivatable land.

loans.name: Yor

texts.en: Mrs. Yor T., a 51-year-old widow, sells groceries and coffee in the Kor Village, Phnom Penh City. She earns around $5 per day and has two children, both of whom are married. Her son is a bricklayer, while another daughter is a fish seller. To sustain her business and expand for the future, T. now asks for a $1,000 loan to improve her grocery and coffee-selling business by increasing her stock.

loans.use: To improve her grocery and coffee selling business by increasing her stock

loans.name: Loep

texts.en: Mrs. Loep K. C., 55, is a farmer who earns $5 per day. A widow, she has five children and lives in the Muoy Village, Phnom Penh City. Two children work in Malaysia, and a third works in the garment industry in Phnom Penh. Mrs. C. now requests a loan of $800 to increase her working capital for her farming business. She hopes this loan will improve her family’s financial stability.

loans.use: To increase her working capital for her farming business

loans.name: Dot

texts.en: Mrs. Dot M. is 44 years old and she lives in the Vihea Village of Kandal Province. She is a subsistence farmer and a widow with three children. Two of her children are working and they can each generate approximately $4.25 per day of income, while her other child is attending school. Mrs. Dot M. relies heavily on her two working children to support the family; even so, she usually goes to a field to work and later goes home to cook for her children. In order to improve her family's standard of living, she is seeking a loan to buy rice seeds to grow in her field.

loans.use: To purchase rice seeds to cultivate in her field.

loans.name: Yem

texts.en: Mrs. Yem C., 32, makes about $5 per day growing edible aquatic plants and selling fish.  She lives with her husband, Suy Bros, and her two children at Stung Chrov Village, Kandal Province. Mr. Bros has been a motorbike taxi driver since 2005 and earns about $5 per day. In order to expand her business, Mrs. C. now seeks a $600 loan to buy a fishing boat and net. With this loan, Mrs. C. will grow edible aquatic plants easier and fish in the Stung Chrov Lake, Kandal Province. It will also help her sustain her family’s living expenses.

loans.use: To buy a fishing boat and net

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To continue stocking store with different products

loans.name: Neang

texts.en:
Neang S. is a 24 year-old housewife in Kampong Cham province. Her husband, Chren Sangbong, is a vendor who sells cashew nuts in stock through a local market. His business brings in about 7 USD daily to support her and their only child.

She wants to use her loan to purchase a larger stock of cashews for her husband to sell and thereby increase his profits. If he can generate enough additional revenue, they would like to expand to sell both cashews and yams in bulk over the border to Vietnam.

loans.use: To purchase cashew nuts in stock to resell for profit.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Sar

texts.en:
Mrs. Sar H. is a 55-year-old grocer who runs her business from home. She earns about $10 per day. Her husband, Mr. Sorn Chhorn, earns $6 per day as a construction worker. They live with their 6 children in the Sophy Village, Banteay Meanchey Province.

She requests a $1,000 loan to expand her stock of groceries and to purchase a motorcycle for her husband. This will allow her to increase her business profit and make it easier for her husband to get to work. In the photo, her husband is sitting in the bed, and two women are her clients. Mrs. Sar H. was not available at the time.

loans.use: To expand her stock of groceries and to purchase a motorcycle for her husband

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok S. is 35 years old and runs a grocery store from her home in Prey Veng province. She makes 15 USD a day through this business. Her husband also helps to support Sok S. and their two children by working as a taxi driver in the capital of Phnom Penh. He makes 6 USD per day on average.

She wants to apply her loan towards building the family a more stable wooden home, from which she also hopes to expand her grocery store.

loans.use: To build a family home.

loans.name: Sagn

texts.en: Mrs. Sagn K., 44, sells porridge and Chinese noodles in the Muoy Village in Banteay Meanchey Province. She earns about $10 per day. Her husband, Mr. Chhut Saroeung, 42, works for the CMAC organization and makes $7 per day. They have three children, all of whom are students. Mrs. K. seeks a $1,100 loan to purchase a motorcycle to make it easier for her husband to commute to work. She will also use the motorcycle to transport goods for her business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to make it easier for her husband to commute to work and to transport goods for her business

loans.name: Soun

texts.en: Mr. Soun C., 44, and his wife, Mrs. Chi Rani,, both earn about $10 per day growing and selling mushrooms from their home. They live with their four children in Kos Keo Village, Banteay Meanchey Province. One of the children helps with the mushroom business, while the other three are still in school. Mr. C. seeks a $200 loan to expand his business, which will help them pay his children’s school fees.

loans.use: To expand his mushroom-growing business

loans.name: Kong

texts.en:
Kong S. is 40 years of age and makes 4 USD per day, buying pepper from provincial farms and reselling it at a low markup. Her husband (pictured here as she was unavailable to be photographed) works for the ministry of forestry in Kampong Cham province, earning only 2 US$ per day.

Two of their three children are already married and live outside the family home. She wants to use her loan to purchase pepper in bulk in order to increase her profits. She hopes to some day purchase a plot of land so that she can store the pepper for resale when market prices are too high.

loans.use: To purchase pepper in bulk for resale.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Hoang Thi

texts.en:
Mrs. Hoang Thi T. is 33 years old and has been with TYM Fund since 2003. She lives with her husband and their 3 children, 2 of whom are in school. The family's main business is to raise chickens and brood chicken eggs in an incubator. Thanks to the effort of the whole family, the average yearly profit is $6,250.

Seeing that this is a successful business, Mrs. Hoang Thi T. wants to borrow $1,200 to continue investing in it.

loans.use: Invest in raising chickens

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for TYM Fund - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Dy

texts.en:
Mr. Dy S., 61, and his wife, Ouk Chea, 60, are farmers in Thmor Village, Kampong Cham Province, where they grow mushrooms. They both earn about $10 per day and have five children, two married and three single. One is a grocer in Siem Reap, while another is a motorbike taxi driver. The other three children are students. 

Mr. S. seeks a $1,100 loan to expand his mushroom growing business. He hopes this investment will improve his family’s financial stability and pay for his children’s education. S., Chea, and their child are shown in the photo.

loans.use: To expand his mushroom growing business

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en:
Mrs. Ngugen Thi V. is 48 years old and joined the TYM Fund in 2002. She lives with her husband and 2 of their 4 children. One of her children studies in Russia, one is married and the other 2 children are still in school. The family's main business is running a milling machine, which generates a monthly income of about $250. The family also raises pigs, and sells them every three months. They sell a lot of rice, too.

Mrs. Ngugen Thi V. now wants to borrow $375 to invest in more livestock.

loans.use: Invest in livestock

loans.name: Pen

texts.en: Mrs. Pen T., 31, and her husband, Sum Phy, 28, are farmers. They live with their three children in Dai Boun Village, Kampong Cham Province. They had been farming for eighteen years and earn around $4 per day. They request a loan of $200 to purchase hard stone to create mills, which they hope to sell. This will generate additional income to help them support their family.

loans.use: To purchase hard stone to create mills

loans.name: Sem

texts.en: Mrs. Sem P. is a 45-year-old farmer. She lives in Dai Boun Village, Kampong Cham Province, earning about $5.00 per day. Her husband, Mr. Phan Chep, is also a farmer and earns about $5.00 per day. Together they have five children, one of whom is married. They request a loan of $1,200 to purchase tools and hard stone to create and sell mills. This loan will expand the capital for their business and get increase their income. P., Chep and their children appear in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase tools and hard stone to create and sell mills

loans.name: Le Thi

texts.en:
Mrs. Le Thi H. is 45 years old and joined the TYM Fund in 2003. She lives with her husband and has 2 grown up children. The family's main business is raising egg-laying ducks and fish for selling. Their average monthly income is $250.

To increase her income, Mrs. Le Thi H. now wishes to borrow $1,000 to buy eggs and food for her ducks. She hopes that with this amount she will be able to expand her business.

loans.use: Invest in animals sales

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi C. is 41 years old and joined TYM Fund in 2003. She lives with her husband and their 3 children, 2 of whom are students. Her main business is selling bran for animals (ducks, pigs, etc.). Her husband works as a builder.

Mrs. Nguyen Thi C. has applied for a loan of $625 to buy more animal feed and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy animal feed

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi N. is 47 years old. She lives with her husband and has 5 grown up children. The family's main business is selling food and making rice wine. Their average monthly income is $125. The family also sells also pigs, which earns them approximately $300 every three months.

Mrs. Nguyen Thi N. wants to borrow $625 to buy more products and invest in her business.

loans.use: To buy more products and invest in a successful business

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi N. is 44 years old and lives with her husband and one of her children. Two other children are grown up and have their own jobs. The family's main business is farming, raising ducks and fish, as well as growing bananas and mangos. The family sells fish twice a year, which is their main source of income.

This year Mrs. Nguyen Thi N. wants to borrow $575 to raise some pigs as another source of income.

loans.use: Invest in raising pigs

loans.name: I Wayan Badra

texts.id:
I Wayan Badra, 40 years old, is a farmer who works on his paddy field of 1.5 hectares (around 15,000 square meter). During then planting season, he was assisted by his wife and another 2 workers. He paid his worker IDR 25,000 per day for a week of planting season, so in total he spent IDR 175,000/ worker (around USD 19/ worker/ week).

During the maintenance season, he is only assisted by his wife. At the moment the paddy plants are 4 month old and they are ready to be harvested in a month time. The money from the harvest will be used to pay the fertilizer and seeds he bought last time. For the next planting season, he wants to plant a high quality paddy field so he can improve the quality of his paddy harvest and also to reduces the maintenance costs as high quality paddy plants requires less maintenance works and also less vulnerable to plaque compares to regular paddy seeds.

With the loan money, he will be able to wisely finance his next farming season to get a better harvest and enable him to repay on schedule.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer.

I Wayan Badra, 40 tahun, berprofesi sebagai seorang petani yang mengerjakan sawah miliknya sendiri seluas 1.5 hektar. Dengan luas lahan tersebut, I Wayan Badra mengerjakan pengolahan sawahnya dengan dibantu oleh istri dan 2 orang tenaga kerja yang dibayar Rp. 25.000.- per hari. Tenaga kerja tersebut dibutuhkan selama 1 minggu saat penanaman padi. Jadi biaya yang dikeluarkan untuk tenaga kerja selama 1 minggu adalah Rp. 175.000.- Dalam masa perawatan, I Wayan Badra hanya dibantu oleh istrinya. Saat ini umur padinya sudah 4 bulan dan sebulan lagi sudah siap dipanen. Semua hasil panen akan dipergunakan untuk membayar pupuk dan bibit yang sudah dibelinya pada masa tanam yang lalu. Saat ini I Wayan Badra merencanakan akan menanam bibit padi jenis unggul agar kwalitas beras yang dihasilkan lebih baik dan biaya perawatan bisa ditekan karena bibit padi jenis unggul lebih tahan terhadap penyakit. Dengan pinjaman yang didapatnya, I Wayan Badra akan menggunakannya dengan bijaksana agar hasil yang didapat lebih baik dan ia dapat mengembalikan pinjaman tepat waktu.

loans.use: To buy high quality of paddy seeds (Membeli bibit padi jenis unggul)

loans.name: Marcelina's Furaha Group

texts.en:
Marcelina is 33 years old and is a married woman with 2 children, ages 9 and 11 years old. Marcelina is a fish seller, and she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $275 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more fish for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in used clothes sales and soft drink sales.

loans.use: To buy more fish for her business.

loans.name: Rehema's Sisikwasisi Group

texts.en:
Rehema is 31 years old and is a widow with 1 child, age 11 years old. Rehema owns a small food vendor store, which she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 6am to 4pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $245 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Scolastica, who has a businesses dealing in soap, sugar and shoe selling.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: I Made Kara

texts.id:
I Made Kara is a paddy farmer. He works on a land of 1 hectare (around 10,000 square meter). At the moment, I Made Kara's paddy plants are 3 month old. In this period, paddy plants need a lot of maintenance and a lot of good care as they are vulnerable to a lot of plaques. Therefore fertilizer and pesticide are crucial in this period of times. However he is facing a difficulty to find affordable good quality fertilizer and pesticide.

He wants to use the loan money from Dinari to finance his purchase of fertilizer and pesticide. He is optimistic that with a good care of his paddy field he will be able to get maximum result. With this he will be able to improve his family's well beings and to repay the loan on schedule.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Saat ini, usia padi I Made Kara sudah 3 bulan. Pada periode ini, tanaman padi sangat membutuhkan perawatan dan penanganan yang baik karena sangat rentan terhadap penyakit. Dengan perawatan dan penanganan yang tepat, akan sangat menentukan hasil yang didapat saat panen. Untuk hal itu, memerlukan pupuk dan anti hama yang cukup untuk areal sawahnya yang seluas 1 hektar. Kendala yang dihadapinya sekarang adalah sulitnya mencari pupuk dan anti hama dengan harga yang terjangkau. I Made Kara merencanakan pinjaman ke Dinari untuk dapat membeli pupuk dan anti hama sehingga tanaman padinyaa tidak terlambat mendapat penanganan. I Made Kara optimis, dengan perawatan dan penanganan yang baik, ia akan mendapat hasil yang maksimal dari sawahnya. Dengan hasil yang didapat, I Made Kara bisa mencukupi kebutuhan keluarganya dan bisa mengembalikan pinjaman tepat waktu.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide (Membeli pupuk dan anti hama)

loans.name: I Kadek Putra

texts.id:
I Kadek Putra is a farmer and he works on a land of 1 hectare (around 10,000 square meter). He needs a continuous supply of water to irrigate his paddy field. In his village, farmers get together and make a group to arrange, create and manage a mutual irrigation system. In this group, each member get an equal share of water for irrigation.

Farmer who wants to join into this group has to pay some amount of dues. Therefore I Kadek Putra needs some money to enable him to join this group to secure irrigation for his paddy field. Furthermore he also needs money to buy paddy seeds and pesticide. With the loan money he hopes he can afford to have good quality paddy seeds, fertilizer and good irrigation, so he will be able to improve the quality of his harvest. This will of course translate to improvement of his family's well being.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Dalam proses pengolahan persawahan, pengairan yang baik sangat dibutuhkan karena tanaman padi sangat memerlukan air pada masa pertumbuhannya. Hal yang sama juga dialami oleh I Kadek Putra. Untuk mengerjakan sawahnya yang seluas 1 hektar, ia memerlukan pengairan yang terjaga selama masa pertumbuhan tanaman padinya. Di desa tempat I Kadek Putra tinggal, para petani padi tergabung dalam satu kelompok yang khusus menangani pengairan ke sawah – sawah sehingga para petani mendapat jatah air yang sama. Setiap petani yang ingin mendapatkan air harus masuk kedalam kelompok tersebut dan diwajibkan membayar iuran yang sudah disepakati. Selain untuk membeli pupuk, anti hama dan bibit padi, I Kadek Putra harus mengeluarkan dana untuk iuran air di kelompoknya. Dengan pinjaman yang didapatnya, ia merencanakan untuk meningkatkan kwalitas persawahannya dengan membeli bibit padi jenis unggul dan pupuk dalam jumlah yang cukup sehingga ia tidak akan kehabisan ditengah jalan. I Kadek Putra optimis, dengan kwalitas padi yang lebih baik, ia akan dapat meningkatkan hasil penjualannya untuk menambah pendapatan keluarganya.

loans.use: To buy water/ irrigation and fertilizer (Membeli air dan pupuk)

loans.name: I Putu Sugama

texts.id:
I Putu Sugama lives in Manistutu village in West Bali where almost 90% of the population works as farmers. He himself is a paddy farmer and he owns a land of 1 hectare (around 10,000 square meter). Ones of the important factors in farming are fertilizer and pesticide. Those are needed to maintain the quality of the paddy. At the moment I Putu Sugama is having limited capital to spend on fertilizer and pesticide as he already used most of his money to finance daily farming works. He wants to use the loan money to buy fertilizer and pesticide to be used at his paddy field.

I Putu is a hard worker and he believes the importance to work really hard for his paddy field in order to enable him to get maximal result so he can improve his family's well fare, to put on saving and also to repay his loan on time.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer.

I Putu Sugama tinggal di desa Manistutu, sebuah desa di Bali Barat yang mana hampir 90 % penduduknya bermata pencaharian sebagai petani. Khusus untuk lingkungan I Putu Sugama, sebagian besar petani bercocok tanam dengan menanam padi. Hal ini disebabkan karena pengairan diwilayah tersebut mencukupi untuk menanam padi. I Putu Sugama memiliki lahan seluas 1 hektar yang ia kerjakan seorang diri. Pada masa tanam saat ini, tanaman padi sangat membutuhkan pupuk dan anti hama untuk menjaga kwalitas yang didapat saat panen nanti. I Putu Sugama membutuhkan dana untuk membeli pupuk dan anti hama yang diperlukan karena semua dana yang dimilikinya sudah diinvestasikan untuk pengolahan sawahnya. Dengan pinjaman yang didapatnya, akan dipergunakan dengan sebaik – baiknya untuk pengolahan sawahnya. I Putu Sugama adalah pekerja keras, sawahnya dikerjakan dengan baik karena ia ingin mendapatkan hasil yang maksimal, sehingga dengan hasil yang maksimal ia bisa mencukupi kebutuhan keluarganya, menabung dan mengembalikan pinjaman tepat waktu.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide (membeli pupuk dan anti hama)

loans.name: Helena

texts.en:
Helena is 37 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, ages 12, 9 and 7 years old. Helena is a timber seller, and she started in 2003. Every day, she works from 6am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $225 from her sales.

In the past, Helena has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more timber for her business.

loans.use: to buy more timber for her business.

loans.name: Pech

texts.en:
Mrs. Pech T. is 45 years old and sells bags, earning about $4.83 per day. Her business depends on mobility around the markets. Mrs. T. buys bags from Oreusey Market in Phnom Penh and spends the rest of the day transporting them. T. has three children, all young students. Her husband, Mr. Bo Ben, also sells bags with her, earning around $4.83 per day. They live in Baray District, Kampong Thom Province.

Mrs.T. requests a loan of $400 to buy more bags to sell. In the future, she hopes to buy a plot of land near the main road and open a small shop to sell her bags. She hopes to achieve her goal by using this loan. T., Ben, and their child appear in the photo.

loans.use: To buy more bags to sell

loans.name: Anna's Amani Group

texts.en:
Anna is 42 years old and is a married woman with 2 children, ages 24 and 22 years old. Anna owns a small grocery, which she started in 2004. Every day, she works from 6am to 7pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $110 from her sales.

In the past, Anna has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Rose, who has a salon.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Salma's Jipe Moyo Group

texts.en:
Salma is 32 years old and is a married woman with 1 child, age 2 years old. Salma owns a small food vendor store, which she started in 2005. Every day, she works from 6am to 7pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $65 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in charcoal sales, market sales and food vending.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Van

texts.en:
Mr. Van T., 59, earns $1 per day as a government official in Balung Lech Village, Kampong Thom Province. His wife, Nhem Sinat, raises ducks from their home. Their married children don’t live with them.

Mr.T. requests a $400 loan to purchase more ducks for his wife to raise. With the extra income generated by the ducks, they hope to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase more ducks for his wife to raise

loans.name: Zainabu's Maarifa Group

texts.en:
Zainabu is 33 years old and is a divorced woman. Zainabu owns a small food vendor store, which she started in 2004. Every day, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $55 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Hadija, who has a business dealing in food vending.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is 41 years old and is married woman with 3 children, ages 25, 20 and 19 years old. Asha is a timber seller, and she started in 2004. Every day, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more timber for her business.

loans.use: To buy more timber for her business.

loans.name: Chhem

texts.en:
Mrs. Chhem C. S. is a 40-year-old policewoman who supplements her income by selling beef tripe, earning about $5 per day. Her husband, Puon Ly, earns $5 per day as a taxi driver. They live with their three children in Baray Toch Village, Kampong Thom Province.

Mrs. S. requests a $500 loan to expand her beef tripe business. With the extra income, she hopes to further her children’s studies as well as improve her family’s financial stability. In the photo, the woman with black shirt is Mrs. Chhem C. S..

loans.use: To expand her beef tripe business

loans.name: Em

texts.en:
Mrs. Em H., 34, earns about $4.33 per day selling second-hand clothes at the Baray Market. Her husband, Lim Pailen, is a journalist and earns $2.66 per day. They live with their three children in Or Suosdey Village, Kampong Thom Province.

Mrs. H. seeks an $800 loan to increase her stock of second-hand clothes, as well as to purchase pigs to raise. She hopes this loan will help further her children’s education. In the photo, the woman is Mrs. Em H..

loans.use: To increase her stock of second-hand clothes and to purchase pigs to raise

loans.name: Hilda's Ujamaa Group

texts.en:
Hilda is 40 years old and is a single woman. Hilda is a shopkeeper, and she started in 2004. Every day, she works from 6am to 7pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

In the past, Hilda has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Mwamvua, who has a business dealing in fish sales.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is 31 years old and is a married woman with 2 children, ages 15 and 13 years old. Rebecca owns a small food vendor store, which she started in 2002. Every day, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Mr. Sok M., 48, and his wife, Ong Sophat, both earn $10 per day selling chickens. They live with their four children in Steng Sen Village, Kampong Thom Province. They request an $800 loan to make their chicken-selling business more efficient. With their increased profits, they hope to help pay their children’s school fees as well as improve their financial stability.

loans.use: To make their chicken-selling business more efficient

loans.name: Sat

texts.en: Mrs. Sat C. lives in the Ampil Village of Kandal Province. She is 57 years old and is the mother of three children, one of whom is working and can generate an income of approximately $2.75 per day while the other two children are studying at a local school. She is a subsistence farmer and a seller of fish. Her husband, Mor Mean (pictured on the right of the photo), is a fisherman who usually gathers fish for his wife to sell at the market. Typically, Mrs. Sat C. can earn approximately $1.85 per day, but she would like to start an animal husbandry business in order to improve her and her family's standard of living. Therefore, she is seeking a loan to buy cows, which she will breed, feed, and tend to.

loans.use: To embark upon a new business venture (animal husbandry) by purchasing cows.

loans.name: Nget

texts.en: Mrs. Nget K. is a housewife and she lives in the Ampil Village of the Kandal province. She is 43 years old and the mother of six children, four of whom are attending school while the other two are working. Her husband, Phy Phin, is a house constructor and can generate an income of approximately $1.75 per day. Mrs. Nget relies entirely on her husband and her children to support their family. Because of their family's poor living conditions, she is seeking a loan to buy dirt to fill in the front yard of her house.

loans.use: To purchsae dirt in order to fill in her family's front yard.

loans.name: Zena's Hamasika Group

texts.en:
Zena is 48 years old and is a married woman with 5 children, ages 12 to 28 years old. She and her husband also take care of 3 other people, ages 20, 22 and 72. Zena owns a small food vendor store, which she started in 1997. Every day, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Amina S., Eliza J. and Amina S., who have businesses dealing in hair salons and food vending.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Hadija

texts.en:
Hadija is 34 years old and is a married woman with 4 children, ages 12, 8, 5 and 2 years old. Hadija is a fish and cassava seller, and she started in 2008. Every day, she works from 7am to 4pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Hadija

texts.en:
Hadija is 34 years old and is married woman with 4 children, ages 12,8,5 and 2 years old.Hadija is fish and cassava seller, she started in 2008. Everyday, she works from 7am to 4pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Hean

texts.en:
Hean T. is 28 years old and lives in Kampong Chnnang province. She runs a small business selling desserts from her home. Her daily revenue from this only totals to 1.50 USD. Her husband, Sim Rotha, works as a taxi driver at the nearby market, making about 2.50 USD per hour.

They share their family home with many family members: their young child, Hean T.’s parents, and two cousins. She hopes to use the loan to purchase a more reliable motor bike for her cousin, providing an easier means of transportation to his job, which adds to the family income. (Pictured here with the motorbike they plan to buy

loans.use: To buy a more reliable motorbike for transportation.

loans.name: Sou

texts.en:
Mrs. Sou V., 43 years old, lives with her husband and four children in the city of Phnom Penh. They have lived here since 1985. Everyday, she and her husband, Mr. San Sor, age 42, make brooms and sell them door=to-door. Sometimes, they also sell these in the market, earning around $10 per day in revenue. One of their children is employed by a garment factory; two others help their mother building brooms, and the last one is a student.

To increase business revenue, she is requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase the grass to make the brooms (In Cambodia the brooms were made by a certain type of grass). When she receives the loan from Kiva, she can then produce a higher number of brooms to sell at the market , thereby enabling them to earn more profits to support the family.

loans.use: To increase capital and make more brooms.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Chuon

texts.en:
Chuon S. is 28 years old and works as a tailor in the Kampong Cham province. In this job, she earns approximately 5 USD per day. Her husband, Naroth, helps provide for their two children by working construction, earning similar wages.

The couple hopes to invest in a motorbike so that Naroth can work as a taxi driver in addition to his current construction job. They hope that this will increase their total family income and provide a better life for their children.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to be used as a taxi.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is 30 years old and is married woman with 5 children, ages 9 to 16 years old. Asha is a food seller, and she started in 2007. Everyday, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $170 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is 25 years old and is a married woman with 1 child, age 1 years old. Rehema owns a small shop, which she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $190 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Nuon

texts.en:
Nuon H. is 31 years of age and her husband, Son Eng, is 37. They live in Thmor Kor, a more remote district of Kampong Cham province, with their young six children. She makes 2.50 USD per day growing lotus and morning glory flowers to sell at the local market. He also farms vegetables and works part-time as a fisherman, earning 2.50 USD daily.

Ms. H.'s loan will be used to purchase a plot of farmland upon which she and her husband can plant more vegetables, and thereby increase their family income.

loans.use: To purchase a plot of farmland.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Ven

texts.en:
Mrs. Ven V., age 39, is a mother of one school-age child and lives with her husband in Phnom Penh city. They have lived here for around 20 years. She runs a business renting rooms to the garment workers; she also a staff at a factory and makes about $4 a day of profit.

Her husband, Mr. Ouk Bunthoeun, 41, is a government official with a salary $150 per month. She is hopeful to borrow some money to purchase wood to install in her house. (Husband is pictured because Mrs. Ven V. is not available)

loans.use: To purchase wood to install in her house (repairing)

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Som

texts.en:
Mrs. Som N., age 53, is married and lives with her two children in Phnom Penh. She and her husband, Mr. Ban Boeun, 59, have a small business selling eggs and a variety of vegetables in a busy market. Typically, they earn a combined income of around $10 a day. One of their children is a student; while the other helps both parents in the market.

To increase their business growth, Mrs. N. would like a loan from Kiva to purchase additional eggs and vegetables to sell in large amounts since she has many customers.

loans.use: To purchase more eggs and vegetables.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Hauy

texts.en:
Hauy S. is 60 years old and lives in the Thmor Kor district of Kampong Cham province. Since 1979, she has been growing vegetables and rice to sustain her family. She also takes these vegetables to the markets to sell. She only earns 1 USD a day.

Her husband, Suon Sem, is also 60 years old and works on staff with a telephone company making 4 USD a day. Of their five children, three are married, while two are single and still live at the family home. The two children at home are garment factory workers, each earning 7 USD per day. She wants to use her loan to buy wood and repair their roof which has been leaking for some time.

loans.use: To repair the house's roof.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Christina's Jitegemee Group

texts.en:
Christina is 32 years old and is a married woman with 1 child, age 9 years old. Christina is a local liquor seller, and she started in 2000. Every day, she works from 8am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $190 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Rahma, who has a business dealing in business and trading.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Njem

texts.en:
Mrs. Njem S., age 58, is a mother of six children and works as farmer growing a variety of vegetables on a plot of farmland. On average, she earns $2 a day. Her husband is also a farmer; he grows rice year-round, making around $3 per day.

Two of the six children are employed as garment workers with a salary $70 a month. The other four children are students and sometimes help their mother planting vegetables.

To make the plants grow faster, she would like to borrow from Kiva to purchase fertilizers and a water pump to water the crops. With the remaining funds, she will purchase watermelon seeds to grow for the next season. (Husband is pictured because Mrs. Njem S. is not available)

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and water pump.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Florence Nakato’S Group

texts.en:
Florence is 46 years old and is the group leader of 5 people. This is the first loan for the entire group. They know each other very well and live in the same neighborhood, so they trust each other with this venture. Florence has 5 children, ages 17 to 23 years old. All of them are in school right now, but at times they have not been able to attend due to the cost of school fees.

Florence’s business is selling charcoal. She has been selling charcoal in her neighborhood for the past six years. One challenge Florence faces with selling charcoal is that the wholesale price changes frequently due to the weather. For example, when it rains the price goes up because the rain affects the road, which causes the transport fees to increase. This loan will help Florence because she no longer has to try to get a loan from the bank, which can be very difficult. She also hopes to be able to pay for school fees consistently and provide more food for her family. She hopes to expand her business and, one day, open another store.

loans.use: To buy charcoal

loans.name: Yim

texts.en:
Mr. Yim Y. is 62 years old and lives in the Kroal Krabei Village, Pursat Province. He farms and raises pigs, earning about $2.50 per day. His wife, Mrs. Sen In, is 55 years old. Sen sells porridge and Khmer noodles from her home and earns about $2.30 per day. Y. has seven children, two of whom are married.

Mr. Y. requests a loan of $500 to purchase small pigs to raise. Y. hopes this loan will increase his income and sustain his family’s financial stability. Sen In is pictured in the photo because Yim Y. was not available at the time.

loans.use: To purchase small pigs to raise

loans.name: Em

texts.en:
Mrs. Em T., age 29, is a mother of four children and lives with her husband in the Siem Reap province since 2000. Everyday, she breeds pigs at her house and earns $5 a day in revenue. Her husband, Mr. Seng Doung, age 40, works as a police man and makes a total of about $3 a day.

In order for her family to earn more income, Mrs. Em T. has decided to borrow from Kiva to purchase more pigs to breed. She plans to use the leftovers for renovating the house. (Picture: husband and wife)

loans.use: To purchase more pigs to breed and renovate the house.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is 20 years old and is single. Amina is a fish seller, and she started in 2008. Every day, she works from 7am to 4pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more fish for her business.

loans.use: To buy more fish for her business.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is 45 years old and is a married woman. Rehema is a food and chicken seller, and he started in 2007. Every day, she works from 7am to 4pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Chhem

texts.en: Mrs. Chhem S. is 32 years old and has been selling groceries for eleven years in the market of Kbal Hong Village, Pursat Province. She earns about $2.66 per day. Her husband, Mr. Chim Chantha, is a 36-year-old farmer and motorcycle taxi driver, earning up to $3.66 per day. They have two children, both of whom are young students. S. requests a loan of $1,100 to expand her grocery inventory and increase her income. She hopes this loan will strengthen her busines

loans.use: To expand her grocery inventory

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi L. is 43 years old and joined TYM fund in 2003. She lives with her husband and one of her 3 children in Yen Lac district, Vinh Phuc province. The other 2 children are grown up. The family's main business is raising cows, pigs, dogs, fish, and ducks. They also grow bananas and mangos. Once a year the family sells fish, earning a profit of about $560.

Mrs. Nguyen Thi L. used her last loan to buy 100 ducks. Now she wants to borrow $575 to buy pigs.

loans.use: To invest in pigs

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for TYM Fund - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Sylivia Nakawooya's Group

texts.en:
N. Sylivia, age 22, is the leader of this group.  Sylivia is married with 1 child that is 2 years old.  Sylivia works in Owino Market, where she sells fruit such as passion fruit and oranges. 

Sylivia’s main challenges while carrying out her business include seasonal changes in fruit supply, seasonal needs for more capital and times when farm yields are poor.  

The loan will enable Sylivia to increase her food stock and retain some of her profits.  In the future, she hopes to make enough money to renovate her house, purchase a plot of land, and improve the family's diet.

loans.use: The loan will enable Sylivia to increase her food stock and save some money.

loans.name: Doeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Doeun T., age 35, is a mother of four children, and stays at home to look after the children. She cooks food for her entire family. Meanwhile, her husband, Mr. Dosh Chea, 52, works in construction, building houses and earning $5 a day of profit.

Mr. Dosh Chea requests a loan from Kiva to purchase wood to install in the house.

loans.use: To purchase wood to fix the leaking roof.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Ly

texts.en: Mrs. Ly P. is a 53-year-old woman living in Ampil, where most villagers live in extremely poor conditions. She dedicates herself as a subsistence farmer to support her family. She is the mother of one child, who has a job and can earn approximately $2 per day. Her husband, Tork Pach, is also a farmer, and they cultivate vegetables on a field next to the village. Simply put, Mrs. Ly P. and her husband grow different kinds of vegetables and they sell the vegetables to a middle-man to generate income for their family. Insufficient vegetable seeds and a lack of money presented the two with a problem, so Mrs. Ly P. is hereby requesting a loan to buy more vegetable seeds to cultivate on the field.

loans.use: To purchase additional vegetable seeds.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi T. is 47 years old and has been with TYM Fund since 2003. She lives with her husband and their 3 children. The family's main business is making natural medicine with plants. The family also raises pigs and plants corn. Making medicine provides them with a main monthly income of about $500. In their free time, her children help with her work.

Mrs.T. has applied for a new loan of $825 to buy pigs, fish and plants (for making medicine).

loans.use: Invest in fish, pigs and medicinal plants

loans.name: Fanyete

texts.en:
Fanyete is 36 years old and is a single woman with 3 children, ages 12, 6 and 5 years old. Fanyete is a clothing seller, and she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 8am to 4pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $190 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothing for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothing for her business.

loans.name: Sles

texts.en: Mrs. Sles L. and her husband, Hou Sun, earn $10 per day sewing fishing nets in the Eslam Village, Pursat Province. They have four children, all of whom are married. They seek a $300 loan to purchase more supplies for their net-sewing business. They feel this loan will help support their business and improve their living conditions. L., Sun, and their children are in the photo

loans.use: To purchase more supplies for their net-sewing business

loans.name: Naida's Maendeleo Group

texts.en:
Naida is 35 years old and is a married woman with 1 child, age 14 years old. She and her husband also take care of 3 other children, ages 9, 13 and another 13 years old. Naida owns a small grocery, which she started in 1998. Every day, she works from 6am to 9pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $425 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Salma, who has a business dealing in shoe sales.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Sokban

texts.en: Mrs. Sokban S. is 28 years old and lives in the Thom Village of Kandal Province. She is the mother of one child, who is enrolled at a local school. Her husband, Im Lon (pictured on the right in the photo), is a lumberjack in the local area. She typically helps her husband gather money generated from lumber sales. However, aside from lumber-related work, she and her husband are farmers, and they work on a cultivatable field to grow vegetables. She would like to access a loan to buy a motorbike so that she and her husband can travel around town more easily, and any remaining proceeds would be used to purchase a lumber machine.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike and a lumber machine.

loans.name: So

texts.en: Ms. So N., 27, sells vegetables at the Pursat Market, where she earns $2.40 per day. She is unmarried and lives with her family in the Stha Ny Village in Pursat Province. N. seeks a $350 loan to expand her inventory of vegetables. With this loan, she hopes to increase sales and improve her family’s financial stability.

loans.use: To expand her inventory of vegetables

loans.name: Shuweya

texts.en:
Shuweya is 26 years old and is a married woman. Shuweya is a tailor, and she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

In the past, Shuweya has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to buy a sewing machine for her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Bui Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Bui Thi H. is 34 years old and has 2 children. Her main business is raising fish, ducks and pigs. Every day she collects duck eggs to sell at the village market. She also teaches morning kindergarten at a nearby school. All of these jobs keep her busy, but she is satisfied with her life. This month she hopes to borrow $825 to expand her livestock raising business.

loans.use: Invest in ducks

loans.name: Margaret Kyamulabi’S Group

texts.en:
Margret K., age 25, is the leader of this group.  Margret is married with 5 children ranging from 1½- to 10 years old. Margret’s children are not in school because she is not able to pay school fees.  

Margret is a charcoal seller in Nakulabye, a suburb outside of Kampala City.  The loan will enable Margret to expand on her stock, provide food for family, and pay school fees for her children.  Margret’s major challenge is paying the store rent where she sells charcoal.

loans.use: The loan will enable Margret to expand her stock.

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is 46 years old and is a married woman with 1 child, age 26 years old. Amina is a fish seller, and she started in 1984. Every day, she works from 5am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $30 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more fish for her business.

loans.use: To buy more fish for her business.

loans.name: Mary Serunjoji’S Group

texts.en:
Mary, age 35, is the leader of this five-person group, 3 of which are receiving loans at this time.  The group has been a successful client of MCDT for several years.  Mary is married with one child.  Her husband is a taxi driver.

Mary makes custom dresses out of fabric she buys at the market.  She has a store in Makere, a suburb of Kampala.  She will use the money to buy more fabric, and use the store profit to provide for her family.  Since receiving loans from MCDT, Mary has been able to improve her business and use the money she earned to buy a piece of land and pay for her children’s school fees.  She hopes to eventually earn enough money to build a house on the property she purchased.

loans.use: She will use the money to buy more fabric and use the store profit to provide for her family.

loans.name: Kim Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Kim Thi H. is 26 years old. She is married and has 2 children. Her husband works in the commune and the family’s main income comes from selling farming products. Mrs. Kim Thi H. also makes rice cakes to sell in the morning. Her business is successful and she wants to borrow $875 to invest in it. She says that if she can earn more money, she will apply it towards furthering her children's education.

loans.use: To purchase more ingredients

loans.name: Hadija

texts.en:
Hadija is 21 years old and is a single woman with 1 child, age 1 year old. Hadija owns a small food vendor store, which she started in 2006. Every day, she works from 10am to 3pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $190 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.en:
Mrs. Tran Thi L. is 45 years old and lives in Hanh Lam commune, Hung Yen province. She and her husband have 2 daughters; the elder is at university and the younger is in high school.

Every day she and her husband produce tofu and rice wine. It is actually a hard job as they have to wake up at 1 am and only go to bed late at night. However, they are very happy because their business is profitable and their children study well. "We don’t mind working hard. We just want to earn enough money to send our children to good universities." With this motto, Mrs. Tran Thi L. wants to borrow $625 USD to expand their business.

loans.use: Invest in rice to increase production of rice wine

loans.name: Tusiga

texts.en: Tusiga L., 45, is married to a taxi driver. The couple has five children. Tusiga would like to receive a loan to be able to purchase paint, a battery, and 3 tires for her husband’s taxi. He has been a taxi driver for over two years now and works six days a week. Tusiga and her husband expect that the loan would generate 200 Tala (~US$80) per week in net cash flow.

loans.use: Purchase paint, a battery, and three tires

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima is 50 years old and is a divorced woman with 4 children, ages 23, 21, 10 and 9 years old. She also takes care of 2 other children, ages 10 and 9 years old. Halima is a clothing seller, and she started in 2004. Every day she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more cloth for her business.

loans.use: To buy more cloth for her business.

loans.name: Moshi

texts.en:
Moshi is 42 years old and is a married woman with 4 children, ages 20, 17, 14 and 10 years old. She and her husband also take care of 2 other children, ages 6 and 11 years old. Moshi is a food seller, and she started in 2005. Every day she works from 5am to 4pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $190 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Doan Thi

texts.en:
