Mrs. Doan Thi D. is 49 years old. She is married and has 5 children. Her main business is making fishing nets. She weaves the nets and her husband sells them to other people. Her husband catches fish, too, which provides their primary daily income.

Mrs. Doan Thi D. generally makes a profit of $2.50 per day and she is happy about the prospect of getting a loan to invest in her business. She has requested a loan of $625 to purchase more net making supplies.

loans.use: To purchase more net making supplies

loans.name: Rem

texts.en: Mrs. Rem S. lives in Thom village, an area in which most people are engaged in farming. She is 35 years old and is a subsistence farmer. As for her family life, she lives with her husband, Chanthorn En; further, she is the mother of two children, one of whom is working, while the other is studying at a local school. Her husband is a motorbike taxi-driver yet he earns very little income. To improve her and her family's living conditions, Mrs. Rem S. would like to expand her crop yield, so she is hereby requesting a loan to buy more vegetable seeds to cultivate on her field.

loans.use: To purchase additional vegetable seeds.

loans.name: Charity

texts.en: Charity O. is a married mother of five. She is 43years of age. Charity sells foodstuffs and drinks in her local community. She has been in this business since the year 2000. She hails from Lambe community Ogun State, Nigeria. She is a LAPO client and has been a member for the past 4years. She needs the loan of $1200 to enable her to buy more gallons of red oil, vegetable oil and 6 crates of drinks. With this she hopes to serve her customers better. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy gallons of red oil, groundnut oil and drinks.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en: Veronica A. is married with 3 children. She is 39 years of age and hails from Lambe community in Ogun State, Nigeria. She sells drinks and pepper soup. She has being in the business since 1994 and needs a loan in the sum of $1200 to enable her to buy more drinks for sale.

loans.use: To buy more drinks and pepper soup items for sale

loans.name: Nkeruka

texts.en: Nkeruka U. is a married woman with 3 children. She is 38 years of age and comes from Lagos State,Nigeria. She sells frozen food, food stuffs and provisions. She has been with LAPO Microfinance for the past 2 years and need the sum of $1200 to enable her to buy a refrigerator and more frozen food. This will help her improve her business. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more frozen food and a deep freezer

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Taga 3 Centre – Group 3

texts.en:
The seven women from Taga, Savaii, who constitute the loan group, are borrowing from SPBD for the first time. They all have undergone four weeks of training in business management and savings account maintenance, and have passed a written test on the SPBD principles: business, savings, weekly meetings, payments, and group guarantee. Over the next 52 weeks, they will support each other in their individual business development and will guarantee that each one of them does payments on time.

Lineta E. (39, married, 5 children) will purchase: a sewing machine, materials, 2 scissors, 4 spools of thread, 5 needles, petrol, and other materials to make clothes.

Niaumasi L. (68, married, 7 children) will purchase: a weed-killing sprayer, pesticides, seeds, and a wheel barrow for her cabbage, tomato, taro and other produce plantation.

Finauvale L. (51, married, 9 children) will purchase: a weed-killing sprayer, pesticides, taro roots, and will hire laborers for her bananas, yams, taro and other produce plantation.

Ane S. (44, divorced, 5 children) will purchase: a weed-killing sprayer, pesticides, fertilizer, and will hire workers for her taro plantation.

Vasati F. (77, married, 6 children) will purchase: a weed-killing sprayer, pesticides, seeds, 2 knives, and a filing. She will also will hire workers and buy food for her cabbage, tomato, beans and other produce plantation.

Maria Imeleta N. (27, single) will purchase: flour, sugar, rice, salt, and a packet of chicken and mutton flaps (lamb ribs) for her retail shop.

Tumama T. (48, married, 4 children) will purchase: timber, sand, sugar, noodles, chemicals, and other food for her canteen and plantation businesses.

loans.use: Purchase a weed-killing sprayer, pesticides, farming tools, etc.

loans.name: Abdou

texts.fr:
Mr. B. is an embroidery tailor in Thiès, he is married and the father of two children who he is responsible for; he has rich experience in this business and works with three male apprentices and a young woman. He specializes in all sewing styles and would like to have a loan to pay for another sewing machine and to purchase some materials to meet his orders.

Translated from French by Liana Bianchi, Kiva Volunteer.

Mr B. est un tailleur broderie à Thiès, il est marié et père de deux enfants à charge; il a une riche experience dans cette activité et travaille avec trois apprentis garçons et une jeune fille. Il est spécialisé dans la couture tous genre et voudrait disposer d' un pret pour se payer une autre machine et acheter quelques matières pour satisfaire les commandes.

loans.use: Purchase of a new sewing machine to complete orders

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for UIMCEC, a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Tubia

texts.en:
Tubia is 32 years old and is married woman. She takes care of 1 person, age 60 years old. Tubia owns a small shop, which she started in 2003. Every day, she works from 9am to 9pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $475 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business

loans.name: Amina's Muamko Group

texts.en:
Amina is 40 years old and is married with 4 children, ages 17,15,12 and 7 years old. She and her husband also take care of 1 other child, age 22 years old. Amina owns a small food store and shop, which she started in 2006. Every day, she works from 7am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $225 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Husna and Ziada, who have businesses dealing in cloth sales.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en: Dorcas K. is a married woman with 2 children.  She is  36 years of age and hails from Lagos State,Nigeria. She sells frozen food such as chicken, turkey, and fish and also sells foodstuffs. She has been in her business since 2001 and needs the sum of $1200 to enable her buy more frozen food and foodstuffs for her business expansion and to maximize profit.

loans.use: To buy more frozen food and foodstuffs for sale.

loans.name: Daouda

texts.fr:
Mr. Daouda Sen is a young man who left his native village two years ago to make his life in the big city of Thiès. To do this, he started a business of grocery trading with rental of a site for which he pays 15,000 francs CFA per month. This business has been going very well for him and he would like support to strengthen his merchandise stock.

Translated from French by Liana Bianchi, Kiva Volunteer.

Mr Daouda Sen est un jeune garçon qui a quitté son village natal depuis deux années pour gagner sa vie dans la grande ville de Thiès. Pour cela, il a embrassé le métier de commerce d’alimentation avec la location d’un local qu’il paye 15 000 FCFA par mois. Cette activité lui va très bien et il voudrait un appui pour renforcer ses stocks de marchandises.

loans.use: Strengthening his merchandise stock

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for UIMCEC, a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: Joy E. is a strong and energetic woman, she hail from ilogbo, Lagos State, Nigeria. At 30 years of age, with her 3 children, she is focused and determined to enlarge her business. She sells provisions, foodstuffs and drinks. Joy has been in this business since 2003 and needs a loan of $450 to enable her to buy more provisions and drinks and foodstuff for sale. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more provisions and foodstuffs for sale.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Anthonia's Muamko Group

texts.en:
Anthonia is 38 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, ages 12,10 and 7 years old. Anthonia is a jewelry seller, and she started in 2005. Every day, she works from 6am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $190 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to start poultry business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Maimuna and Zaina, who have businesses dealing in snacks, soft drink sales, tailoring and food vending.

loans.use: To start poultry business.

loans.name: Aliou

texts.fr:
Mr. Seye is a professional cobbler, a craft which he learned from his parents for over 20 years and with which he feeds his family. He specializes in making shoes, purses, and other items made from leather. This is a business which requires substantial working capital and for this reason he is seeking financial support.

Translated from French by Liana Bianchi, Kiva Volunteer.

Mr Seye est cordonnier de profession, métier qu’il hérité de ses parents depuis plus d’une vingtaine d’années et avec lequel il nourrit sa famille. Il s’est spécialisé dans la fabrication de chaussures, de sacs et d’autres articles à base se cuir. C’est une activité qui nécessite un fonds de roulement importat c’est à cet effet qu’il demande un appui financier

loans.use: Strengthening working capital

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for UIMCEC, a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Tupone

texts.en:
Tupone is 40 years old and is a married woman with 5 children, ages 3-18 years old. Tupone owns a small charcoal store, which she started in 2005. Everyday, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $190 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Rachel

texts.en: Rachel O. is married with three children.  She is 35 years of age and hails from ilogbo, Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells notebooks and textbooks in  the ilogbo community. She buys directly from the company and sells to schools in her community. She has been in this business since 2001and needs a loan of $450 to enable her to buy more textbooks and notebooks. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more textbook and notebooks for sale.

texts.en:
Philipine is 38 years old and is a married woman with 2 children, ages 12 and 10 years old. Philipine is a fish seller, and she started in 2005. Everyday, she works from 5am to 1pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $190 from her sales.

In the past, Philipine has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more fish for her business.

loans.use: to buy more fish for her business

loans.name: Salama

texts.en:
Salama is 20 years old and is a single woman. Salama is a cloth seller; she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 8am to 7pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $275 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en: Sylvia O. is married and has a child. She is 29 years old and hails from Okiagbo, Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells phone accessories, recharge cards, makes phone calls and rents CD cassettes. She has been with LAPO Microfinance as a client for the past 4years and in this  business for the past 7 years. She needs a loan of $450 to enable her buy recharge cards and phone accessories for sale.

loans.use: To buy recharge cards and phone accessories for sale.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Mwanahawa

texts.en:
Mwanahawa is 36 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, ages 10, 7 and 4 years old. Mwanahawa is a alcohol retailer; she started in 2007. Every day she works from 6am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

In the past, Mwanahawa has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en: Eunice A.'s fashion home has a special outlook as clothes are well arranged in different colors. Eunice is married with four children.  As a fashion designer she sews in different kinds of styles. She equally sews male and female clothes. This is a business she learned for 3 years. At 39 years of age Eunice is determined to improve her business . She has been in her business since 1998. She needs a loan 0f $450 to enable her to buy more cloth and tailoring materials for sale. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and tailoring materials.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Romoke

texts.en: Romoke Y. is married with 2 children.  She is 30 years of age and hails from ilogbo in Lagos State,Nigeria. She sells foodstuffs and provisions. She acquired the skill for one and a half years and has been in the business for the past 5 years. Romoke needs a loan of $450 to enable her buy more foodstuffs and provisions for sale. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs and provisions for sale.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima is 30 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, ages 10, 8 and 3 years old. Halima is a clothes seller which she started in 2000. Everyday, she works from 7am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is 38 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, ages 16,13 and 4 years old. She and her husband also take care of 3 other children, ages 22, 8 and 10 years old. Maria owns a small auto spare parts shop, which she started in 2004. Everyday, she works from 7am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $300 from her sales.

In the past, Maria has taken out 2 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is 41 years old and is a married woman with 4 children, ages 18,15,10 and 7 years old. Amina owns a small shop, which she started in 2006. Everyday, she works from 7am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $225 from her sales.

In the past, Amina has taken out 2 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther O. is married with 2 children. She is 32 years of age and hails from Okoko, Lagos State, Nigeria. She rents video Cd’s and sells drinks. O. acquired the skill for 2 years and she has being in this business since 2003. She needs a loan of $875 to enable her buy more drinks and video Cd’s. This  will help her serve her customers better.

loans.use: To buy more CD cassettes and drinks for sale

loans.name: Radhia's Mshikamano Group

texts.en:
Radhia is 27 years old and is a married woman with 1 child, age 4 years old. Radhia is a soft drink seller and she started in 2006. Everyday, she works from 9am to 7pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $190 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Mwanaheri, who has business dealings in used clothes sales.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Adjo

texts.fr:
Born May 12th, 1975 in Lomé, Mrs. Adjo D. is married and the mother of four children. Since 1990, she has been running a small grocery store in the Békpota neighborhood. She often receives help from her husband Mr. SAVADOGO who is a retailer. She has already received two consecutive loans of 300,000 francs CFA. She is now seeking a loan of 450,000 francs CFA. Half of the loan will allow her to purchase 12 boxes of milk, 24 boxes of canned foods, and 12 boxes of soap. The other half will help her to begin selling cosmetic products. In this way she will be able to diversify her business to improve revenues and better contribute to family expenses.

Translated from French by Liana Bianchi, Kiva Volunteer.

Née le 12 mai 1975 à Lomé, Madame D. Adjo est mariée et a quatre (4) enfants qui fréquentent tous. Depuis 1990, elle a ouvert une boutique des produits de premières nécessité dans le quartier Bè kpota. Elle est souvent assistée par son mari SAVADOGO qui est un revendeur. Elle a obtenu deux (2) fois successives les crédits de 300.000FCFA. Elle sollicite un crédit de 450.000 FCFA. La moitié de ce crédit lui permettra d’acheter douze (12) cartons de lait, vingt quatre (24) de boîtes de conserve et douze (12) cartons de savons. La moitié lui servira de débuter le commerce des produits cosmétiques. Ainsi elle pourra varier son activité pour améliorer ses recettes envue de participer aux besoins de sa famille.

loans.use: Increase stock in basic goods

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine is 36 years old and is married woman with 2 children, ages 12 and 8 years old. Catherine is a clothes and shoes seller and she started her business in 2004. Everyday, she works from 7am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $225 from her sales.

In the past, Catherine has taken out 2 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: to buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Kikelomon

texts.en: Kikelomon A. is married with 4 children and hails from Okoko, Lagos State, Nigeria. Kikelomon sells fruit such as apples, a skill that she acquired for 5 years. She has been a client of LAPO Microfinance and she has been in her business for the past 3 years.She needs the sum of $450 to enable her buy more fruit  in order for her to maximize profit.

loans.use: To buy more apples

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Kokou Djigbodi

texts.fr:
Mr. Kokou Djigbodi L. was born March 23rd, 1983 in the town of Ahepe located 35 km away from Lomé. Since the year 2004, he has been doing business selling electrical equipment in the Nyékonakpoè neighborhood of Lomé. He wishes to increase his stock of electrical equipment and to this end is seeking a loan of 250,000 francs CFA to buy two boxes of button switches, one box of sockets, ten rolls of wire cable, and 12 boxes of neon bulbs. His new stock will allow him to improve his sales.

Translated from French by Liana Bianchi, Kiva Volunteer.

Monsieur L. Kokou Djigbodi est né le 23 mars 1983 à AHEPE localité située à 35 km de la ville de Lomé. Depuis l’année 2004, il exerce l’activité de vente de matériels électriques dans le quartier de Nyékonakpoè à Lomé. Il désire augmenter son stock de matériels électriques et sollicite à cet effet un crédit d’un montant de 250.000 FCFA pour acheter deux (2) cartons interrupteurs, un (1) carton de prises, dix (10) rouleaux de fils conducteurs et douze (12) cartons d’ampoule néon. Ainsi son nouveau stock va lui permettre d’améliorer son chiffre d’affaires.

loans.use: Expand merchandise stock

loans.name: Ramota

texts.en: Ramota B. comes from the Okoko community in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 32 years old and has 3 children. She is a fashion designer. She acquired the skill for 5 years and she has been in this business for the past 11 years. Ramota need the sum of $450 to enable her to buy one weaving machine in order for her to satisfy the needs of her customers. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy a weaving machine

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Salama

texts.en:
Salama is 29 years old and is married woman with 2 children, ages 15 and 7 years old. Salama conduct taxi business, which she started in 2007. Everyday, she works from 5am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $300 from her sales.

In the past, Salama has taken out 1successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan can expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Nasma

texts.en:
Nasma is 25 years old and is a single woman. Nasma owns a small food vendor store and is a cloth seller (Khanga), which she started in 2006. Everyday, she works from 7am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $190 from her sales.

In the past, Nasma has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Awa

texts.fr:
Awa Kébé is married and is responsible for seven children. She has been a member of the village bank of Diaobé for five and a half years. She sells peanut butter, which she makes from the seeds that she buys at the Diaobé marketplace. Her business enables her to have an income and to support her husband in schooling the children. She is requesting a loan that will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

Awa Kébé, mariée, 07 enfants en charge, est membre du banc villageois de Diaobé depuis cinq ans et demi. Elle vend de la pâte d’arachide qu’elle produit avec la transformation des grains qu’elle achète au marché de Diaobé. Son activité lui permet d’avoir des revenus et de soutenir son mari pour la scolarité des enfants. Elle sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de 6 mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use: To buy peanuts

loans.name: Olasukunmin

texts.en: Olasukunmin O. is a mother of 7, 45 years of age and hails from Okoko, Lagos State,Nigeria. She sells foodstuffs and has been in this business since 1994. She needs the sum of $450 to enable her to buy more foodstuffs to increase her stock and to maximize profit.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for sale.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Mwanaidi's Tuaminiane Group

texts.en:
Mwanaidi is 31 years old and is a single woman. Mwanaidi is a cosmetics seller and she started her business in 2007. Everyday, she works from 7am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $170 from her sales.

In the past, Mwanaidi has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Bichai and Salama, who have businesses dealings in a cafe, soft drink sales, and snack sales.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is 28 years old and is a married woman with 2 children, ages 12 and 8 years old. Rose owns a small beauty salon, which she started in 2000. Everyday, she works from 7am to 9pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $225 from her sales.

In the past, Rose has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her  business.

loans.name: Mariama

texts.fr:
Mariama F. is married and has, for three years, been a member of the village bank of Diaobé in Kolda. Her business involves buying sacks of onions and baskets of smoked fish and selling them in the Diaobé marketplace. She would like to build up her business that she is mastering, having practiced it for years. The loan she is requesting will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

Mariama F., marié est membre du banc villageois de Diaobé à Kolda depuis 3 ans. Son activité consiste à acheter des sacs d’oignons et des paniers de poissons fumés et revendre sur le marché de Diaobé. Elle souhaite renforcer son activité qu’elle maîtrise bien du fait de l’avoir pratiquée depuis des années. Le prêt qu’elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de 6 mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use: Commerce in smoked fish and onions

loans.name: Maria's Tujitume Group

texts.en:
Maria is 31 years old and is a married woman with 4 children, ages 12, 8, 6 and 3 years old. Maria sells clothes and bed sheets. She started her business in 2006. Everyday she works from 7am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

In the past, Maria has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Sophia, who has a business dealing in used clothes sales.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Baleba

texts.fr:
Baleba G. is married and has been a member of the village bank of Diaobé. She has always honored her commitments for five and a half years. She buys peanuts and uses them for making peanut butter, which she sells in the Diaobé marketplace. Her income enables her to improve her family's living conditions. She wishes to improve and strengthen her business. The loan she is requesting will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

Baleba G., mariée, est une membre du banc villageois de Diaobé qui a toujours respecté ses engagements depuis cinq ans et demi. Elle achète des graines d’arachide et les transforment en pâte d’arachide qu’elle vend au marché de Diaobé. Ses revenus lui permettent d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille. Elle souhaite améliorer et renforcer son activité. Le prêt qu’elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de 6 mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use: To buy peanuts

loans.name: Toyin

texts.en: Toyin A. is married with 3 children.  She is 48years of age and hails from Ijaniki, Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells cooked food and drinks, a trade that she acquired for 2 years. She has been in this business since 1988 and has been with LAPO Microfinance for 4 years. She needs the sum of $1200 to enable her to buy more food items and drinks for sale. With this she will be able to make more profit.

loans.use: To buy more drinks and food items

loans.name: Toyin

texts.en: Toyin A. is married with 3 children, 48years of age and hails from ijaniki, Lagos State Nigeria. She sells cooked food and drinks, trade that she acquired for 2 years. She has been in this business since 1988 and has been with LAPO Microfinance for 4 years. She needs the sum of $1200 to enable her buy more food items and drinks for sale. With this she will be able to make more profit.

loans.use: To buy more drinks and food items

loans.name: Oluwakemi

texts.en: Oluwakemi A. is a typical businesswoman. With her combination of businesses, she has being able to win customers. She sells kerosene, snacks and cooked food. At 46 years of age with one child, she is dedicated to her business. She acquired the skill for 2 years and has been in this business for the past 5 years. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. Oluwakemi needs the sum of $875 to enable her buy more kerosene for sale. This she says will enable her to improve her business. She says thank you to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more kerosene, snacks and food Items

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Omowumi

texts.en: "LAPO has helped me a great deal because through them I have been able to buy more provisions for my shop", says Mrs. Omowumi P. who lives in ijaniki ,Lagos State, Nigeria. Omowumi is 43 years of age and  has 4 children. She is eager to lift her family above the poverty level  contribute greatly to the upkeep of her family. She needs the loan of $875 to enable her buy more provisions for sale.

loans.use: To buy more provisions and cosmetics for sale

loans.name: Nosirat

texts.en: Nosirat A. Lives in Ijaniki,Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 35 years of age and  has four children. The youngest child she must bring to her shop everyday. she work 7 days in a week and from 7am until evvening. She sells drinks and provisions. Nosirat has being borrowing from LAPO Microfinance and repaying loans for the past 3 years and she has been in this business since 1996. She needs the sum of $450 to enable her buy more provisions and drinks for sale. This will help her serve her customers better. She say thanks to Kiva and their lenders.

loans.use: To buy more provisions and drinks for sale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Onyinye

texts.en: Mrs. Onyinye N. is a business oriented woman, having the strong desire to diversify her business. She is 36years of age and hails from ijaniki,Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells drinks and sachet pure water. "I would like to sell underwear in another shop with this Kiva loan", says Onyinye. She believes with strong conviction that she can grow her business which will enable her to increase her profit margin. Onyinye acquired the skill for 1 year and she has been in  business since 2001. She needs a loan of $875. With the loan she can buy more drinks and sachet water for sale and also diversify and sell underwear. She says thanks to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more drinks and Sachet water and sell underwear.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca A. is married. She is an older woman  but still energetic in business dealings.  She has 5 children; 4 are married, and the last one is still in school. He is not married. At the age of 52 years Rebecca still travelsaway from Lagos State to Ogun State and its environs, a distance of 3hours drive by car twice every week to buy yams, garri, a popular West African food made of cassava tubers, and plantains. She also sells  kerosene in her community. Rebecca acquired the skill for 2 years and need the sum of $875 to her buy more foodstuffs and kerosene in order to increase her profit margin.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs and kerosene

loans.name: Aboki

texts.en: Mr. Aboki A. is married. He is 36y ears of age and hails from ijaniki, Lagos State, Nigeria. He sells phone accessories, recharge cards and makes phone calls. He acquired the skill for 1year and has been in this business since 2001. Aboki has being borrowing from LAPO Microfinance and repaying loans for the past 4years and needs the sum of $875 to enable him buy more phone accessories and recharge cards for sale.

loans.use: To buy more phone accessories and recharge cards for sale.

loans.name: Faith

texts.en: Mrs. Faith E. lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells and supplies eggs to her neighboring market and other retailers in her community. She has been in this business since 2005 and she needs the sum of $875 to enable her to buy more eggs so that she can satisfy her customers' needs. This Faith says will help her increase her income.

loans.use: To buy more eggs for sale.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Ajibola

texts.en: Ajibola R. hails from Okoko Lagos State Nigeria; she sells frozen food, drinks and popcorn. She is 32 years old, with one child and has enough time and energy to handle this business properly. She requests the sum of $700 to enable her to buy more frozen food and drinks for sale. She has been operating this business since 1997.

loans.use: To buy more frozen food and drinks for sale.

loans.name: Bola

texts.en: Bola I. is 40 years of age, married with 4 children, and hails from Okoko Lagos State Nigeria. Bola has been selling kerosene for 1 year. She has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 3 years and has been in her business for the past 7 years. Bola is requesting a loan of $1200 to enable her buy more kerosene for sale. This will enable her to earn more income.

loans.use: To buy more kerosene for sale.

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua F. is a fishmonger. She buys fish, smokes them, and then sells them. She is a single parent with five children. She is supporting her family with her small income. She wants to increase sales so she can increase her income.

Ekua F. is asking for a loan of $325 to buy more fish for processing and selling.

loans.use: To buy more fish for processing and selling

payments.comment: Correction due to overpayment for business 43409

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
A. Theresa is a hairdresser, and she also sells plastic bowls. She is a single parent of 2 children. Her income is not enough to meet the needs of her family. She wants to increase her income.

She is asking for a loan for $425 to buy more creams and other supplies to improve her services to her customers.

loans.use: To buy more creams and other supplies to improve her services to her customers

payments.comment: Correction due to overpayment for business 43410

loans.name: Club De Madres Enmanuel Group

texts.en:
Wilma is a 31 year-old woman from the community of Imbert, on the north coast of the Dominican Republic, where she lives as a single parent with her 12 year-old daughter, a student at a nearby local school . Wilma is currently attending University and hopes to one day be a professional and move to the United States. She received her first loan from Esperanza six months ago, and is now taking out a second. She sells used clothing that she imports from the US, and her business has grown significantly since she first started working with Esperanza. We asked her to tell us a few facts about herself, and she told us that her favorite foods are salami and bananas and that she loves using the Internet in her free time.

Five women in this community have already taken out one loan with Esperanza and five women are new clients. They are all looking forward to this opportunity, and are committed to their families, businesses, and each other! Oh behalf of Esperanza, and all of the women in this group, thank you for your generosity and support. God Bless!

loans.use: To increase imports of used clothing from the U.S.

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
Juana is a tailor. She tailors aprons for indigenous women. She has a sewing machine that runs by pedal, which isn’t industrial enough to meet the demand she has from clients. Juana and her 5-year-old son live at her sister’s house. The house is located in the Ballivian area of the city of El Alto.

The loan she is asking for is to buy an industrial sewing machine that will help her increase the production of aprons.

This is her first loan with Impro, made possible by an evaluation process. Her experience and desire to excel have inspired our institution to help Juana with her business.

Translated by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer.

Juana es costurera, confecciona mandiles (en ingles significa aprons) para cholitas (cholitas son las mujeres campesinas); ella tiene una máquina a pedal, misma que no le abastece para confeccionar la cantidad de demanda que tiene en su mercado. Juana vive en la casa de su hermana y tiene un hijo de 5 años de edad. Su domicilio esta ubicado en la Zona Ballivian de la Ciudad de El Alto.

El crédito que solicita será utilizado para comprar una maquina semi industrial de costura, que le ayudará a incrementar su producción de mandiles.

Este es su primer crédito con Impro. La evaluación realizada permite otorgarle el préstamo. Asimismo, su experiencia y su afán de superación motivan a nuestra institución para ayudar a Juana en su negocio.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine to increase the production of aprons.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama B. is a fishmonger. She is married and has 2 children. She travels to a town far away to buy iced fish for processing and selling. She doesn't have enough capital to buy more fish to meet the increasing demand of her customers.

Ama B. is requesting a loan for $525 to buy more fish for processing and selling.

loans.use: To buy more fish for processing and selling

payments.comment: Correction due to underpayment for business 43413

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Esi D. is a fishmonger and also prepares and sells other food items. She is married and has 3 children. She buys fish, processes them, and sells them to her customers. Her business is doing well and she wants to increase her sales by purchasing more fish.

Esi Duman is asking for a loan of $425 to buy more fish for processing and selling.

loans.use: To buy more fish for processing and selling

payments.comment: Correction due to overpayment for business 43414

loans.name: Justice

texts.en:
Justice A. sells plastic housewares. He is married and has 3 children. His business is doing very well and he want to purchase more items to increase sales.

He is requesting for a loan of $525 to buy more plastic goods to sell.

loans.use: To buy more plastics for sale.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 22, 2008)
Correction due to underpayment for business 43415

loans.name: Rosa Olimpia

texts.es:
Mrs. Rosa Olimpia B. is a 43-year-old from Bluefields, married to Rogelio Sequeira. They have 3 young children. Mrs. B. is the proprietor of a general store. Her customers live in the neighborhood and prefer her store because of the wide selection of products available there. Currently, Mrs. B. needs to buy 200 Kg of rice at $90, 100 Kg of sugar at $36, 100 Kg of beans at $50, 1 barrel of oil at $41 and 3 boxes of laundry detergent at $18 a box. With this loan, she will be able to increase stock in order to satisfy customer demand.

Translated by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. Rosa Olimpia Benítez es originaria de la ciudad de Bluefields, tiene 43 años de edad esta casada con el Sr. Rogelio Sequeira ambos tienen 3 hijos menores de edad. La Sra. Benítez es propietaria de una pulpería, sus clientes son los habitantes del barrio que la prefieren por ofrecer una variedad de productos , en estos momentos la Sra. Benítez necesita comprar 2 quintales de arroz a $45.00 dólares el quintal , 1 quintal de azúcar a $36.00 dólares el quintal, 1 quintal de frijoles a $50.00 dólares el quintal , 1 bidón de aceite a $ 41.00 dólares el bidón y 3 cajas de jabón de lavar ropa a $ 18.00 dólares cada caja con esta inversión podrá aumentar la cantidad de productos para satisfacer la necesidades de sus clientes.

loans.use: To by rice, sugar, beans, oil and laundry detergent.

payments.comment: La cuota real de pago es de $ 34.19 dólares.
La cuota real es de $ 34.19 dólares.
La cuota real de pago es de $ 34.19 dólares
El credito que la  Sra. Benitez recibio  es de $ 273.53 dólares  a 8 meses de plazo. La cuota real efectuada de pago es  de 136.76 dólares pagando 4 cuotas cancelando su credito.

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Esi B. is a fishmonger and also sells other food products. She is married and has 3 children. She is working very hard to meet her family’s financial needs. She wants to increase sales so she can meet the increasing demands to support her family.

She is asking for a loan of $425 to purchase more fish for processing and selling.

loans.use: To purchase more fish for processing and selling

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 22, 2008)
Correction due to overpayment for business 43417

loans.name: Maria Emperatriz

texts.es:
Mrs. M.’s business is located in the Libertador district. She has been offering regional dishes for about 15 years, and for the moment, it’s the biggest source of family income. Her partner works as a laborer in the region. In the 15 years she’s had her business, she’s raised two sons who are now adults and have their own families, and little by little, she’s been able to make home improvements. She began by paying off her land lot in one payment, and has since been able to build a house dignified to live in. Her credit record with this institution, as with other institutions, is excellent and she demonstrates punctuality and responsibility in her financial transactions. Currently, she needs to have a absorption well installed to be a part of the potable water project in that area.

Translated by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. M. tiene su negocio ubicado en el departamento de la Libertad venta de comidas típicas el cual a mantenido al rededor de quince años y que por el momento sigue siendo la fuente de sus ingresos mayores en la familia el grupo familiar lo componen dos personas la solicitante y el compañero de vida quien trabaja como jornalero en la zona durante estos quince años de tener el negocio a podido sacar adelante a su grupo familiar sus dos hijos que ya crecieron y tienen su grupo familiar ya formado con estos esfuerzos además a podido ir mejorando poco a poco su vivienda comenzó pagando su lote en totalidad y hasta la fecha a podido construir una vivienda digna en la cual vivir, en su historial crediticio tanto con la institución como con otras instituciones es excelente ya que demuestra mucha puntualidad y responsabilidad en sus compromisos financieros, su necesidad actualmente es el poder efectuar un pozo de absorción que esta solicitando la empresa que efectuara el proyecto de instalación de Agua Potable en la zona

loans.use: To buy construction materials such as sand, gravel and cement to install an absorption well.

payments.comment: This entrepreneur has prepaid the remaining balance on her loan. She is very grateful for your loan and appreciates your support.

loans.name: Celso Inosencio

texts.es:
For 16 years, Mr. M. has been selling lottery tickets by foot in the regions of Sonsonate Armenia Izalco and San Julian and Santa Ana. He has 2 grown sons who have their own homes. All these years of work have permitted him to raise his children and take care of himself and his home. With great efforts, he’s been building his house. He’s a hard worker and responsible for his actions. This is his first loan with Integral. His credit history is excellent. He’d like to build a gutter in front of his house to evacuate the rain water from both his neighbor’s place and his.

Translated by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer.

El señor M. tiene 16 años de dedicarse a la venta de billetes de loteria vende de forma ambulante en Sonsonate Armenia Izalco y San Julian y Santa Ana tiene dos hijos actualmente los cuales ya son mayores y que tienen sus hogares, el señor a trabajado por años en esta actividad lo cual le a permitido el poder sacar adelante a sus hijos y poderse manetner a si mismo su vivienda la a ido construyendo con esfuerzos es una persona emprendedora y responsable en sus actos a tenido créditos con otras instituciones este seria el primero con Integral pero el historial crediticio se muestra con calificación excelente al manejar sus créditos la mejora que hará sera en frente de su vivienda una canaleta que recogera las aguas lluvias tanto de vecinos como de la vivienda en la cual esta habitando el cliente.

loans.use: To buy sand, cement and gravel to build a gutter in front of his house to evacuate the rain water coming from the street.

loans.name: Leonidas Pedro

texts.es:
The businessman Leonidas G. is 51-year-old married father of three. For 25 years he’s been selling fish and shellfish like lobster, snails and shrimp. He buys these products directly from artesian fishermen primarily from Bluefields and El Bluff port. He used to sell to the general public in Bluefields. Currently, he’s only buying fish and snails because it’s closed season on shrimp and lobster. This businessman solicits your financial support to buy 250 pounds of Yellowtail at $.90 US per pound, 250 pounds of Pargo at $.90 US per pound and 250 pounds of Croaker at $.80 US per pound.

Translated by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer.

El microempresario Leonidas G. tiene 51 años de edad, es originario de Bluefields, es casado tiene 3 hijos y desde hace 25 años se dedica a comprar mariscos, entre estos langostas, pescados, caracoles y camarones. Estos productos se los compra directamente a pescadores artesanales principalmente de Bluefields y el Puerto el Bluff. Posteriormente los vende a la poblacion en general de Bluefields. Actualmente solo esta comprando pescados y caracoles ya que tanto el camaron como la langosta se encuentran en veda. Este microempresario solicita el apoyo con un financiamiento para la compra de: 250 libras de pescado llelotiel el cual compra a US$ 0.90 dolares cada libra, 250 libras de pescado Pargo, el cual compra a US$ 0.90 dolares cada libra y 250 libras de pescado Roncador el cual compra a US$ 0.80 dolares cada libra.

loans.use: To buy 250 pounds of Yellowtail, 250 pounds of Pargo and 250 pounds of Croaker.

payments.comment: La cuota real de pago es de $ 54.17 dólares.
La cuota real de4 pago es de $ 54.17 dólares.
La  cuota real de pago es de $ 54.17 dólares

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Esi T. is a trader who buys goods in large quantities and sells smaller quantities to her customers. She is married and has 3 children. She doesn't have the funds to purchase enough goods to meet the demand of her customers.

Esi T. is asking for a loan of $425 to purchase more goods to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more goods to sell

payments.comment: Correction due to overpayment for business 43421

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
A. Esi is a trader. She travels to a distant town to buy Gary and other food items for sale. Her business is doing very well and she wishes to increase sales. She is married and has 3 children.

She is requesting a loan of $425 as additional capital to buy more food items to sell.

loans.use: To buy more food items to sell

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 22, 2008)
Correction due to overpayment for business 43422

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy 2 color TVs, 1 Nintendo Playstation and 5 chairs.

payments.comment: La cuota real de pago es de $ 42.32 dólares.
La cuota real de pago es $ 42.32 dólares

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more merchandise and to make some renovations in her home

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase school supplies and uniforms

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase parts

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Capital, primarily to stock their businesses

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to increase her merchandise so that she can sell different types of products.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in seafood, coal, and the meals his wife makes for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase various merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase merchandise to stock his business.

loans.name: Wiñay Waras Group

texts.es:
The Wiñay Waras Association is more than 12 years old, in the center of Alto Lima and one of the most responsible and punctual with regard to payments and the success of its businesses. It is made up primarily of women who most definitely collaborate with each other in the areas of responsibility and timeliness, in particular the younger members who make up the association. This group is characterized by commercial endeavors, primarily involving basic necessities and in some cases the ladies have their own place of business. This does not stop them, however, from also marketing their products at the fairs and markets. Currently, the Wiñay Waras Association requires capital to strengthen the business and to be ready for the various fairs in the cities of El Alto and La Paz.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

La Asociación Wiñay Waras es una asociación con una antigüedad de más de 12 años aproximadamente dentro del Centro Focal de Alto Lima, una de las más responsables y puntuales en referencia al pago de cuotas y a la prosperidad de sus negocios. Esta conformada en gran parte por mujeres que definitivamente colaboran en aspectos de responsabilidad y puntualidad principalmente a aquellas socias jóvenes que integran la Asociación. Esta asociación se caracteriza por el comercio de mercadería, principalmente artículos de primera necesidad, como ser víveres y en algunos casos las señoras son dueñas de tiendas de abarrotes, o simplemente venta de víveres al crédito. La mayoría no cuenta con puestos de venta propio, pero eso no impide que realicen su trabajo en ferias y mercados. Actualmente la asociación Wiñay Waras precisa de capital para fortalecer sus negocios, preparándolos para las distintas ferias de la ciudad de El Alto y La Paz.

loans.use: Require capital to strengthen their businesses.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Pro Mujer Bolivia - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Amancaya Group

texts.es:
The Amancaya group is comprised of eighteen members, all young and enterprising, who are in their 15th cycle of working in an organized and timely manner for their loans.

The group members have a deep-rooted belief system, and this conviction leads them to seek a blessing of their activities. For this, they practice the traditional ritual called “Ch’alla” whereby offerings are made to Pachamama, goddess of the earth, to allow them to succeed in their enterprise.

Their primary activities include making clothing such as sweaters, blankets, skirts and other casual clothes. In some instances, they can position themselves at the 16th of July Market, one of the main markets in the city of El Alto.

They require funds to inject more capital into their business so they can buy both raw materials and finished product to sell to the affluent customers who frequent the city’s markets.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

El grupo Amancaya , es una asociación compuesta por 18 socias, todas bastante jóvenes y emprendedoras, ya cumplen su ciclo numero 15 trabajando con mucha organización y puntualidad en cuanto a sus creditos La asociación Amancaya son de creencias muy arraigadas, por tal motivo toda actividad que emprenden, lleva la bendición y aprobación de los dioses de la tierra, para esto, realizan el tradicional ritual de la Ch’alla, ritual donde se realizan ofrendas a la Pachamama, la diosa de la tierra, y la que les permitirá tener el éxito en la actividad que emprendan. Dentro de sus principales actividades se encuentra la confección y comercialización de diversas prendas de vestir, como ser mantas, mantillas, polleras, ropa casual y otros, en algunos casos cuentan con puestos propios ubicados en la Feria 16 de Julio, la principal feria de la ciudad de El Alto. Ellas precisan de dinero para una fuerte inyección de capital a sus negocios, tanto para la compra de materia prima, como para la compra de mercadería en si, tomando en cuenta la gran afluencia de gente que se da a laa ferias de la ciudd.

loans.use: Capital for the business, both to purchase raw materials as well as finished product.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Pro Mujer Bolivia - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Un Nuevo Dia 3 Group

texts.es:
Victoria Guadalupe is 30 years old and is married with one child. She belongs to the group “A New Day 3”. With her loan, she will invest in the purchase of basic foods such as rice, sugar, salt, pasta, etc., to supply the small store she runs from her house since in the area where she lives there are no nearby stores. With her business, she can help to meet the locals’ needs as well as help her husband with their living expenses. The other group members include Maria Dolores (clothing sales), Ricarda (food sales), Juliana (fruit and vegetable sales), Adelina Agustina and Maria Asuncion (general store).

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

VICTORIA GUADALUPE TIENE 30 AÑOS, CASADA, UN HIJO. PERTENECE AL GRUPO SOLIDARIO LLAMADO UN NUEVO DIA 3. CON SU PRESTAMO INVERTIRA EN LA COMPRA DE ALIMENTOS BASICOS: ARROZ, AZUCAR, SAL, PASTAS, ETC., PARA ABASTECER LA PEQUEÑA TIENDA QUE TIENE EN SU CASA, YA QUE POR DONDE VIVE NO HAY TIENDAS CERCANAS Y CON ESTE NEGOCIO AYUDARA A SATISFACER UNA NECESIDAD DE LA GENTE DE SU LOCALIDAD Y PARA SI MISMA YA QUE DE ESTA FORMA APOYARA A SU ESPOSO CON LOS GASTOS DEL HOGAR. LAS DEMAS INTEGRANTES DEL GRUPO: MARIA DOLORES (VENTA DE ROPA), RICARDA (VENTA DE ALIMENTOS), JULIANA (VENTA DE FRUTAS Y VERDURAS), ADELINA AGUSTINA Y MARIA ASUNCION (TIENDA DE ABARROTES).

loans.use: Invest in the purchase of basic foods.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase plastic products and small appliances.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use:
to purchase various merchandise for re-sale

El crédito lo utilizara en la compra mercadería variada

loans.name: Kim

texts.en: Mrs. Kim W. is 48 years old and lives in Thom Village in Kandal Province. She is a single mother with two children, both of whom are working and can earn around US$4.80 per day. Mrs. Kim W. owns a butcher store in the market: she buys animals that are raised by villagers and then sells them to her customers for a profit. Aside from this work, Mrs. Kim W. is a farmer and grows vegetables in her field which is next to her village. However, the amount of vegetable seeds that she has is insufficient, and Mrs. W. lacks money to buy more. She would therefore like to take out a loan to be able to buy more seeds to cultivate on her field.

loans.use: Purchase of vegetable seeds

loans.name: Doeun

texts.en: Mrs. Doeun T. is 35 years old and the mother of four children, all of whom are still in school. She stays at home to look after her children and cook food for the entire family. Her husband, Mr. Dosh Chea, 52, is a construction worker who earns $5 a day building houses. He has applied for a loan from Kiva to buy wood for his construction business.

loans.use: To buy wood for a home-building business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Choeun

texts.en: Mrs. Choeun S. is 25 years old, has two children and lives with her husband in Siem Reap province. She earns about $2 a day selling fried bananas. Her husband, Mr. Kong Dy, is a 30-year-old motor-taxi driver who earns about $5 a day. Mrs. Choeun has applied for a loan from Kiva to buy a plot of farmland so that she can increase her income by growing a variety of vegetables. (Photo: Mr. Kong driving a motorbike with his wife behind him and his son in the front seat)

loans.use: To purchase farmland on which to grow vegetables.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: I Gede Kenul

texts.id:
I Gede Kenul is a paddy farmer located at Pangkung Buluh village. He is married and have several children. His job as a farmer is the main and only source of income for his family.

He works on a land of 1.5 hectares (around 15,000 square meter) and he is awaiting for harvest season at the moment. The main problem he is facing in farming is lack of capital to enable him to buy a high quality paddy seeds and also to buy the farming utilities. Therefore he is applying for a loan from Dinari foundation. He will use the loan money to buy high quality seed fertilizer and pesticide. He hopes to be able to improve the quality of his paddy harvest by having all of those.

With this his revenue will increase and he will be able to finance his children's education to higher level and also to help him to meet his family's daily needs.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer.

I Gede Kenul seorang petani padi yang berlokasi di desa pangkung Buluh,menjalankan usahanya dengan penuh semangat walaupun ditengah teriknya matahari. Semua karena rasa tanggungjawabnya terhadap keluarga dan pendidikan anak-anaknya.Apalagi istrinya sebagai ibu rumah tangga tidak mempunyai penghasilan yang tetap.Jadi semua masalah keuangan menjadi tanggungjawab I Gede Kenul .Lahan yang digarap sekitar 1.5 hektar dan kini sedang menunggu panen. Tapi dalam penggarapan lahan ini I Gede Kenul mengalami kekurangan modal baik dalam pembelian bibit maupun pemeliharaannya. Oleh sebab itu I Gede Kenul mengajukan pinjaman kepada Yayasan Dinari. Pinjaman ini dipergunakan untuk membeli bibit unggul,penggarapan sawah,karena semua penggarapan menggunakan tenaga traktor,karena I Gede Kenul tidak memiliki Sapi yang dipergunakan untuk membajak, kemudian membeli pupuk dan obat-obat vestisida lainnya. Dengan harapan hasil yang diperoleh akan meningkat dari pada panen sebelumnya yang hanya menggunakan bibit lokal ,dan pemeliharaanya tidak maksimal. Panen yang akan datang ini diharapkan keuntungan yang diperoleh menjadi meningkat ,sehingga I Gede Kenul bisa menyekolahkan anak-anaknya ketingkat yang lebih tinggi, dan keluarganya bisa sejahtera dan tercukupi.

loans.use: To buy high quality paddy seeds, pesticide and fertilizer (Membeli bibit padi jenis unggul, anti hama dan pupuk)

loans.name: I Gede Suendra

texts.id:
To be able to support family's economical well being, I Gede Suendra has to work to obtain an income, especially now where his children need funds to pay for school expenses. That is why I Gede Suendra works on his brother's rice fields, while he is stationed in an outer island. The land he worked on is about 1 hectare. Because of subak (local rules) which is good in Pangkung Buluh village, now is I Gede Suendra's time to plant rice. As a tenant farmer whose life is very simple, to process a 1 hectare land, I Gede Suendra did not have enough funds. Especially if planted with local seeds, and non maximal maintenance, he is afraid that the results would be very unsatisfactory, and his efforts wasted. That is why I Gede Suendra requested a loan from Dinari Foundation. This loan would be used to buy superior rice seeds, fertilizer, and also insecticides, and to work the fields by rented tractor power, since I Gede Suendra does not own a cow to plow the rice field. He hopes that the upcoming harvest would bring good results, so that his profit would increase. From this profit, I Gede Suendra wished to be able to provide schooling for his children, enough to be able to support his household expenses, so that I Gede Suendra could have a happy family.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Untuk bisa menopang perekonomian keluarga I Gede Suendra,harus bekerja agar mendapatkan penghasilan,apalagisekarang anak-anaknya sedang membutuhkan biaya untuk bersekolah.Oleh sebab itu I Gede Suendra menggarap sawah milik Saudaranya yang kebetulan bertugas di luar pulau. Lahan yang digarap sekitar 1 hektar. Karena pengaturan subak yang baik di desa Pangkung Buluh maka sekarang giliran di lokasi I Gede Suendra untuk menanam padi. Sebagai petani penggarap yang hidupnya sangat sederhana ,maka untuk pengolahan tanah 1 hektar I Gede Suendra menjadi kekurangan modal. Apabila ditanami dengan bibit lokal dan pemeliharaan tidak maksimal ,maka nantinya ia kawatir hasil yang diperoleh tidak bagus,sehingga biaya yang dikeluarkan menjadi sia-sia. Oleh sebab itu I Gede Suendra mengajukan pinjaman kepada Yayasan Dinari,pinjaman ini dipergunakan untuk membeli bibit unggul,pupuk dan juga obat-obat vestisida dan penggarapannya pun menggunakan tenaga traktor karena I Gede Suendra tidak mempunyai Sapi untuk membajak disawah. Hal ini diharapkan panen yang akan datang mendapatkan hasil yang bagus,dan keuntungan yang diporolehpun akan meningkat. Dari keuntungan ini I Gede Suendra mempunyai keinginan untuk bisa menyekolahkan anak-anaknya dan juga mencukupi kebutuhan rumah tangganya,sehingga I Gede Suendra memiliki keluarga yang sejahtera.

loans.use:
To buy superior quality rice seeds, insecticide and fertilizer

Membeli bibit padi jenis unggul, anti hama dan pupuk

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Thim

texts.en: Thim S. is a 65-year-old widow living in the Prey Kao commune of Kampong Cham. Since 1980, she has worked hard as a rice and vegetable farmer making less than $1 per day. All of her children are single and live at home. With this small loan, she hopes to purchase better-quality land that will allow her to grow rice even during the dry season in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy better-quality farmland.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Kong

texts.en: Kong S. is 23 years old and lives in the Me Mut district of Kampong Cham province. She earns $3 a day as a yam farmer. Her husband, Njek Sopheap, adds $4 per day to the family income as a cigarette salesman. If their yam crop yields are high this year, they will be able to set up a stand to sell them along the Vietnamese border and better support their young child. They want to use their loan to invest in more farmland on which to grow yams.

loans.use: To purchase additional farmland.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Yon

texts.en:
Mrs. Yon L., age 31, is a garment worker who has lived in Siem Reap province since 2005. She earns $2.50 a day.
Her husband is a construction worker who builds houses and makes $6 a day. They have three children, all of whom are in school. This couple has applied for a loan from Kiva to buy a motorbike that they will use to commute to work and to buy some land. They will hold on to the land until the price goes up, and then sell it for a profit.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike and a piece of land.

loans.name: Sutaminingsih

texts.id:
The kiosk business, which Sutaminingsih runs in front of her house, is her main job. Her husband, Sujarwo, is a merchant who sells fish powder in Pesisir beach. When there is no fish powder, Sujarwo helps her wife taking care of the kiosk. Sutaminingsih's kiosk offers quite a complete range of merchandise. Many people around her neighbourhood and smaller kiosks are her regular customers. Sutaminingsih got a loan from DINARI for buying more merchandises. She sells rice, cooking oil, eggs, and various kitchen materials, snacks, and also stationaries. The kiosk opens from 6 am until 8 pm. Sutaminingsih usually purchases the merchandises twice a week. She can spend about Rp. 500,000 to Rp. 1,000,000 for the merchandises. Her net profit is Rp. 50,000 per day. She gets additional income from this business so she can use it for her daily expenses and her children's education.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Kustini Lim, Kiva volunteer.

Usaha Warung yang dikelola Sutaminingsih yang ada didepan rumahnya, merupakan usaha yang menjadi pekerjaan pokoknya. Suaminya, Sujarwo, adalah pedagang tepung ikan yang ada di daerah Pesisir pantai. Kalau tidak ada tepung ikan, Sujarwo ikut bergantian dengan istrinya untuk menunggui warungnya. Usaha warung Sutaminingsih sudah tergolong lengkap. Banyak penduduk disekitar tempat tinggalnya yang menjadi pelanggannya, bahkan banyak warung-warung kecil yang menjadi pelanggannya. Untuk mencukupi dan melengkapi barang dagangannya, Sutaminingsih mendapat pinjaman dana dari yayasan DINARI. Barang-barang yang disediakan warungnya yaitu beras, minyak goreng, telor dan segala macam kebutuhan dapur, aneka makanan ringan, peralatan tulis juga tersedia. Warung buka mulai pukul 06.00 pagi dan tutup pada pukul 20.00 malam.Untuk melengkapi barang dagangan biasanya Sutaminingsih berbelanja dua kali dalam satu minggu. Sekali berbelanja Sutaminingsih bisa menghabiskan Rp. 500.000.- s/d Rp.1.000.000.- Dengan keuntungan bersih Rp. 50.000.- dapat diraihnya dalam sehari. Dengan pekerjaan inilah Sutaminingsih dapat memperoleh pendapatan sehingga dapat untuk mencukupi keperluan sehari- hari dan juga keperluan sekolah dua orang anaknya selain dari penghasilan suaminya.

loans.use: To add more capital

loans.name: Prem

texts.en:
Mrs. Prem C., age 27, is a housewife who stays at home looking after her four children and cooking for her family . 
Her husband, Mr. Nai Leak, is a 24-year-old construction worker who is busy building a house. He has been in construction for more than ten years and makes around $5 a day. To raise an extra income to support her family, Mrs. Prem has applied for a loan from Kiva to buy a generator, speaker and musical equipment. Her husband plans to rent them out to people who live in their area when they have a party or celebration. (Mr. Nai is pictured here because his wife was not available to be photographed.)

loans.use: To buy a generator, speaker and musical equipment.

loans.name: Kith

texts.en: Kith S. is 30 years old and has been farming rice and various kinds of vegetables since 1995. She makes less than $1 doing this. Her husband works in their village in Kampong Cham as a traditional doctor and earns $4 a day.  They have four children. Mrs. Kith has applied for a loan to buy additional medical supplies for her husband's practice. This will allow him to provide services to people beyond those in their immediate village. She will use any money left over from the loan to buy commercial fertilizer for their rice and vegetable fields.

loans.use: To buy medicine and additional health care equipment.

loans.name: Vanna

texts.en: Mrs. Vanna S. is a fish seller in Thom Village. She is 43 years old and has four children, two of whom are attending a local school, while the others are already working. Her husband, Ros Chhum, is a fisherman. Mrs. Vanna S. usually helps her husband in fishing and then sells the fish in the village. Additionally, she grows crops on a field. Mrs. S. currently needs a loan to buy more vegetable seeds to cultivate on the field.

loans.use: Purchase of vegetable seeds

loans.name: Istiqomah

texts.id:
For the sake of her food kiosk business, Istikomah lives in her kiosk in Dermaga Pangembangan area, West Bali. Her regular customers are fishermen who just come back from the sea. Her kiosk opens 24 hours because there are always customers who come to the kiosk. The most crowded time is around 2pm to 8pm when fishermen just arrive in the shore and they directly go to her kiosk for having breakfast or buying take-away food. When DINARI entered the area, Istikomah was fortunate to get a loan from DINARI. She uses the loan for buying the raw materials for her food kiosk. She usually buys the food materials in the market. Her net profit can reach Rp. 100,000 per day when many customers come to the kiosk and during the fish season. Istikomah uses the profit for helping her husband and for adding her family's income.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Kustini Lim, Kiva volunteer.

Demi menjalankan usaha warung nasinya, Istikomah rela menginap diwarungnya yang ada disekitar Dermaga Pengambengan, Bali barat. Pelanggan warung nasinya adalah para nelayan yang baru tiba dari laut setelah mencari ikan di laut lepas.Warung dibuka selama 24 jam karena ada saja pelanggan yang datang berbelanja di sekitar dermaga. Saat- saat paling ramai adalah pukul 14.00 s/d 20.00 wita setelah nelayan sampai di darat dan langsung ke warungnya untuk makan pagi setelah semalaman melaut maupun untuk bekal makanan dalam bekerja ditengah laut untuk mencari ikan. Pelayanan Yayasan DINARI sampai di daerah tersebut dan akhirnya Istikomah mendapat kepercayaan dan memperoleh dana pinjaman. Dengan dana pinjaman tersebut Istikomah pergunakan untuk menambah modal usahanya yaitu untuk berbelanja segala keperluan usaha warung makannya.untuk berbelanja lauk pauk yang dilakukannya hari dipasar. Keuntungan bersih dalam sehari mencapai Rp.100.000.- jika situasi sedang ramai dan musim ikan. Dari keuntungan inilah Istikomah dapat meringankan beban suaminya untuk menambah pendapatan keluarganya.

loans.use: To add more capital

loans.name: Sang

texts.en: Mrs. Sang L., age 53, has seven children and lives in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. Her husband, Mr. Kong Ven, 40, is a logger and earns about $5 a day. One of their children is married and lives away from home, and another works as a waitress in a restaurant in Siem Reap, where she earns around $100 a month. Their five other children are all students. This couple has applied for a loan to buy a plot of farmland, on which they will grow a variety of vegetables. By doing this, they will increase their income and provide better support to their family.

loans.use: To buy land on which to grow vegetables.

loans.name: I Kadek Rustika

texts.id:
Kadek Rustika wakes up every morning at around 3 am and then he goes to the town market to buy merchandises to be sold. He has run this business for quite some time. After he got all the materials, Kadek Rustika travels around with his motorcycle to sell the merchandises. He sells various kinds of vegetables, meats, fishes, cakes, and also ready-to-eat food. Kadek Rustika usually starts traveling at 5 to 8 am to meet his regular customers. His regular customers are housewives who live quite far from the market. Based on the information from his relatives, Kadek Rustika applied for a loan from DINARI foundation. Kadek Rustika used the loan to add more capital and to cover sales expenses. In a day, Kadek Rustika spends about Rp. 250,000 to Rp. 300,000 for sales expenses. His net profit is about Rp. 30,000 to Rp. 40,000. Kadek Rustika uses the profit to cover his family expenses.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Kustini Lim, Kiva volunteer.

Kadek Rustika setiap pagi harus bangun pagi sekitar pukul 03.00 wita dan harus bergegas ke pasar pagi di kotanya untuk berbelanja keperluan dagangannya.Usaha dagang sayur memang sudah ditekuni sejak lama. Setelah barang dagangannya lengkap, Kadek Rustika berkeliling dengan sepeda motornya untuk menjajakan barang dagangannya. Barang barang yang di jual yaitu aneka macam sayuran hijau untuk keperluan masak, daging, ikan, aneka macam kue, aneka macam sayur yang sudah dimasak dan dibungkus dengan plastik. Biasanya Kadek Rustika mulai berkeliling pukul 05.00 s/d 08.00 wita menemui pelanggannya. Pelanggannya adalah ibu-ibu yang ada di daerah pedesaan yang jauh dari pasar . Melalui informasi oleh saudaranya akhirnya Kadek Rustika mengajukan permohonan untuk mendapatkan pinjaman dana dari Yayasan DINARI. Dengan dana itulah Kadek Rustika memakainya untuk tambahan modal usaha dan memenuhi keperluan usaha dagang sayur keliling. Dalam sehari Kadek Rustika membelanjakan dana sampai Rp. 250.000.- s/d Rp. 300.000,- yang terpakai untuk keperluan usaha dagang sayur keliling. Dengan keuntungan bersih mencapai Rp. 30.000 s/d Rp. 40.000,- Dengan keuntungan inilah kadek Rustika dapat mencukupi keperluan keluargnya bersama seorang anaknya.

loans.use: To add more capital

loans.name: Kol

texts.en:
Mrs. Kol P., 21, is a grocer and farmer who earn about $2.50 per day. She lives with her husband, Chhorn Kim Non, her only child, and her parents in the Kanher Baydach Village, Pursat Province. Kim Non makes $2.50 per day transporting merchandise to the Pursat Market.

P. requests a $600 loan to purchase small pigs to raise and to buy a used motorcycle. This will make it easier and more economical for her husband to transport goods to the market, thus increasing their income. P.’s mother is pictured in the photo because P. and her husband were not available at the time.

loans.use: To purchase small pigs to raise, and a used motorcycle

loans.name: Sai

texts.en: Mrs. Sai M. is 35 years old and earns about $4 a day raising pigs and growing rice on her farm. Her husband, Mr. Lao Siem, makes a living raising fish, and makes around $3 a day. They have three children who help their mother farm. They have applied for a loan to buy a grinding mill that they can use and also rent out to their neighbors. Mrs. Sai plans to use the additional revenue generated by the mill to support the family and buy fertilizers to use on her farm. (Picture: husband and wife)

loans.use: To buy a grinding mill and fertilizer.

loans.name: Korng

texts.en: Mrs. Korng S. is 45 years old and lives in Thom Village in Kandal Province. She is married and has three children, two of whom are enrolled in a local school, while the third one is working. Additionally, she is a subsistance farmer who cultivates many different kinds of vegetables. Her husband, Heourn Ourk, is a motorbike taxi-driver, but earns too little to support the needs of the family. Due to their poor living condition and insufficient income, Mrs. Korng S. needs a loan to buy more mushroom seeds to cultivate on her field.

loans.use: Purchase of mushroom seeds

loans.name: Laor

texts.en: Laor H. is 53 years old and lives in Kampong Cham province with her husband. Both of them have been rice farmers since 1985, and they earn a little over $2 a day. They have seven children, four of whom are married. One of their daughters is a garment-factory worker and makes about $50 a month. They also have a son who lives in Thailand, where he makes $30 a day and manages to send some money home. Mrs. Laor wants to use her loan to buy a grinding mill to use for food production, and thereby increase her family's income. She hopes to be able to send all of her children to university, and someday buy a second grinding mill.

loans.use: To buy a grinding mill.

loans.name: Heng

texts.en: Mrs. Heng K. is 32 years old and has two children. At her home, she works hard raising pigs and cows as livestock. Her husband works as the village doctor. They each make about $5 a day. Beside his work as a doctor, her husband also owns a plot of farmland on which he grows vegetables. Mrs. Heng hopes to use her loan to buy a grinding mill for the village and to hire the workers needed to run it. This additional business could free her from the economic vulnerability of raising livestock and generate greater income for her family.  (Picture: her husband)

loans.use: To buy a grinding mill.

loans.name: Teuth

texts.en: Teuth L. is 24 years old  and lives in Kampong Cham province with her husband and their two young children. Both she and her husband work in the rice fields, where they earn a combined $2.50 a day. She wants to buy a grinding mill that she can use to prepare her own food, as well as rent out to local farmers. With their increased income, she hopes to buy additional farmland and possibly even a generator for their home.

loans.use: To purchase a grinding mill.

loans.name: Nhiv

texts.en: Mrs. Nhiv P., a 34-year-old widow, makes about $4 per day as a teacher at the Tapong Secondary School in Battambang Province. She supplements her income by selling groceries. P. lives with her three children, all of whom are students, in the Kork Kduoch Village, Battambang Province. P. seeks a $300 loan to expand her business. With this loan, she hopes to generate more income and improve her family’s financial stability.

loans.use: To enlarge her grocery-selling business

loans.name: Touch

texts.en: Mrs. Touch D. is a 31-year-old widow, and makes a living as a garment worker at a factory in the central province of Kompong Chnang. She earns only $2-$3 a day, and works hard to support her only child. With this loan, she hopes to build a home that she and her child can live in.

loans.use: To build a home that she and her child can live in.

loans.name: Thorn

texts.en: Mrs. Thorn P. is 27 years old and lives with her husband in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She makes a living by selling various kinds of grocery products to the people in her area, and earns about $5 a day . Her husband earns about $3 each day working as a construction foreman. Mrs. Thorn P. has three children who are too young to attend school.  She has applied for a loan to buy a motor-bike that will allow her to transport grocery products to her food stand.

loans.use: To purchase a motor-bike for her business.

loans.name: Neur

texts.en: Mrs. Neur C. lives in Tropeng Angkrorng Village in Kompong Speu Province. She is 22 years old and has two children, one of whom attends school, while the other is still too young. Mrs. Neur C. is a water supplier who sells water in her village. Mrs. Neur's husband, Mr. Lim Tha, is a motorbike driver and also delivers water containers to the villagers. Currently, the couple is facing financial difficulties, since Mr. Lim's motorbike is old and always needs repairs. Therefore, Mrs. Neur would like to request a loan to buy a new motorbike.

loans.use: Purchase of a new motorbike

loans.name: Yem

texts.en: Mrs. Yem S., 43, makes around $3.20 per day selling porridge and Chinese noodles from her home in the Kab Kor Thmey Village, Battambang Province. Her husband, Mr. Hem Sok Sakhon, makes about $2 per day as a motorcycle taxi driver. S. has four children, one married and three single. She seeks a loan of $1,000 to enlarge her business. With an improved business, S. can support her family’s living expenses and pay for her children’s school fees. S. and her husband are in the photo.

loans.use: To enlarge her porridge and Chinese-noodle business

loans.name: Prak

texts.en: Mrs. Prak S. is 49 years old and has six children. She makes a living by running a stand near her home from which she sells a Cambodian delicacy that is made of papaya mixed with fermented fish, chili and small shrimp. Her husband works at a construction site and earns about $3 per day. Mrs. Prak S. has applied for a loan to purchase some utensils and more equipment for her stand so that she can raise her income and meet her clients' demand. She will also use the loan to buy a motor-bike that her husband will use to commute to work. This will make their lives easier, and help them raise their standard of living.

loans.use: to buy utensils and equipment for her stand

loans.name: Chem

texts.en: Mrs. Chem S. is 28 years old, has two young children and makes her living farming a variety of vegetables in Kompong Chnang province. She makes only $1.50 a day. Her husband, Von Somban, is 34 and works both as a fisherman and rice farmer, bringing in another $1.50 daily. Ms. Chem wants to use her loan to buy a motor-taxi for her husband so he can move into a higher-earning occupation. His higher earning power will help him better support his wife and two children. (Mr. Von Somban is pictured with the motorbike he would like to purchase)

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Navy

texts.en: Mrs. Navy H., 32, lives in Sarikakeo Village in Kompong Speu Province and is married to Mr. Chan Seourn. They have two children who are both too young to work or attend school. Mrs. Nary Hul and her husband own a grocery store in a local market and have no difficulties running the business. However, Mrs. Navy H. would like to expand her business and is therefore applying for a loan to buy more grocery goods for sale.

loans.use: Purchase of grocery goods for sale

loans.name: Theab

texts.en: Mrs.Theab S. is a widow and the mother of four children. One of her children is a motor-taxi driver and all four live on their own.
