Mrs. Theab S. makes a living by selling porridge from a stand in front of her house. She earns about $1 to $2 a day. Theab S. is a diligent mother who has worked hard to help her children since her husband passed away many years ago. She has to get up very early in the morning to cook her breakfast for her customers. Recently, Mrs. Theab decided that it would be a good idea to purchase some pigs to breed on her piece of land because the leftover food from her food stand makes excellent feed for them. To do this, she needs a loan to help her buy some piglets to breed.

loans.use: to buy pigs to breed

loans.name: Long

texts.en: Mrs. Long P. is 46 years old and lives in Kompong Chnang province, where she makes a living raising pigs and planting rice. Her husband, Long Hout, works as a fisherman. Their combined income amounts to only $3.50 per day. Of their nine children, one is married and works as a village blacksmith. Two of the older children stay home to work in the rice paddies while the other six are in school. Mrs. Long wants to use her loan to buy more farmland on which to grow rice. With the additional income generated from another plot, she hopes to be able to adequately feed and support her large family. (Picture: husband and wife)

loans.use: To purchase farmland.

loans.name: Pen

texts.en:
Mr. Pen S. lives in the Koh Kor Krao Village, Kampong Cham Province. S. is 47 years old and is a construction worker, earning about $3.66 per day. His wife, Mrs. Heng Bora, is 44 years old and a farmer. Bora earns about $1.33 per day and has two children, all of whom are students.

Mr. S. request a loan of $700 to buy a cement mixer to make his work easier. This will help increase his income and support his family’s expenses. Bora is pictured in the photo because S. was not available at the time.

loans.use: To buy a cement mixer to make his work easier

loans.name: Shafiq Allah

texts.en: Shafiq Allah lives in District 5 of Kabul Afghanistan. He is married and has a small grocery store, a business he has operated for more than five years. With an excellent location in Kabul, his store is doing well, so he now is requesting a loan to expand his inventory. The resulting increased income will allow him to better support his family.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Hut

texts.en:
Mrs. Hut N., 52, is the mother of one child and lives in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. Her husband passed away many years ago, so she has to cover all of her family’s expense by making Khmer traditional cakes called "Num Anksom" (bananas wrapped in coconut sticky rice, then wrapped in banana leaves and boiled). Mrs. Hug N. and sells them to the people in her community. Each day, she can make approximately $2 of net income. She is so happy with her business.

To improve her standard of living, Mrs. Hut N. has humbly applied for a loan of $300 to expand her business. The remainder of the loan is to buy a motorbike for her son to commute to work and also use for her business's transportation.

loans.use: To expand her business and to buy a motorbike

loans.name: Sayaad Dawood

texts.en: Sayaad Dawood lives in District 5 of Kabul Afghanistan, where he is married and the father of five children. With a degree in agriculture, he works very hard in the field, his family’s only source of income. He is requesting a loan in order to expand his business by increasing his inventory. This, in turn, will allow him to better support his family.

loans.use: To expand his agricultural stock

loans.name: Abdulla Jan

texts.en: Abdulla Jan, who is married, lives in District 17 of Kabul Afghanistan. Returning from Pakistan about a year ago with his family, Abdulla opened a clothing shop.  During this time he has established a solid customer base, but he is now requesting a loan to purchase new designs of clothing.  This will help him to increase his income, thereby enabling his family to have a better life in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To buy new designs of clothes

loans.name: Fatha Mohammad

texts.en: Fatha Mohammad lives in District 5 of Kabul Afghanistan, where he is  the married father of three children, two daughters and one son. Fatha has been involved in agriculture for more than five years, during which time he has worked hard to further his business. He now needs to expand his business to better provide for his family, and is therefore requesting a loan to increase his agricultural stock so as to cultivate all of his land.  Fatha thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To expand his agricultural stock

loans.name: Plong

texts.en:
Mrs. Plong N. is 54 and is married with ten children. Five of her children are married, two are farmers who breed cows and grow rice, and the rest cook food for their household. Mrs. Plong N. is a widow. Since her husband passed away many years ago, Plong N. has to carry the burden of covering all of her family’s expenses by herself.

She has a stand at a market selling various kinds of vegetables and she, normally, she can make about $1 to $2 of net income each day. She has humbly requested a loan to expand her vegetable booth. With the leftover money, she will purchase another plot of farmland to expand her family’s crops.

loans.use: To expand her vegetable booth and purchase another plot of farmland

loans.name: Kalsoom's Group

texts.en:
I am Kalsoom S. and a mother of five: four girls and one boy. My eldest daughter is married. My next daughter helps me in my household chores. The next girl is working and the the youngest attends school. My son is working as a plumber. My husband has lived abroad for the last four years. I am borrowing a loan for my son so that he can buy pipes, bolts and other matierals in bulk for his business. Buying in bulk is cheaper and saves us on the cost per item.

My group members who are also in need of loans are: Suriya N., who wants to payoff the remaining money she owes for her donkey cart; Ameera B., who needs this loan for her husband’s shopping-bag trade; and Yasmeen B., who is borrowing for her grocery store.

This is a group loan and funds will be distributed among group members, each of whom will either invest in her own or her household's business.

loans.use: To buy pipes, bolts and other related materials for the repairing business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Nguyen Thi T. is 43 years old, married and has 3 children. She lives in Hanh Lam with her family. Her main income comes from farming, making bread and raising cows and chickens. She also has a milling machine, which provides her with additional income as well as some leftover bran. To take full advantage of this source of chickenfeed, she wants to borrow $750 to buy some calves and chickens.

loans.use: To purchase calves and chickens

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for TYM Fund - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Parween's Group

texts.en:
My name is Parween A.. I was born in Pakistan’s second largest city, Lahore, but after marriage I had to move to a small city, Borewala, with my husband. I am a mother of four sons. Two of my sons are married and live in our native village and the other two live with me. When my kids were young I used to sew clothes on order. However, I do not stitch anymore. My husband is a plumber. My two sons sell milk. Currently we need to expand our milk business, and therefore need to buy a cow. We are requesting a loan to buy a dairy cow.

My group members need loans for the following businesses: Nasreen B. will invest her share of the loan in her husband’s business. He is a plumber. Safia B. plans to sell bangles from her house. Khursheed B. is a widow and wants to invest her share of the loan in her juice corner.

loans.use: Buy a dairy cow

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Rin

texts.en: Mrs. Rin N. is 44 years old and lives in Trapaing Angkrorng Village in Kompong Speu Province. She is a vegetable and petroleum seller and the mother of five children, three of whom are working in a garment factory while the others are too young to work and study. Her husband, Art Hout, earns income transporting dirt in the village. Mrs. Rin N. and her husband usually spend US$75 per month on regular family expenses as well as wedding ceremonies and funerals. Mrs. Rin N. would like to obtain a loan to buy more vegetables and petroleum for sale. In addition, she would use part of the money to build stairs for their house.

loans.use: Purchase of vegetables and petroleum for sale

loans.name: Ye

texts.en: Mrs. Ye A. was born in 1984 and now lives in Snam Pok Village in Kompong Speu Province. She is a farmer and sells vegetables in the market. She has a child who is too young to attend school. Mrs. Ye A.’s husband is Mr. Ley Pon, who is a motorbike taxi-driver. Most of their income comes from vegetable sales and motorbike taxi fares. Unfortunately, the motorbike is old and always needs to be repaired, so it is an obstacle for her husband’s business. Thus, Mrs. Ye A. would like to buy a new motorbike. To be able to do so, she is asking for a loan.

loans.use: Purchase of a new motorbike

loans.name: Yorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Yorn R., age 43, is the mother of three children and works as farmer growing rice on her farmland. On average, she earns around $1 a day of profit. All of the children help their parents work.

Her husband, Mr. Moun Pha, 45 years old, is a worker. He is usually hired by villagers to harvest their rice and, normally, he makes about $4 a day in revenue.

This couple would like to request a loan from Kiva to purchase a small truck. They will rent this truck hire to the villagers to transport their rice.

loans.use: To purchase a small truck.

loans.name: Lidia's Maisha Group

texts.en:
Lidia is 28 years old and is a single woman and she takes care of one other person. Lidia owns a small shop and is a tailor, which she started in 2007. Everyday she works from 8.30am to 9pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $20 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Emmy, who is a shop owner.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Naomi's Maisha Group

texts.en:
Naomi is 35 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, ages 16,12 and 3 years old. She and her husband also take care of 4 other people, ages 60, 68,18 and 17 years old. Naomi owns a small beauty salon and is a cosmetics seller, which is a business she started in 2002. Everyday she works from 8am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $15 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Grace, who has a tailoring business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Yen

texts.en:
Mrs. Yen T., age 45, has had a business selling groceries and vegetables in a market since 1979. She earns around $5 a day in revenue. Her husband, Mr. Sim Savoeun, 48, stays at home and raises pigs. He makes approximately $3 a day. They have eight children. Three are married and live away from home. Three sons are construction workers in Phnom Penh City and earn around $3 each per day. One other daughter works in a restaurant with a salary $50 a month.

Mr. Sim Savoeun would like to request a loan from Kiva to purchase pig food.

loans.use: To purchase pig food.

loans.name: Sili 1 Centre - Group 4

texts.en:
Faamalie and Aunuua from Sili 1, Savaii, are borrowing from SPBD for the first time. They both have undergone four weeks of training in business management and maintenance of a savings account, and have passed a written test on the SPBD principles: business, savings, weekly meetings, payments, and group guarantee. Over the next 52 weeks, they will support each other in their individual business development and in repaying their loans on time. 

Faamalie Fiti A., 67, widowed, has 10 children. She would like to enter the vegetable farming business. Her sons are already farmers. With her loan, Faamalie will purchase a knife, pesticides, a weed-killing sprayer, a spade, and a wheel barrow.    

Aunuua Fiu S., 37, is married and has 8 children. She has two years of experience in making handbags, a practice she learned from her sister-in-law. Her loan will be used to purchase plastic bags (clear and colored), materials, four scissors, and thread.

loans.use: Purchase of a weed-killing sprayer, machete, a spade, etc.

loans.name: Maota A Centre - Group 2

texts.en:
The three women pictured in the photograph live in Maota A on the island of Savaii. They are borrowing from SPBD for the first time. All of them have undergone four weeks of training in business management and maintenance of a savings account, and have passed a written test on the SPBD principles: business, savings, weekly meetings, payments, and group guarantee. Over the next 52 weeks, they will support each other in their individual business development and in repaying their loans on time. 

Ao U., 45, is married and has three children. For the last three years, she has been selling pancakes (round lumps of fried bread) at a local school. With the help of the loan, Ao will be able to open her own shop and increase the productivity of her business. She will purchase iron roofing, bags of cement, flour, bags of sugar, cooking oil, and cooking powder. Ao expects her weekly profit to be 230 Tala (~US$92).

Keke I., 36, is married and has two children.  She sells coconuts, bananas, pineapples, and other fruit at a flea market once a week. Her business is known for its wide variety, low prices, and good customer service. Keke's loan will be used to purchase materials to build a sales stall.

Naama U., 55, married, has 10 children. She has three years of experience in farming. Every day, she sells taro, bananas, coconuts, and other fruits and vegetables. With her loan, Naama will purchase 5 rolls of wire, 2 pliers, 2 gallons of water, chemicals, 2 machetes, and other farming equipment. She expects her weekly profit to be 200 Tala (~US$80).

loans.use: Purchase of building materials and farming equipment

loans.name: Bertha's Tuinome Group

texts.en:
Bertha is 30 years old and is a married woman with 1 child, age 5 years old. Bertha is a soft drinks seller and she started her business in 2004. Everyday she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealings in chicken sales and soft drinks sales.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 24 years old and is a married woman. Elizabeth is a food seller and she started her business in 2007. Everyday she works from 6am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $15 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Salelavalu Tai Centre - Group 4

texts.en:
Ave and Lei, two women from Salelavalu Tai, Savaii, are borrowing from SPBD for the first time. They both have undergone four weeks of training in business management and maintenance of a savings account, and have passed a written test on the SPBD principles: business, savings, weekly meetings, payments, and group guarantee. Over the next 52 weeks, they will support each other in their individual business development and in repaying their loans on time.

Ave L., 22, is married to a farmer. She has over three years of experience in selling goods at a flea market. She will use her loan to purchase sugar, salt, soap, potatoes, and other products for sale.

Lei I., 27, is married and has four children. She is starting a taro and banana sales business. She will grow the produce at her home and sell it at the Salelologa market. Lei is requesting a loan in order to purchase a weed-killing sprayer, pesticides, two bow knives, a spade, and a knife sharpener.

loans.use: Purchase of products for sale at a food stall

loans.name: Pech

texts.en: Mrs. Pech C., 43, is a grocer in Trapaing Angkrorng Village. She has six children, two of whom are working in construction and earn around US$5 a day, while the other two attend school. Pech's husband, Chum Peach, grows sugar palm in the village. Typically, Pech spends around US$52.20 per month on regular family expenses as well as wedding ceremonies and funerals. In order to cover the family's expenses, she would like to receive a loan to buy more groceries for sale in her store.

loans.use: To buy groceries to sell.

loans.name: Leone

texts.en: Leone A., 29, is married and has four children. She has over three  years of experience in growing taro and bananas. Leone sells her produce on Fridays. Her loan will be used to purchase a weed-killing sprayer, pesticides, fertilizer, four bow knives, five filings, and an axe.

loans.use: Purchase of a weed-killing sprayer and pesticides

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is 27 years old and is a married woman with 1 child, age 4 years old. She and her husband also take care of 1 other person, age 20 years old. Florence is a cloth seller and she started her business in 2006. Everyday she works from 6am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $45 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more cloth for her business.

loans.use: To buy more cloth for her business.

loans.name: Chou

texts.en:
Chou H. is 47 years old and is living in Kampong Cham province. She works raising pigs and cultivating a small rice paddy while her husband breeds ducks. They support their five children on a combined income of approximately $6.50 USD per day. The children stay at home and help their parents with the livestock.

With her loan she wants to purchase more ducks for her husband to breed. He takes their eggs and sells them at the local market to make the majority of his profit. Her husband, Sem Nung, and their small boy, appear in the photo.

loans.use: To buy ducks.

loans.name: Maota B Centre - Group 2

texts.en:
The four women pictured in the photograph are borrowing from SPBD for the first time. They all have undergone four weeks of training in business management and maintenance of a savings account, and have passed a written test on the SPBD principles: business, savings, weekly meetings, payments, and group guarantee. Over the next 52 weeks, they will support each other in their individual business development and in repaying their loans on time.

Faatele S. (35, married, 2 children) and Metu L. (45, married, 3 children) both grow and sell taro, a staple of the Samoan diet. They are requesting a loan to purchase a weed killer, pesticides, a bush knife, and a knife sharpener.

Aolipa T. (38, married, 8 children) makes pancakes (round lumps of fried bread) for sale five days a week. She will use her loan to purchase a stove, a fryer, yeast, sugar, and flour.

Me F. (46, married, 6 children) is starting a food stall at the Salelologa market. She will sell pancakes, chicken, rice, and curry. Her loan will be used to purchase a stove, sugar, a sack of flour, a sack of rice, a box of noodles, and wheat.

loans.use: Purchase of a weed killer, pesticides, a bush knife, etc.

loans.name: Chheang

texts.en:
Chheang Y. is a 32-year-old widow who is supporting her four young children with the revenue she generates from her small grocery store in Kampong Cham. She earns $10 USD per day from her store and from a small plot of farmland on which she grows rice and yams.

She wants to take a loan to buy groceries in bulk to save money and hopefully increase her family income. With any additional cash left over, she will purchase extra rice and yam seeds to plant next year.

loans.use: To buy a large stock of groceries.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is 35 years old and is a married woman with 2 children, ages four and one years old. She and her husband also take care of one other child, age 13 years old. Lucy owns a small food vendor store which she started in 2006. Everyday she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en:
Sophia is 23 years old and is a married woman with one child, age 3 months. She and her husband also take care of one other person, age 17 years old. Sophia is a tailor and she started her business in 2005. Everyday she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Touch

texts.en: Touch C. is a 31-year-old living in the province of Kampong Cham. She provides a valuable service to the villagers in her district by selling drinking water, which she pumps from the well right by her house. She earns $2 USD per day. Her husband, Kim Chun, is a mechanic and brings in $2.60 USD daily for the family. They are currently sending all three of their children to school full time. She wants to invest in a modern water pump to expedite the process of getting water each morning and, thus, to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase and install a water pump.

loans.name: Noeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Noeun C., 37, and her husband married in 1990. They have four children; one son and three daughters. One of their children weaves silk at home and the other four are students. The family lives on an Island on the Mekong River about twelve kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Noeun has been a weaver for over ten years. It’s a skill she learned from her neighbor. She sells her finished product to a middleman in the village who then sells them in Phnom Penh. Now she wants to start another business raising pigs. Her husband has been a boatmaker for thirteen years. 

She is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase materials for weaving silk and to buy baby pigs to raise.

loans.use: to purchase materials for weaving silk and to buy baby pigs to raise

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Salelologa Tumupapa Centre - Group 4

texts.en:
June and Vaivasu are two women from Salelologa Tumupapa, Savaii, who are borrowing from SPBD for the first time. They have both undergone four weeks of training in business management and maintenance of a savings account, and have passed a written test on the SPBD principles: business, savings, weekly meetings, payments and group guarantee.  Over the next 52 weeks, they will support each other in their individual business development and in repaying the loan on time. 

June F., 34, is married and has five children. Her husband owns a BBQ stall and grows crops. June will use her loan to help him purchase pesticides, a bush knife, rubber gloves and a knife sharpener. She expects to earn a weekly profit of 220 Tala (~US$108).    

Vaivasa S., 46, is married and has twelve children. She would like to purchase merchandise for her stall at the Salelologa market. Specifically, Vaivasa plans to buy a box of cups, a box of roll-on deodorant, and a box of boots.

loans.use: Purchase of a weed killer, pesticides, two bush knives, etc.

loans.name: Ngoun

texts.en:
Mrs. Ngoun N., age 35, lives with her husband and four children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She works selling corn and earns around $5 a day of profit. This couple has four children. One child is married and lives away from home and three others are students.

Her husband supports the family’s income as a boat driver. He was hired by a company to transfer sand from the river to the bank and he resells the sand to the people in the area. On average, he makes $3 a day. He aims to use the loan from Kiva to buy a small boat to ferry the sand and resell it directly to the people to gain more income for the family.

loans.use: To purchase a small boat

loans.name: Hul

texts.en: Hul S. is 30 years old and is a rice vendor in Kampong Cham. She makes $4 USD per day on average. Her husband, Nal Chamnan, is 35 years old and a local teacher. He earns $3 USD daily. They have only one child. She wants to invest in some farmland on which she and her husband will grow yams to supplement the family income.

loans.use: To buy farmland.

loans.name: Mwanahamis

texts.en:
Mwanahamis is 48 years old and is a married woman with one child, age 17 years old. She and her husband also take care of one other child, age 2 years old. Mwanhamis owns a small shop, which she started in 2007. Everyday she works from 8am to 4pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Kong

texts.en:
Mrs. Kong C., 45, and her husband married in 1984. They have two children; one son and one daughter. One of her children is employed full time. The family lives along the Mekong River about twelve kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Kong has been a weaver for twenty eight years. It’s a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village who will sell it in Phnom Penh.  Her husband has been a wooden house constructor for ten years. 

She is requesting a loan of $200 to to purchase materials for weaving silk.

loans.use: to purchase materials for weaving silk

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Velona

texts.en:
Velona is 28 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, ages 12,11, and 9 years old. Velona is a clothes seller and she started in 2007. Everyday she works from 8am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Hadia

texts.en:
Hadia is a 50 year old woman who works and lives in the Beirut suburbs.

Hadia sells clothes. She needs a loan to buy new merchandise so she can sustain and develop her business. Hadia is striving to provide for herself and to make ends meet.

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Ros

texts.en: Ros S. is 50 years of age and a widow. She works as part of the local staff at the Ministry of Transportation in Phnom Penh. She has a total of eight children. Three are married and five remain single and in the family home. Two of her children are currently employed as low-earning garment factory workers. She needs a loan to build a better house for her family. She also hopes to have enough left over to invest in pigs for breeding.

loans.use: To build a new house and purchase pigs for breeding.

loans.name: Sophan

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophan N., 63, and her husband have been married since 1972. They have six children; four sons and two daughters. Two of her children are married and live outside the family house. Of the other four children, three are employed full time and one is a student. The family lives along the Mekong River about twelve kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Sophan has been a weaver for forty years. It’s a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village who sells it in Phnom Penh.  Her husband has been a farmer since he was young. They are in their early 60s but are still strong enough to work. 


She is requesting a loan of $1200 to purchase materials for weaving silk and to repair parts of her house. Based on her business success so far, she will have no problem in repaying the loan to MAXIMA.

loans.use: to purchase materials for weaving silk and to repair parts of her house

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Sonia is a 35 year old woman who works and lives in the Beirut suburbs. She has 3 children.

Sonia sells home products. This is the first time she has applied for a loan at Al Majmoua. She needs a loan to buy new merchandise to sustain and develop her business.

loans.use: To buy merchandise

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Al Majmoua Lebanese Association for Development, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Yim

texts.en:
Yim T. is 38 years old and has lived with her family in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia for years. She and her husband work as construction workers building houses to earn approximately $8 a day of profit. They have an old mother that they need to take care of every day. They also have four children; two are students and the rest are employed. She will loan from Kiva to purchase wood to repair the house.

Yim T., her husband, and her elderly mother, are shown in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase wood to repair the house.

loans.name: Sokleng

texts.en:
Ms. Sokleng P., 26, is single and lives with her parents. She has two elder brothers and three elder sisters. All of them are married and live outside of the family house. The family lives along the Mekong River about twelve kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Ms. Sokleng has been a weaver for six years.  It’s a skill she learned from her neighbor. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village who then take sells it in Phnom Penh.

She is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase materials to weave silk and to repair part of her house.

loans.use: to purchase materials to weave silk and to repair her house

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Souad

texts.en:
Souad is a 43 year old woman who works and lives in the Beirut suburbs.

Souad is a tailor. This is the first time she has applied for a loan at Al Majmoua. She needs a loan to buy material to sustain and develop her tailoring business.

loans.use: To buy materials

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Al Majmoua Lebanese Association for Development, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Saom

texts.en:
Saom C. is 44 years old and works in construction in the capital city of Phnom Penh. He earns $6 USD per day while his wife, who appears in the photo, makes $2.50 USD per day working at a garment factory. Together they have three young children.

He needs a loan to buy a trailer that can be hooked to the back of a motorbike. With this trailer, he will be able to run a small taxi and goods transportation business after he finishes his construction work each day, raising his income substantially.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer.

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: Joy A. is a 39 year old mother of 3 that hails from Okoko Lagos State, Nigeria. Joy sells drinks and foodstuffs and she has been in her business for the past 10 years. Joy has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 3 years and she now requests  a loan of $875 to enable her to buy more foodstuffs and drinks for sale. She thanks you

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs and drinks for sale.

loans.name: Phalla

texts.en:
Mrs. Phalla K., 34, and her husband married in 1991. They have four children; two sons and two daughters.  All of their children are students. The family lives on an island on the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Phalla has been a weaver for twenty years. It’s a skill she learned from her sister. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village who then sells it in Phnom Penh. 

She is requesting a loan of $400 to purchase materials to weave silk.

loans.use: to purchase materials to weave silk

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Saida

texts.en:
Saida is a 38 year old woman who works and lives in the Beirut suburbs.

Saida does embroidery work and is also a nurse. This is the second time she has applied for a loan at Al Majmoua. She needs a loan to buy material to sustain and develop her embroidery business.

loans.use: To buy material

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Al Majmoua Lebanese Association for Development, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida is a 45 year old woman who works and lives in the Beirut suburbs. She has 3 children.

Aida sells clothes for a living. She needs a loan to buy new merchandise to sustain and develop her business.

loans.use: To buy merchandise

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Al Majmoua Lebanese Association for Development, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Satufia Satupaitea 2 Centre - Group 3

texts.en:
The five women pictured in the photograph are from Satufia Satupaitea of the island of Savaii. They are all borrowing from SPBD for the first time after undergoing four weeks of training in business management and maintenance of a savings account, and then passing a written test on the SPBD principles: business, savings, weekly meetings, payments and group guarantee. Over the next 52 weeks, they will support each other in their individual business development and in making repayments on time. 

Epenesa T., 59, is a widow and has 8 children. She has over three years of experience in baking pork cakes. She now sells them 6 days a week.  With her loan, Epenesa will purchase a new oven, flour, yeast, and other ingredients and utensils.  She expects that her weekly net cash flow will total 280 Tala (~US$112).  

Fanolua L., 40, is married and has three children. She grows taro and bananas, staples of the Samoan diet.  She is requesting a loan to purchase a weed killer, a bush knife, pesticides, and other equipment for farming.    

Keni T., 51, is married and has six children. She produces ice cakes (ice cream), and currently needs two bags of sugar, 500 plastic cups, a cooler and other supplies to start her own ice cream business. The good taste, clean environment, high quality and pure water set Keni apart from her competitors.  

Patisepa I., 46, is married and has six children. She has been selling taro and yams for over three years. Patisepa currently needs to buy a weed killer, pesticides, a bush knife, a knife filing (sharpener) as well as hire workers.  

Sofia Mao F., 47, is married and has three children. She produces fine mates, hats, Samoan bags and other handicrafts. She is requesting a loan to purchase a weed killer, pesticides, a knife, and to hire workers. She plans to sell her handicrafts in the village five days a week.

loans.use: Purchase a weed killer, pesticides, knives, etc.

loans.name: Najwa

texts.en: Najwa is a 63 year old woman who works and lives in the Beirut suburbs. She has a grocery shop and is also a tailor. She needs a loan to buy merchandise to sustain and develop her grocery store.

loans.use: To buy merchandise

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Al Majmoua Lebanese Association for Development, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Irene's Starehe Group

texts.en:
Irene is 36 years old and is married woman with 3 children, ages 15,11, and 7 years old. She and her husband also take care of 3 other children, ages15,11 and 7 years old. Irene is a clothes seller (vintage and sheets) and started in 2005. Everyday she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $225 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in cloth sales, cement sales, and food vending.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Ruos

texts.en:
Ruos S. E. is 35 years old and makes her living selling a variety of small freshwater clams in a Kampong Cham market. She earns $2 USD per day. Her husband, Tuy Sophat, runs a goods transport service making $5 USD per day. Both of their two children are currently enrolled in school.

She wants to invest in a large stock of cashew nuts so she can sell thE. for profit once market prices go up.

loans.use: To buy cashew nuts in bulk.

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mrs. Mao P., age 51, is a widow who has been selling clothes in a busy market since 2000. On average, she makes around $2.60 a day of profit. She has nine children, six of who are married and live away from home, and three others, who are employed by garment factory with a salary of $80 each a month.

Mrs. Yem Thea is requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase wood to repair the house, especially the leaking roof.

loans.use: To purchase wood to repair the house.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 39 year old man who works and lives with his family in the Beirut suburbs. Ali has one child.

Ali sells paint for a living. This is the first time he has applied for a loan at Al Majmoua. He needs a loan to buy merchandise to sustain and develop his business.

loans.use: To buy merchandise for his paint shop

loans.name: Uth

texts.en: Uth S. is a 46-year-old housewife residing in Kampong Cham. She stays home and cares for the three children still living in the family home. Two of her five children are employed as garment factory workers. She wants to purchase a motorbike for her husband so he can save time on his commute to work at various construction projects.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for the commute to work.

loans.name: Sabrine

texts.en:
Sabrine is a 22 year old young woman who works and lives in the Beirut suburbs.

Sabrine makes handicrafts. This is the second time she has applied for a loan at A. Majmoua. She needs a loan to buy materiA. to sustain and develop her business.

loans.use: To buy material

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Al Majmoua Lebanese Association for Development, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Halima's Tuungane Group

texts.en:
Halima is 28 years old and is married with one child, age 11. Halima has been a charcoal seller since 2004. Everyday, she works from 6am to 4pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $215 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal for her business. She will share this loan with her sub-group member, Mwanawetu, who has business dealing in food vending.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Thy

texts.en:
Mrs. Thy C. and her husband, Mr. Phoung Ya, married in 1972. They have six children; two sons and four daughters. All of their children are employed full time. The family lives on an island on the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Thy has been a weaver for over one year. It’s a skill she learned from her neighbor. She sells her finished product to a middleman in the village who then sells it in Phnom Penh. Besides weaving, she buys recycled materials in her village to resell. She started this business two years ago. Her husband raises cows.

Thy is requesting a loan of $300 to purchase materials for silk weaving and buy recycled materials to resell.

loans.use: to purchase materials for silk weaving and buy recycling materials to resell

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Abbas

texts.en:
Abbas is a 27 year old man who works and lives in the Beirut suburbs.

Abbas is a barber. This is the first time he has applied for a loan at Al Majmoua. He needs a loan to buy material to sustain and develop his barber shop.

loans.use: To buy materials

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Al Majmoua Lebanese Association for Development, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Ol

texts.en: Ol S. is 35 years of age and runs a small tailoring shop from her home in Kampong Cham. Since 1999, she has also worked hard selling fish in the market on the side. Between these two jobs, she still only earns $1 USD per day. Her husband, Hean Eith, is a local fisherman and rice farmer. Together they have four children. She has a younger sister also living in their family home who works in a nearby garment factory. She wants to invest in new, more efficient nets for her husband to fish with and, thereby, expand her fish selling business.

loans.use: Tp buy fishing nets.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more wine, juice and drinks for sale

loans.name: Sroin

texts.en:
Mrs. Sroin K., 43, and her husband married in 1982. They have two sons, one is a fisherman and the other is in school. The family lives along the MeK. River, about twelve kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Sroin and her husband have been farmers since they were young. They grow rice in their farm in the village.  She is requesting a loan of $250 to purchase fishing nets for her son.

loans.use: to purchase fishing nets for her son

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Jesca's Wema Group

texts.en:
Jesca is 33 years old and is married with three children, aged 8, 6 and 1. Jesca is a used clothes seller, she started in 2007. Everyday, she works from 9.30am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $110 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her sub-group members, Pili and Nelia, who have a salon and a food vending business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Nora

texts.en: Mrs. Nora E. comes from Afro media Lagos State Nigeria. She sells foodstuffs, provisions and drinks. She acquired the skill for 5 years and has been in this business since the year 2000. Nora is 39 years of age, has 4 children and has being borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 3 years. She requests the sum of $1200 to enable her to buy more provisions, foodstuffs and drinks for sale. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs and drinks for sale

loans.name: Srun

texts.en: Srun M. is a 32-year-old widow working for a tobacco company in the province of Kampong Cham. She earns $1.50 USD per day. She has two sons, both of whom work to help support the family. One is a construction worker and the other is a mechanic. She wants to purchase a better set of tools for her son working as a mechanic so he can gain more business.

loans.use: To purchase new tools.

loans.name: Soklin

texts.en:
Mrs. Soklin L., 40, and her husband married in 1991. They have three children; two sons and one daughter. All of them are students. The family lives along National Road Number Two which is about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Soklin has been a scarf weaver since she was eighteen years old. It’s a skill she learned from her parents. She sells her finished products to wholesalers in Phnom Penh.  Her husband is a policeman. She hopes that her business can support her children to study at university.

She is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase cotton for weaving scarves.

loans.use: to purchase cotton for weaving scarves

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Daung

texts.en: Daung Y. is a 22 year old mother with one little child. She owns a plot of farmland and has been growing rice since 2000.  She currently earns about $1 a day.  Her husband is named Sem Sren and he is a 27 year old construction worker who builds houses. Normally he makes about $5 a day. Their child is just two years old. They would like to borrow $125 through Kiva  to purchase cow to assist with their farm work and thereby increase their income.

loans.use: To purchase cow to help with farm work.

loans.name: Saroeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Saroeun C. (pictured with her daughter) is a widow with six children; two sons and four daughters. Both of her sons are married and live outside the family home. Three of her daughters work in a garment factory and other one weaves silk at home. The family lives on an island on the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Saroeun has been a weaver since 1965. It’s skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished product to a middle man in the village who then sells it in Phnom Penh. 
Mrs. Saroeun is requesting a loan of $300 to repair some parts of her house.

loans.use: to repair some parts of her house

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Rehema's Cloth Sales Group

texts.en:
Rehema is 39 years old and is married with three children, ages 16, 14 and 11. Rehema is a batik cloth seller, a business she started in 2007. Everyday, she works from 8am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more materials for her business. She will share this loan with her sub-group member, Naima , who has business dealing in charcoal sales.

loans.use: To buy more materials for her batik business.

loans.name: Rabia's Group

texts.en:
I am Rabia B. and I have five kids: two boys and three girls. I reside with my family in Borewala, Pakistan. My elder kids could not finish school because of our poor economic condition, but now we are better off and have enrolled all three of our girls in school. I have been sewing clothes on order since my teens. One of my sons works at a local food market. He sells fruits there. We need a loan so that he can purchase fruits and vegetables in bulk, so that our income can increase.

The following are my group members with their businesses: Nazira B. is borrowing for her milk business; Khursheed B. needs to expand her wood business; and Sajida B. wants to buy a sewing machine. Please help all of us by lending us the loan as quickly as possible. We shall never forget your assistance.

loans.use: To expand the fruits and vegetables business and to fund the other businesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Selina's Raha Group

texts.en:
Selina is 36 years old and is married with five children. Selina owns a small grocery, which she started in 2007. Everyday, she works from 10.30am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $190 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her sub-group member, Zuhura, who has a food vending business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Heng

texts.en:
Mr. Heng K. (picture with his wife) married in 1987.  He has four children; two sons and two daughters. Both of his daughters work in a garment factory.  One of his sons is a mason and the younger one is in school. The family lives about twelve kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mr. Heng has three years of experience constructing wooden houses. He learned this skill from his brother-in-law. His wife sells fruit in the village. She purchases the fruit from the market in Phnom Penh and resells it.

Mr. Heng is requesting a loan of $1000 to repair his house and purchase fruit for his wife to resell.

loans.use: to purchase fruit to resell and repair his house

loans.name: Damin

texts.en: Damin K. is 40 years of age, married with 2 children,  and hails from Ayetoro Lagos State Nigeria. She sells drinks in her community; this was a business she learned for some years. She has been operating her business for the past 8 years and requests the sum of $1200 to enable her to buy more crates of drinks for sale. The loan will improve her business.

loans.use: To buy more drinks for sale

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en: Gladys A. lives in her local community in Igbaye Lagos State Nigeria. At 38 years of age, with 4 children, she has the goal of pulling her family above poverty. As a petty trader she travels to main Lagos where she buy shoes, clothes, plastic rubber and baby items that she sell in her community. Gladys has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 4 years and she has being in her business since the year 2000. She requests the sum of $875 to enable her to buy more shoes, clothes, baby items and plastic rubbers for her business which will be able to serve her customers better

loans.use: To buy more clothes and shoes for sale

loans.name: Osadara

texts.en: Osadara O.'s  business is distinguished from other shops because of her colorful arrangement of food stuffs, ranging from thin tomatoes, sachet water etc. She also has a deep freezer which is used for selling frozen food like turkey, fish and chickens which has allowed her to meet the demand of her numerous customers. She acquired the skill of trading for 6 months. Osadara has being borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 3 years and she has beeen in her business since 2007. She requests the sum of $1200 to enable her to buy an additional deep freezer and generator so that she can serve her customers better.

loans.use: To buy one Freezer and one Generator

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen Ofrabor is a petty trader in her community; she is 28 years of age, with 2 children. Helen sells foodstuffs, ranging from seed tomatoes, yam, pepper, plantain, egg, oil and onions. Her business is demanding because the major market is far from the community. She sells from 8am until nightime  Monday through Sunday. The demanding work schedule allows her to satisfy the demand of her customers and to maximize profit. She hails from Okoko Lagos State Nigeria. Helen has being borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 3 years and has been operating her business since 2001. She is requesting a loan of $450 to enable her to buy more foodstuffs in order for her to maximize profits.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Sughran's Group

texts.en:
My name is Sughran S.. I am a mother of five: four boys and one girl. Two of my kids are married. The others are working. I reside with my family in a brick mud house in Borewala, a small town in Pakistan. My husband is a jeweler. He runs a small shop in a nearby market. He has been in this trade for the last twenty years. Currently, we need a loan to improve our business.

My group fellows who require loans for their businesses are: Suriya B., who is borrowing for her grocery store; Rafia B., who will buy items for her sanitary store with her share of loan; and Zahida P., who is borrowing for her milk business.

loans.use: To expand the family's jewelry business and to fund the other businesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Tahira's Group

I have been joined in my loan group by a few other women. They are: Naseem B., who runs a boutique; Jameela B., who sews clothes on order; Fazeelat B.’s husband, who is a blacksmith; and Sajida P., who wants to start a stitching training centre in her community.

loans.use: To buy required items for the beauty salon and to fund the other businesses

loans.name: Souadou

texts.fr:
Souadou B., age 45, is married and the mother of eight children and is taking care of one. She is a member of the village bank of Diaobé. She trades in fruit and peanut butter, which she produces from the seeds that she buys at the Diaobé marketplace. Her business enables her to have an income and to raise a few goats. To promote this economic activity, Souadou is requesting a loan that will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

Souadou B., 45 ans, mariée, mère de 08 enfants et 01 en charge est membre du banc villageois de Diaobé. Elle fait un commerce de fruit et de pâte d’arachide qu’elle produit avec la transformation des graines d’arachide qu’elle achète au marché de Diaobé. Son activité lui permet d’avoir des revenus et de faire un petit élevage de caprins. Pour promouvoir cette activité économique, Souadou sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de 6 mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use: To buy fruit and peanuts

loans.name: Sherifat

texts.en: Sherifat J.’s sells different types of goods ranging from leather and rubber sandals, cosmetics, weavon and hair attachments. Sherifat J. is 32 years of age, with 2 kids, and, with her facial expression, one can deduce that she is happy with her business. She has been in her business since 2005 and requests the sum of $450 to enable her buy more rubber and leather sandals for sale. She thanks you.

loans.name: Patience

She hails from Okoko Lagos State Nigeria. Patience sells provisions and drinks and has been in her business since 2001. She requests a loan of $450 to enable her to buy more provisions and drinks. She intends on adding to her business with the sale of foodstuffs. This will be made possible on the receipt of Kiva loan. She thanks you.

Sounkarou Kébé, 30 ans, divorcée, 04 enfants en charge est membre très dynamique du comité de gestion du banc villageois de Diaobé et fidèle à Caurie depuis cinq ans et demi. loans.name: Madeleine

texts.fr:
Madeleine B. is married and takes care of five children. She is a member of the village bank of Femmes Catholiques de Vélingara in the Kolda region. She buys fish, drinks, peanut butter, and monkey bread (baobab fruit) and then resells them. She also sells pork, which she raises. The income drawn from her business enables her to improve her family's living conditions. This 9th loan that she is requesting will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

Madeleine B., mariée, 05 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois de Femmes Catholiques de Vélingara dans la région de Kolda. Elle achète et revend du poisson, de la boisson, de la pate d'arachide et pain de singe (fruit du baobab). Madeleine vend aussi des porcs qu'elle élève.. Les revenus tirés de son commerce lui permettent d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille. Ce 9ème prêt qu’elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de 6 mois en une seule échéance.
