loans.name: Irma

texts.es:
Irma and Ángel are a very united couple with lots of innumerable projects for their lives; ever since they were small they have been tied to agriculture and ranching, work that they inherited from their respective parents. Now with their knowledge and experience that they have acquired through their many years in this noble activity they are acheiving and increase in their quality of life and that of their little daughter Dianita, the fruit of their love. Irma and her beloved husband have had eight years of marital bliss, and in this time, with hard work and dedication they have managed to increase the number of cattle they have. Thanks to the care and devotion they provide, these also provide a fair quantity of milk, with which they create delicious cheeses. But in these icy seasons, Irma and Ángel find themselves in hard times. They don't have enough fodder for their many animals, and so they turn to all of you to request a loan to purchase more well-balanced foods.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer.

Irma y Ángel, es una pareja de esposos muy unida con innumerables proyectos para sus vidas; ambos desde muy niños han estado ligados a la actividad agrícola y ganadera, labores que heredaron de sus respectivos padres y que ahora con sus conocimientos y la experiencia adquirida durante muchos años en esta noble actividad están logrando incrementar su calidad de vida y la de su pequeña niña Dianita quien nació fruto de su amor.Irma y su querido esposo tienen 8 años de feliz matrimonio, en ese período con sumo trabajo y dedicación lograron aumentar poco a poco la cantidad de sus vaquitas, que gracias a los cuidados y a la dedicación que les brindan corresponden generosamente con una buena cantidad de leche, que luego de ordeñarlas con mucho cariño proceden a vender para la elaboración de deliciosos quesos.Pero por estas temporadas de helada Irma y Ángel se ven envueltos en grandes dificultades, no cuentan con suficiente forraje para alimentar a sus generosos animalitos, es por ello que recurre a vosotros para solicitarte un préstamo para adquirir mayor cantidad de comida balanceada.

loans.use: Purchase a balanced diet for their many cattle

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Microfinanzas PRISMA - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Fortunato

texts.es:
Fortunato is a man that loves and values nature. Ever since he was a young man, he has dedicated himself to agriculture and ranching. His economic situation did now allow him to pursue higher education, but he has always tried and keeps on trying to exert himself to improve his quality of life. In this way, he hopes to provide the opportunity to become professionals to his three youngest children. With love, patience, and the support of his family, every morning Fortunato dedicates himself to caring for this cattle to later process their nutritious milk into delicious cheeses to sell in the city of Ayaviri.

In addition to this work, he dedicates himself to agriculture, and activity that he has managed to keep up and improve his quality of life. Now, due to the inclement weather, Fortunato wishes to look ahead and purchase fodder to feed his calves and lambs. Consider that with this investment, he will have the assurance of food for his little animals during these hard times. Your indispensible help will allow Fortunato to face these difficult times.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer.

Fortunato es un hombre que ama y valora la naturaleza, desde muy niño se ha dedicado a la agricultura y ganadería, sus posibilidades económicas no le permitieron seguir estudios superiores, pero ha siempre tratado y sigue tratando de esforzarse para mejorar su calidad de vida y así darles la oportunidades de convertirse en profesionales de éxito a sus 3 menores hijos.Con mucho cariño y paciencia durante todas las mañanas con el apoyo de toda su familia don Fortunato se dedica a ordeñar sus vaquitas para luego procesar su nutriente leche y elaborar con dedicación y paciencia deliciosos quesos para venderlos en la ciudad de Ayaviri. Adicionalmente a esta labor se dedica a la agricultura, actividad con la que esta logrando sostener y mejorar su calidad de vida.Pero ahora, viendo las inclemencias del tiempo Fortunato desea prevenir y comprar forraje para la alimentación de sus becerritas y corderitos, considera que con esta inversión tendrá asegurada la provisión de sus animalitos para tiempos difíciles. Tu indispensable aporte permitirá afrontar difíciles momentos a don Fortunato.

loans.use: Purchase fodder to feed his calves during this scarce season

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Microfinanzas PRISMA - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Marie Joseph

texts.fr:
Marie Joseph B., age 46, has one child and has been a member of the village bank of Femmes Catholiques de Vélingara for four years. Her business consists of selling ice and ice cream that she makes with monkey bread (baobab fruit) and sugar. Her income enables her to improve family living conditions by contributing her children's healthcare and schooling. Marie is requesting a loan that will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

Marie Joseph B., 46 ans, 01 enfant est membre du banc villageois des Femmes Catholiques de Vélingara depuis quatre ans. Ses activités consistent à vendre de la glace et des crèmes glaces qu'elle prépare avec le pain de de singe (fruit du baobab) et du sucre.Ses revenus lui permettent d' amélioration les conditions de vie de la famille en contribuant aux soins de santé et à la scolarité des enfants. Marie sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use: To buy sugar and monkey bread

loans.name: La Economica Group

texts.en:
Aura Peguero is a member of the community of “La Econimica” in San Pedro de Macoris. This is the third loan that she and many of the other women in this group of 15 are applying for with Esperanza. As an organization, it is our hope that these women will continue participating in our programs until they have accomplished their goals. Aura is an amazing example and leader in her community, and has proven once again the sustainable benefits of micro-finance. She has four children (13, 14, 16, and 17) and runs a small grocery store near her home. Aura wants to use this loan to continue buying more merchandise for her “colmado.” One day she hopes to have saved enough money to buy a larger and nicer building to run her store out of. Her other priorities are providing for her children and fixing up her home.

On behalf of Esperanza, and this group of women, we want to thank you for your continued support and generosity!

About Group Loans: In a group loan, each member of the group receives an individual loan but is part of a group of individuals bound by a group guarantee. Under this arrangement, each member of the group supports one another and is responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise for her store: rice, beans, crackers, sugar, oil, etc.

loans.name: Yama De Amor Group

texts.en:
Yolanda lives in the city of San Pedro de Macoris, and is part of a bank of 20 women from her community. She has two children and in addition to caring for her household, she runs a bakery/bread shop. She wants to use this loan to buy more flour, sugar, and butter in order to always have a supply on hand. Her business has grown significantly since she took out her first loan with Esperanza six months ago, and she wants to continue expanding her business. Her favorite foods are natural juice, rice, beans, and meat. In the future Yolanda wants to continue expanding her business so that she can help other women in her community.

These six women are part of a larger Bank of Hope, and they have grown very close over the course of their first loan. They are all excited for the opportunity to take out a second loan, and appreciate the support from Kiva lenders. On behalf of everyone, we want to thank you for your support and encouragement!

About Group Loans: In a group loan, each member of the group receives an individual loan but is part of a group of individuals bound by a group guarantee. Under this arrangement, each member of the group supports one another and is responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

loans.use: To buy more flour, sugar, and butter for her bread shop.

loans.name: Pablo Emilio

texts.es:
Mr. Pablo Emilio M. N. is the man wearing a red shirt and blue cap. He is a 63-year-old man from the city of Bluefields. He is married to Mrs. Virginia López, with whom his has 3 adult kids who have received an education thanks to the income generated from Mr. M.’s business. He has been a photographer for over 45 years. His customers are people of all ages who prefer him because he gives specialized in-home services. He currently needs to buy 30 boxes of Polaroid film—at $16.00 per box—and 65 rolls of film—at $6.00 per roll. With this investment, he will be able to meet his customers’ demands.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

El Sr. Pablo Emilio M. N. es el que se encuentra vestido con camisa roja y gorra azul, es originario de la ciudad de Bluefields, tiene 63 años de edad, esta casado con la Sra. Virginia López ambos tienen 3 hijos mayores de edad, que han obtenido sus estudios por el ingreso del negocio del Sr. M. quien tiene más de 45 años de ser fotógrafo, sus clientes son hombres y mujeres de todas las edades que lo prefieren por brindar servicio especializado y a domicilio, en estos momentos necesita comprar 30 cajas de polaroid a $16.00 dólares cada caja y 65 rollo películas a $6.00 dólares cada rollo con esta inversión podrá satisfacer sus demandas.

loans.use: Purchase 30 boxes of Polaroid film and 65 rolls of film

payments.comment: La cuota real es de $ 133.33 dólares.
La cuota real es de $ 133.33 dólares.

loans.name: Gabriela

texts.es:
Mrs. Gabriela S. decided to open a general store due to financial necessity, since her partner’s income was not sufficient to cover the family expenses.

She started this business a year ago using the money she had saved, initially offering only a few goods. Currently, the business generates good profits.

It is for this reason that she is now requesting a loan of $475.00 USD for six months in order to purchase merchandise and a display cabinet, and give maintenance to her refrigerators, thus allowing her to offer her customers better service. She fully hopes that she will obtain her goals with your support.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Gabriela decidió emprender un negocio de venta de Abarrotes por necesidad económica, ya que los ingresos de su cónyuge no eran suficientes para los gastos familiares.

Inicio el negocio hace un año con el dinero que en su momento ahorro, empezando con poca mercancía, actualmente el negocio ya genera buenos ingresos.

Es por tal motivo que ahora solicita de un crédito de US $475 a 6 meses, para la comprar mercancía, compra una vitrina y darle mantenimiento a los refrigeradores, y así poder brindar un mejor servicio a sus clientes, ella tiene todas las esperanzas de que con el apoyo de ustedes lo obtendrá.

loans.use: Refrigerator maintenance and purchase of merchandise and display cabinet

loans.name: Enriqueta

texts.es:
Ms. Enriqueta V. started her cosmetics business 14 years ago. She started out helping a friend to sell, and that is how she would generate the extra income that helped her financially with the household expenses. Upon realizing that this activity was lucrative, she decided to work directly for those cosmetics companies with the aim of earning more income. Today, her business has prospered, and she has been able to cover her financial expenses.

She is currently requesting a loan of $400.00 US for 6 months in order to purchase merchandise at wholesale prices, thus giving her customers better service. She fully trusts that she will obtain that loan with Kiva’s support.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Ella inicio su negocio de Venta de cosméticos hace 14 años, primero ayudándole a una amiga a vender y así recibía algo de ingresos extras, que le ayudaba económicamente con los gastos de su hogar. Al darse cuenta que le estaba yendo bien decidió hacer el trato directamente con las líneas de cosméticos, esto con la finalidad de obtener mas ganancias, hoy en día le ha ido muy bien y ha podido salir adelante con los gastos económicos.

Ahora solicita de un crédito de US $400 a 6 meses, para la compra de mercancía a precio de mayoreo, y así dar mejor servicio a sus clientes, ella confía plenamente que con el apoyo de Kiva obtendrá su crédito.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Maria De La Luz

texts.es:
María de la Luz started her business as a way of generating additional income in her spare time. This activity allowed her to cover both her personal expenses and her family’s financial necessities, since she has a 14-year-old son who is currently studying, and her husband’s wages could not cover his studies.

For this reason, she started selling cosmetics 20 years ago. Because of her efforts, she has done well, but she would like to expand her clientele and form groups of women who can sell products for her.

She is currently requesting a loan of $775.00 USD, which she will repay in 6 months, for the purchase of merchandise and display shelves. She fully hopes that she will get what she needs with your support.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

María de la Luz inicio su negocio como una forma de generar más ingresos en su tiempo libre, para así poder solventar gastos personales y las necesidades económicas de su familia, ya que tiene un hijo de 14 años que se encuentra estudiando y con el sueldo de su esposo no pueden solventar estos gastos.

Por tal motivo inicio en la venta de cosméticos hace 20 años y debido a su esfuerzo le ha ido muy bien, pero ella desea seguir incrementado su cartera de clientes y formar grupos de señoras que le vendan productos.

Actualmente esta solicitando un crédito por US $775 que pagara en 6 meses, para la compra de mercancía y compra de exhibidores. Ella tiene toda la esperanza que con tu apoyo lo obtendrá.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise and display shelves

loans.name: Minerva

texts.es:
Minerva started a cosmetic sales business after her husband died. She was left in charge of the household, as well as responsible for the care of one of her children who has disabilities. She needs to dedicate a large portion of her time to the child’s care, and this includes providing the child with therapy, which generates additional costs. For these reasons Minerva began her own cosmetics business, since she had no other income to be able to pay her expenses. As an extra activity Minerva also irons and washes the clothes of her neighbors, and from that she obtains additional income.

Now Minerva is requesting a loan of $300 U.S. that will be repaid in 5 months in order to purchase merchandise. She is confident that with the support of KIVA she will be able to move forward.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

Minerva inicio el negocio de venta de cosméticos cuando falleció su esposo, ella quedo con la responsabilidad del hogar, y la manutención de uno de sus hijos ya que tiene discapacidad y le tiene que dedicar la mayor parte de su tiempo además que recibe terapias las cuales le generan un costo. Por tal motivo emprendió su negocio de venta de cosméticos ya que ella no tenía ningún ingreso para poder solventar estos gastos. Como una actividad extra también se dedica a planchar y lavar ropa a sus vecinos, y de ahí obtiene otro ingreso.

Ahora solicita un crédito por US $300 que pagara en 5 meses, para la compra de mercancía. Ella confía que con el apoyo de Kiva lograra progresar

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Teresa

texts.es:
I need to put up a wall around my home and also to repair a window since it is in bad condition and therefore I cannot use the room. I am asking for $1,000 US in order to put up a wall and repair the window.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

Tengo al necesidad de levantar una barda enseguida de mi vivenda y también reparar una ventana ya que esta en malas condiciones y asi no puedo habitar el cuarto" Solicito $ 1,000.00 dlls para levantar la barda y reparar la ventana.

loans.use: To put up a wall and repair a window at my house

loans.name: Manuela

texts.es:
The patio at my house is linked to the patio of the house right behind ours. I would like to put up a wall between the two patios in order to give my home more privacy and also to make it more secure for my two children. I am asking for $600 US in order to put up a wall around the patio of my house.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

"El patio de mi casa esta pegado con el patio de la casa de atras, asi es que me gustaria levantar una barda para darle más privacidad a mi vivienda y sobre todo más seguridad para mis hijos" Solicito $ 600.00 dlls para levantar la barda del patio de mi casa.

loans.use: To put up a wall around the patio of her house

loans.name: Brenda Eloisa

texts.es:
I have run a store out of my home for the past year.  I am the one who tends to the store all day since my husband also works in a factory in order to help cover expenses.  I would like to invest in my business in order to have more merchandise to offer my clients.   I am requesting $500 U.S. to invest in my business.
Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.
Tengo una tienda en mi vivienda desde hace 1 año, yo soy la que esta atendiendo todo el dia ya que mi esposo también trabaja en una maquiladora para ayudar con los gastos, me gustaria invertir en mi negocio para tener más mercancia que ofrecerles a mis clientes". Solicito $ 500.00 dlls para inverir en mi negocio.

loans.use: To invest in my business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación para la Vivienda Progresiva (FVP), a partner of CHF International - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Marilu's Group

texts.es:
Delia, Alicia, and Marilu have been part of the “Banco Lirio” for 2, 1, and 2 years respectively.

Delia is married, 39 years old and has two daughters, 14 and 1 years old. Delia has a small general store at her home where she has been selling vegetables and groceries for the past 2 years. Alicia is a single mother, 45 years old and has 1 son, she has a bakery inherited from her mother, she sells at the market “Nery García” and she also travels to local markets weekly. Marilu lives with a partner, she is 22 years old and has a 3 year-old daughter, she sells firewood from home. She also sells typical “chichas” (maize liquor) from the area during holiday seasons.

Delia, Alicia, and Marilu need loans for 400 soles, 400 soles, and 800 soles to be invested in the purchase of groceries, rice, sugar, flour, firewood, and maize. Delia’s, Alicia’s, and Marilu’s dreams are for their children to become professionals, build their houses with lasting material, buy land and increase their capital.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer.

Delia, Alicia y Marilu pertenecen al Banco Comunal Lirio hace 2, 1, 2 años respectivamente.

Delia es casada, tiene 39 años y 2 hijas de 14 y 1 año, Delia tiene una pequeña bodega en su casa donde vende verduras, abarrotes, actividad que realiza hace 2 años. Por otro lado Alicia es madre soltera, tiene 45 años y 1 hijo, Alicia tiene una panadería que fue heredado por su mamá, sus ventas los realiza en el mercado Nery García y también viaja a las ferias semanalmente. Mientras que Marilu es conviviente, tiene 22 años y 1 hija de 3 años, Marilu vende leña en su casa. Además en épocas de fiestas vende chichas típicas de la zona.

Delia, Alicia y Marilu necesitan préstamos de 400 soles, 400 soles, 800 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de abarrotes, arroz, azúcar, harina, leña y maíz. Los sueños de Delia, Alicia y Marilu son que sus hijos sean profesionales, construir su casa con material noble, comprar un terreno y tener más capital.

loans.use: Delia, Alicia, and Marilu need loans for 400, 400, and 800 soles to purchase groceries, rice, sugar, flour, firewood, and maize.

loans.name: Maria's Group

texts.es:
Megy, Magdalena, and Maria have been members of the “Banco Comunal Lirio” for 4 months, 4 months, and 2 years respectively.

Megy lives with a partner, she is 28 years old and has 1 son, she is a baker, using her mother’s oven and selling at the market “F. Vivanco”. She also has a grocery store at home. Magdalena is married, 53 years old and has 4 children. She sells beverages at her house. She also has a stand at “la Picota” hill where she sells typical food and beverages. Maria is married, 40 years old and has 6 children, she travels to the different markets in the region where she buys small animals and cereal which she sells at the central market of the town of Ayacucho and at the cattle market,

Megy, Magdalena, and Maria need loans of 600 soles, 1600 soles, and 800 soles to be invested in buying rice, eggs, flour, beer, soft drinks, small animals, and cereals. The dreams of Megy, Magdalena, and Maria are to have their own house, own oven, a hall for special events, lodgings, and move ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer.

Megy, Magdalena y Maria pertenecen al Banco Comunal Lirio hace 4 meses, 4 meses, 2 años respectivamente.

Megy es conviviente, tiene 28 años y 1 hijo, Megy es panificadora, actividad que realiza en el horno D. su mamá, sus ventas lo realiza en el mercado F. Vivanco. Además Megy tiene una tienda D. abarrotes en su casa. Por otro lado Magdalena es casada, tiene 53 años y 4 hijos, Magdalena venD. bebidas en su casa. Además Magdalena tiene un recreo en el cerro la Picota donD. venD. comidas típicas y bebidas. Mientras que Maria es casada, tiene 40 años y 6 hijos, Maria viaja a las diferentes ferias D. la región donD. compra animales menores, cereales que venD. en el mercado central D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho y la feria D. animales.

Megy, Magdalena y Maria necesitan préstamos D. 600 soles, 1600 soles, 800 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra D. arroz, huevo, harina, cerveza, gaseosa, animales menores y cereales. Los sueños D. Megy, Magdalena y Maria son tener casa propia, horno propio, un salón D. eventos, hospedaje y salir adelante.

loans.use: Megy, Magdalena, and Maria need loans of 600, 1600, and 800 soles to purchase rice, eggs, flour, beer, soft drinks, small animals, and cereals.

loans.name: Marilu's Group

texts.es:
Raquel, Doris, and Marilu have been members of “Banco Comunal Guadalupe” for 6 months.

Raquel is a single mother, she is 26 years old and has a 4 year-old son. She sells cosmetics from catalogues and she also helps out from time to time at her aunt’s store. Doris lives with a partner, she is 28 years old and has 2 children. She owns a store where she has been selling groceries and vegetables for the past 6 months. Marilu lives with a partner, she is 37 years old and has 4 children. Together with her husband she sells jackets and leather shoes. Their products are bought at the town of Puno and Lima and sold in stores and institutions at the town of Ayucucho. They also own a shoe repair workshop.

Raquel, Doris, and Marilu need loans of 600 soles, 1000 soles, and 1000 soles to invest in the purchase of cream, perfume, talc, shampoo, cologne, sugar, pasta, cooking oil, salt, tuna fish, jackets, shoes, and material for the shoe repair. It is their dream to make their businesses grow, to increase stock, that their children become professionals and to own a shoe store.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer.

Raquel, Doris y Marilu pertenecen al Banco Comunal Guadalupe hace 6 meses.

Raquel es madre soltera, tiene 26 años y 1 hijo de 4 años, Raquel vende cosméticos por catálogos. Además Raquel en algunas ocasiones ayuda en la tienda de su tía. Por otro lado Doris es conviviente, tiene 28 años y 2 hijos, Doris tiene una tienda donde vende abarrotes, verduras, actividad que realiza hace 6 meses. Mientras que Marilu es conviviente, tiene 37 años y 4 hijos, Marilu junto a su esposo venden casacas y zapatos de cuero, sus productos son adquiridos de la ciudad de Puno y Lima y son vendidos a tiendas, instituciones de la ciudad de Ayacucho. Además junto a su esposo tienen una renovadora de calzados.

Raquel, Doris y Marilu necesitan préstamos de 600 soles, 1000 soles, 1000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de cremas, perfumes, talcos, champú, colonias, azúcar, fideo, aceite, sal, atún, casacas, zapatos y materiales para su renovadora. Los sueños de Raquel, Doris y Marilu son salir adelante con su negocio, surtir su negocio, que sus hijos sean profesionales y tener una tienda de calzados.

loans.use: Raquel, Doris, and Marilu need loans of 600, 1000, and 1000 soles to purchase cream, perfume, talc, shampoo, cologne, sugar, pasta, cooking oil, salt, tuna fish, jackets, shoes, and material for shoe repair.

loans.name: Delia Tereza's Group

texts.es:
Lie, Delia and Yanira belong to the Guadalupe Communal Bank since 6 months ago. Lie is convivial, she is 25 years old and has 2 children. Some time ago Lie used to sell tuberss and 2 months ago she decided to change her business and sell cereals instead. She buys the products in Andahuaylas and sells it at the Nery Garcia market. Along with her husband Lie sell purses and footwear that they buy in Bolivia.

Delia is married, she is 32 years old and has 3 children. Delia sells candies and natural remedies in the convent of Santa Teresa. In the afternoons Delia sells Salchipollos (chicken hotdogs), she has also thought of opening a restaurant.

Yanira is a single mother, she is 25 years old and has one son, Yanira sells food in a stand in the Magdalene market. Yanira also sells clothes that she brings of the city of Lima and Trujillo.

Lie, Delia and Yanira need loans of 900 S., 1000 S., 900 S., money that will be invested in the purchase of purses, shoes, oil, potatoes, noodles, mustard, carbonated soft drinks, sweets, vegetables and clothes.

Lie's, Delia's and Yanira’s dreams are to travel abroad, to have their own retail stores and to offer their children a good education.

Translated from Spanish by Antonella Sacconi, Kiva Volunteer.

Lie, Delia y Yanira pertenecen al Banco Comunal Guadalupe hace 6 meses.

Lie es conviviente, tiene 25 años y 2 hijos, Lie al inicio vendía tubérculos y hace 2 meses cambio de negocio por la venta de cereales, sus productos lo compra en Andahuaylas y lo vende en el mercado Nery García. Además Lie junto a su esposo venden carteras, calzados que compran en Bolivia.

Por otro lado Delia es casada, tiene 32 años y 3 hijos, Delia vende dulces y remedios naturales en el convento de Santa Teresa. Además Delia por las tardes vende Salchipollos y tiene proyectado aperturar un restaurante.

Mientras que Yanira es madre soltera, tiene 25 años y 1 hijo, Yannira vende comida en un Kiosco en el mercado Magdalena. Además Yanira vende ropa a pedido, que trae de la ciudad de Lima y Trujillo.

Lie, Delia y Yanira necesitan présstamos de 900 S., 1000 S., 900 S., dinero que será invertido en la compra de carteras, zapatos, aceite, papa, fideo, mostaza, gaseosas, dulces, verduras y ropa.

Los sueños de Lie, Delia y Yanira son viajar al extranjero, tener local propio y brindarles una buena educación a sus hijos.

loans.use: Lie, Delia and Yanira need loans of 900 Soles, 1000 Soles, 900 Soles, money that will be invested in the purchase of purses, shoes, oil, potatoes, noodles, mustard, carbonated soft drinks, sweets, vegetables and clothes.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FINCA Peru - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es:
Margarita has been a member of the Comunal Bank Muchuy Warakaq, which means "wealth" in quechua, for the past 10 years.

Margarita is 41 years old and has 2 children. She sells animals such as hens, rabbits, and guinea pigs in the "April 12" market. Margarita has steady providers that sell her merchandise at her stand . Margarita also has a small grocery store where her husband and daughter work.

Margarita needs a loan of 2000 soles, with which she will buy hens, rabbits, guinea pigs, sugar, rice, oil, and noodles.

Margarita dreams of buying a car so that her son can work, roofing her home, have a better stocked grocery store and that her children are able to study and become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Samantha, Kiva volunteer.

Margarita es socia del Banco Comunal Muchuy Warakaq que significa “Abundancia” en quechua hace 10 años.

Margarita es conviviente, tiene 41 años y 2 hijos, Margarita vende animales menores como gallinas, conejo, cuy en el mercado 12 de abril, Margarita tiene proveedores fijos que le traen a su puesto. Además Margarita tiene una pequeña tienda de abarrotes en su casa donde venden su esposo e hija.

Margarita necesita un préstamo de 2000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de cuy, gallinas, conejo, azúcar, arroz, aceite y fideo.

Los sueños de Margarita son comprar un carro para que trabaje su hijo, techar su casa, tener una tienda de abarrotes más surtida, que sus hijos estudien y sean profesionales.

loans.use: To buy hens, rabbits, sugar, rice, oil, noodles, and guinea pigs for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FINCA Peru - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Cirila's Group

texts.es:
It has been ten years since Antonia and Cirila are members of the Muchuy Warakaq Communal Bank, which means “abundance” in Quechua. Antonia is married and is 60 years old, Antonia sells meat and cheese, she obtains the products at regional fairs. Besides this activity, Antonia raises cattle in her home town Rancha. Cirila is married, she is 45 years old and has 2 children. Cirila and her husband have a store to fix appliances and sale replacement parts, these products are acquired in the capital city of Lima. Antonia and Cirila need loans of 750 Soles, 1000 Soles, money that will be invested in the purchase of cattle, replacement parts for DVD players and television sets. The dreams of Antonia and Cirila are to roof their house, to have a successful business and see it prosper.

Translated from Spanish by Antonella Sacconi, Kiva Volunteer.

Antonia y Cirila pertenecen al Banco Comunal Muchuy Warakaq que significa “Abundancia” en quechua hace 10 años.

Antonia es casada y tiene 60 años, Antonia venD. carne y queso D. manera ambulatoria, sus productos lo adquiere en las ferias D. la región. Además Antonia se dedica al engorD. ganado vacuno en su pueblo D. Rancha.

Mientras que Cirila es casada, tiene 45 años y 2 hijos, Cirila junto a su esposo tienen una tienda para arreglar artefactos y venta D. repuestos, cuyos productos son adquiridos en la ciudad D. Lima.

Antonia y Cirila necesitan préstamos D. 750 soles, 1000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra D. ganado vacuno, repuestos para DVD y televisores.

Los sueños D. Antonia y Cirila son techar su casa, tener una empresa exitosa y que sus negocios prosperen.

loans.use: Antonia and Cirila need loans of 750 Soles, 1000 Soles, money that will be invested in the purchase of cattle, replacement parts for DVD players and television sets.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FINCA Peru - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Maria Rosario's Group

texts.es:
Edith, Gloria, and Rosario have been members of the Spring Communal Bank for 4, 3, and 1 years, respectively.

Edith is 25 years old, married, and has two children. She sells clothing and shoes on credit, at different markets in her hometown. On the weekends, Edith sells corn porridge and ceviche in her home.

Gloria is 23 years old and single, studying education at the university. Gloria sells fish in the Ayacuchana jungle. She also rents a motorcycle-taxi.

Rosario is married with three children. She is 38 years old. Rosario has a store in her home where she sells vegetables, meat, groceries, and photocopies.

Edith, Gloria, and Rosario need loans of 600 soles, 1000 soles, and 1000 soles, respectively. This money will be used to buy blankets, clothes, rice, and paper, and to repair Gloria’s motorcycle-taxi.

Edith, Gloria, and Rosario would like to finish their studies, and enroll in a masters program. They would like for their children to be professionals, improve their businesses, buy a car, and to have a store.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer.

Edith, Gloria y Rosario pertenecen al Banco Comunal Primavera hace 4, 3, 1 años respectivamente.

Edith es casada, tiene 25 años y 2 hijos, Edith vende ropa y zapatos a crédito, sus ventas lo realiza al por menor en los diferentes mercados. Además Edith los fines de semana vende mazamorras y cebiche en su casa.

Por otro lado Gloria es soltera y tiene 23 años, estudiante de Educación en la universidad, Gloria vende pescado en la selva Ayacuchana. Además tiene una mototaxi que alquila.

Mientras que Rosario es casada, tiene 38 años y 3 hijos, Rosario tiene una tienda en su casa donde vende verduras, carnes, abarrotes y además servicios de fotocopiado.

Edith, Gloria y Rosario necesitan préstamos de 600 soles, 1000 soles, 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de frazadas, ropa, arroz, papeles y para la reparación de su mototaxi.

Los sueños de Edith, Gloria y Rosario son culminar sus estudios, estudiar una maestría, que sus hijos sean profesionales, mejorar sus negocios, comprar un carro y tener una tienda.

loans.use: Edith, Gloria, and Rosario need loans of 600 soles, 1000 soles, and 1000 soles, respectively. This money will be used to buy blankets, clothes, rice, and paper, and to repair Gloria’s motorcycle-taxi.

loans.name: Enma Elisa

texts.es:
Enma has been a member of the Spring Communal Bank for eight months, where she learned to run her business. In this new cycle she will assume the position of President in her Communal Bank.

Enma is 32 years old, lives with her partner, and expecting is her first child. She travels the center of the city of Ayacucho, selling orange juice. With a loan, Enma will be able to open a seafood restaurant with her husband.

Enma needs a loan of 2000 soles, which she will use to buy tables, chairs, plates, and to pay rent.

Enma dreams of having a large seafood restaurant, so that her children can grow up to be professionals and she can finish building her house.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer.

Enma pertenece al Banco Comunal Primavera hace 8 meses, en su Banco Comunal aprendió a como administrar su negocio, en este nuevo ciclo ella asumirá el cargo de presidenta de su Banco Comunal.

Enma es conviviente, tiene 32 años y esta esperando su primer hijo, Enma vende jugo de naranja de manera ambulante en una calle céntrica de la ciudad de Ayacucho. Enma con el préstamo que obtendrá aperturará una cebichería junto a su esposo.

Enma necesita un préstamo de 2000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de mesas, sillas, platos y pago del local que alquilará para la cebichería.

Los sueños de Enma son tener una marisquería grande, sus hijos sean profesionales y terminar de construir su casa.

loans.use: Enma needs a loan of 2000 soles, which she will use to buy tables, chairs, plates, and to pay rent.

loans.name: Qatun Llaqta Group

texts.es:
The Qatun Llaqta Communal Bank means “Great People” in quechua. It’s young, as it was started a year ago. It currently has three cycles and 16 partners. The partners of this Communal Bank are from a variety of communities in the Socos state, where the population is employed in agriculture, especially growing corn and raising animals.

The partners note that the Communal Bank has taught them to be punctual and responsible, and to save.

The partners are engaged in a variety of businesses including selling food, vegetables, grains, firewood, raising small animals and embroidering blankets (these are used to carry supplies and children).

Each partner has a different story. Adela, for example, helps her husband sell firewood and embroiders beautiful blankets which she sells in the markets.

The partners need to borrow different amounts, including 300 soles, 450 soles, 600 soles, and 900 soles, for a total loan of 8,700 soles to the Communal Bank.

These loans will buy rice, sugar, carrots, squash, onions, thread, cord, wheat, beans, eucalyptus trees, guinea pigs, and chickens.

The partners dream of seeing their businesses grow and their children receive a better education than they did.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer.

El Banco Comunal Qatun Llaqta que significa “Pueblo GranD.” en quechua, es un banco joven que se inició hace 1 año. Actualmente tiene 3 ciclos y 16 socias. Las socias D. este Banco Comunal son D. diferentes comunidades del Distrito D. Socos, donD. la población se dedica a la agricultura en especial D. maíz y crianza D. animales.

Las socias mencionan que en el Banco Comunal las socias aprendieron a ser puntuales, responsables y a ahorrar.

Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la venta D. comida, verduras, cereales, leña, crianza D. animales menores y bordado D. mantas (que son utilizadas para cargar bultos y sus hijos)

Cada socia tiene una historia diferente como es el caso D. Adela que junto a su esposo venden leña y además Adela hace bellos bordados en mantas que luego venD. en las ferias.

Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. préstamos, algunos montos son D. 300 soles, 450 soles, 600 soles, 900 soles, haciendo un total D. 8,700 soles D. préstamos en el Banco Comunal.

Los préstamos lo invertirán en la compra arroz, azúcar, zanahoria, zapallo, cebolla, hilos, maíz, trigo, haba, árboles D. eucalipto, cuy y gallina.

Los sueños D. las socias es que sus negocios crezcan y que sus hijos sean mejores que ellas con una educación.

loans.use: These loans will buy rice, sugar, carrots, squash, onions, thread, cord, wheat, beans, eucalyptus trees, guinea pigs, and chickens.

loans.name: Milagros Group

texts.es:
The “Milagros” (Miracles) microfinance institute is just opening with 18 members, who are starting with lots of enthusiasm.

The members partake in different businesses, such as the sale of cosmetics, sweets, cereals, groceries, flowers, clothing, food, footwear, plastic goods, and handicrafts.

The members need different loan amounts; some need 300 Peruvian soles, while others need 600, bringing their total to 8,400 soles in loans from the microfinance institute.

They will invest those loans in the purchase of sugar, rice, noodles, cooking oil, milk, detergent, corn, wheat, quinoa, barley, footwear, pants, polo shirts, lotions, perfume, and cosmetics.

The members dream that their children will become professionals, that they will have more capital for their businesses, and that their business will be more prosperous.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

El Banco Comunal Milagros es un banco que recién inicia con18 socias, que inician con mucho entusiasmo.

Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la venta D. cosméticos, golosinas, cereales, abarrotes, flores, ropa, comida, calzados, artículos plásticos y elaboración D. manualidades.

Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. préstamos, algunos montos son D. 300 soles, 600 soles, haciendo un total D. 8,400 soles D. préstamos en el Banco Comunal.

Los préstamos lo invertirán en la compra D. azúcar, arroz, fideo, aceite, leche, detergentes, maíz, trigo, quinua, cebada, calzados, pantalones, polos, cremas, perfumes y cosméticos.

Los sueños D. las socias son que sus hijos sean profesionales, tener mas capital para sus negocios y que sus negocios sean prósperos.

loans.use: Purchase of sugar, rice, noodles, cooking oil, milk, detergent, corn, wheat, quinoa, barley, footwear, pants, polo shirts, lotions, perfume, and cosmetics

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FINCA Peru - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Janett's Group

texts.es:
Raida, Janett, and Hermelinda have been members of Los Ladrilleros de Compañia Communal Bank for a year.

Raida lives with her partner, is 21 years old, and has a one year old daughter. Janett is 28 years old, and lives with her partner and three children. Hermelinda is 34 years old, and lives with her partner and five children.

Raida, Janett, and HErmelinda are from the Compañía community, 40 minutes outside of the city of Ayachucho. Together with their partners they create artisan bricks and sell them to distributors in their community.

Raida, Janett, and Hermelinda need loans of 1250 soles, 450 soles, and 900 soles, which they will use to purchase sand, clay, plastic, tools, firewood, and to pay wages.

Raida, Janett, and Hermelinda would like to have houses of their own in the city of Ayachucho. They hope to produce greater quantities of brick that their children can be professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer.

Raida, Janett y Hermelinda pertenecen al Banco Comunal Los Ladrilleros de Compañía hace 1 año.

Raida es conviviente, tiene 21 años y 1 hija de 1 año. Por otro lado Yaneth es conviviente, tiene 28 años y 3 hijos. Mientras que Hermelinda es conviviente, tiene 34 años y 5 hijos.

Raida, Janett y Hermelinda son de la comunidad de Compañía que esta a 40 minutos de la ciudad de Ayacucho, ellas junto a sus esposos se dedican a la fabricación de ladrillos artesanales y sus ventas lo realizan en su misma comunidad a intermediarios.

Raida, Janett y Hermelinda necesitan préstamos de 1250 soles, 450 soles, 900 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de arena, arcilla, plásticos, herramientas, leña y para el pago de peones.

Los sueños de Raida, Janett y Hermelinda son tener casa propia en la ciudad de Ayacucho, que sus hijos sean profesionales y producir sus ladrillos en más cantidad.

loans.use: Raida, Janett, and Hermelinda need loans of 1250 soles, 450 soles, and 900 soles, which they will use to purchase sand, clay, plastic, tools, firewood, and to pay wages.

loans.name: Julie

texts.es:
Julie has been a member of Los Sauces Communal Bank for one year, where she learned values and how to save.

Julie is 40 years old, and married with three children. Julie sells caña (liquor made from sugar cane) to local stores, and her husband travels to the city of Apurimac to buy the caña. Julie recently installed a store in her house where she sells caña, sodas, candies, and would like to expand her selection.

Julie needs a loan of 1500 soles, which she will invest in the purchase of caña, sodas, sugar, rice, and noodles, thereby supplying her business.

Julie dreams of helping her children get ahead, so that they can become professionals. Julie would like to expand her business and own her home.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer.

Julie pertenece al Banco Comunal Los Sauces hace 1 año, en su Banco Comunal aprendió los valores y a ahorrar.

Julie es casada, tiene 40 años y 3 hijos, Julie vende caña (aguardiente elaborado de caña de azúcar) y sus ventas lo realiza de tienda en tienda, su esposo es quien viaja a la ciudad de Apurimac para comprar la caña. Recientemente Julie aperturó una tienda en su casa donde vende caña, gaseosas, golosinas y piensa surtir más su negocio.

Julie necesita un préstamo de 1500 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de caña, gaseosas, azúcar, arroz, fideo y así surtir más su negocio .

Los sueños de Julie es sacar adelante a sus hijos y sean profesionales, ampliar su negocio y tener casa propia.

loans.use: Julie needs a loan of 1500 soles, which she will invest in the purchase of caña, sodas, sugar, rice, and noodles, thereby supplying her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FINCA Peru - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Maria Mercedes' Group

texts.es:
Maria, Glenda, and Sara have been members of the Los Sauces Communal Bank for one year.

Maria is married, with two children. She is 43 years old. Maria sells cosmetics from a catalog, weaves jerseys, bakes cakes and home-made chocolates. She sells her products to friends, family, co-workers, and in her children’s school. Maria also has a project to make dried potatoes.

Glenda is 19, and lives with her partner and one year old son. Glenda and her husband recycle scraps such as bottles, cans, and copper, among others. Glenda also works as a cook at a hotel.

Sara is 22 years old and single, studying to be a nurse. Sara rents a small store where she sells candy and school supplies.

Maria, Glenda, and Sara need 750, 1000, and 1000 soles, which will go to purchase potatoes, recycling products, soft drinks, cookies, and school supplies.

Maria, Glenda, and Sara dream that their children will be great businesspeople, have a wholesale business, have a business and finish their career.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer.

Maria, Glenda y Sara pertenecen al Banco Comunal Los Sauces hace 1 año.

Maria es casada, tiene 43 años y 2 hijos, Maria vende cosméticos por catálogo, teje chompas, elabora queques y chocolates caseros, sus productos los ofrece a amigos, familiares, compañeros de trabajo y en el colegio de sus hijos. Además Maria tiene proyectado hacer papa seca.

Por otro lado Glenda es conviviente, tiene 19 años y 1 hijo de 1 año, Glenda junto a su esposo se dedican al reciclaje de chatarra como botellas descartables, latas, cobre, entre otros. Además Glenda trabaja en un hospedaje como cocinera.

Mientras que Sara es soltera y tiene 22 años, estudiante de enfermería, Sara tiene una pequeña tienda de golosinas, útiles escolares en un local alquilado.

Maria, Glenda y Sara necesitan préstamos de 750 soles, 1000 soles, 1000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de papa, productos de reciclaje, gaseosas, galletas, útiles escolares.

Los sueños de Maria, Glenda y Sara son que sus hijos sean grandes empresarios, tener un negocio mayorista, tener una empresa y terminar su carrera.

loans.use: Maria, Glenda, and Sara need 750, 1000, and 1000 soles, which will go to purchase potatoes, recycling products, soft drinks, cookies, and school supplies

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Mrs. Chea R., a 74-year-old widow, makes around $8 per day selling bags from her home in the Prek Krobao 3 Village, Kandal Province. She has two married children who sell bags at the Prek Leap Market. R. now requests a loan of $800 to purchase more bags to sell. With the income generated by her business, she will be able to support her family’s financial stability easily. She appreciates Kiva for their support. R. and her client appear in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase more bags to sell

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Mrs. Chea R., a 74-year-old widow, makes around $8 per day selling bags from her home in the Prek Krobao 3 Village, Kandal Province. She has two married children who sell bags at the Prek Leap Market. R. now requests a loan of $800 to purchase more bags to sell. With her income is generated by her business, She will be able to support her family’s financial stability easily and appreciates Kiva for their support. R. and her client are in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase more bags to sell

loans.name: Phum

texts.en:
Mrs. Phum S., 51, has a motorbike-washing business in the Chhlang Moeung Tbong Village in Kandal Province where she earns about $2.5 per day. She lives with her husband, Thlang Pruonh, 54, and her only child, who repairs motorbikes and drives a soil truck. Pruonh earns around $2.5 per day as a soldier.

Mrs. S. now seeks a $800 loan to buy a air pumping machine for using in her motorbike-washing business. With the income generated by her business, she will be able to support her family’s financial stability easily.

loans.use: To buy a air pumping machine for using in her motorbike-washing business

loans.name: Keo

texts.en:
Keo M. is a 48-year-old mother of five children who lives in Kampong Cham province. To raise the family’s income, she works as a chef in a restaurant, normally earning around $3 a day. Her husband, Teng Chea, who is a farmer, makes less than one dollar a day. One child is married and lives away from home. Two others are garment workers with a salary $70 a month, as well as being students.

To increase the family income, Teng Chea, is requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase wood to make a bed to sell for extra profit. With the remainder, he will buy fertilizer to put on his farmland.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and to buy wood to make a bed to sell.

loans.name: Yang

texts.en:
Yang P., 68, is a mother of four children and works as a farmer. On average, she makes less than one dollar a day. Her husband, Ken Chen, age 71, is also a farmer, eventually earning around $1 a day of profit. All of their children are employed by a garment factory with a salary $80 each a month.

This couple needs a loan from Kiva to purchase a motorbike for transportation from their house to the field. Any leftover money will be used to purchase fertilizer for their farmland. (Mr. Ken Chen is pictured because Mrs. Yang P. was not available.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike and fertilizer.

loans.name: Long

texts.en:
Long T., 45, is a mother of nine children and has resided in Kampong Cham province since 1991 with her husband. She works as a cart driver. On average, she earns around $5 a day in profit. Her husband, Mr. Man Yon, age 46, supports the household as farmer growing rice on his farmland. Normally, he earns around $4 a day of income. Three of their children are married and live away from home.

He would like to borrow from Kiva to buy a plot of farmland to grow more rice in order to increase his output.

loans.use: To purchase a plot of farmland.

loans.name: Be

texts.en:
Be H. is 34 years old and lives with her family in Kampong Cham province. To support the family’s income, she works as a farmer and earns, on average, $2 a day of profit. Her husband, Mr. Kong Touch, age 36, is also a farmer and makes less than $1 a day. They have two children, both of them are students and earn no profit

This couple wants to request a loan from Kiva to purchase wood to repair the leaking roof in their house. In the future, if they have enough money, they will own a grocery stand.

loans.use: To purchase wood to fix the leaking roof.

loans.name: Njem

texts.en:
Njem M., age 47, is a widow, who works as a housewife and has three children. She and her children have lived in the central part of Kampong Cham province, Cambodia since 1990. One of her daughters is a hairdresser in a busy market, and she always gives $5 a day to her mother. Most of Mrs. M.'s daily expenses are cover by her daughter.

So the family would like a load to get a booth for her daughter's business and to purchase hairdressing equipment. This will allow the child to save in the future and enlarge her business site, and they will have enough money to support the household.

In the photo, Njem M. is shown with her daughter.

loans.use: To purchase hair dresser equipment.

loans.name: Phan

texts.en:
Phan H., age 31, stays at home with her older sister and her two cousins. She has not married yet.

To meet her daily expenses, she would like a loan from Kiva to purchase stone to make a small grinding mill for 2 kg to 5 kg use. Before this, she stayed at home and made no profit. Every day she was given some money to spend on food. With this money, she can make a profit to help purchase food.

loans.use: To purchase stone to make a small grinding mill.

loans.name: Linh

texts.en:
Mrs. Linh S. is a mother of four children and has resided in Kampong Cham with her husband since 1998. She has a business selling fish in a busy market and makes $7 each day in revenue.

Her husband, Heap Pheap, makes Khmer wine at home. On average, he earns $2 a day of profit. This wine is made from rice and most of the Cambodian people like it very much because does not harm people's health. The couple has four children. Two are too young to attend school and the other two are students.

To help the family to earn more profit from selling fish, she needs to have some more money to purchase fish and resell in the market.

Mrs. Linh S. and her two youngest sons appear in the photo.

loans.use: To order more fish to sell in the market.
